For iTunes 6 (don't know if it works with earlier versions), select all the files you want (edit->select all), click on copy, then paste them to a folder/USB drive/CD burner to transfer them to your new computer. You can then install iTunes on the new machine and import the files. Not sure what happens to tunes you've bought on iTunes, but I assume they'll work once your new computer has been registered.. . For playlists, use File->Export Library... or File->Export Song List... on the old machine and File->Import... on the new machine.The iLounge has all sorts of tutorials on iPod and iTunes useThis is easy enough with iTunes 4 or greater.  Install the iTunes on the new computer first.  The use a network connection, USB flash drive (memory stick) or CD (or DVD) burning software to backup you iTunes Music Library.  You can then either import the songs and playlist into the new computer or (with iTunes 4) copy and then recreate the Music Library file.. . This is so much easier with and iPod set to automatic mode.

Voice memo from what device?  That depends.  I do know of a way to turn anything into a ring tone for your cell phone, however, it depends on how good you are with a computer and if you have the appropriate hardware.  . . The first thing you will need is a sound card with a line in connection.  The second thing you will need is some sort of headset connected to the line in.. . The third thing is a free audio editing program known as Audacity, it has two versions 1.2.4 stable and 1.3 beta, I like the beta version.  You will also need the LAME MP3 encoder associated with Audacity to export your recording as a MP3 file.. . Using the headset you will use Audacity to record the voice memo (by actually saying what you want) and then exporting that recording as a MP3 file.. . Maybe there is an easier way that I am not thinking of and if anyone knows I would ask them to post as well.

email them and ask :)There are a few FCC approved testing labs that will test out your product to see if it meets the FCC standards. They will submit a report to the FCC and get it approved, they will also obtain a FCC logo and a certification number. This process usually costs around USD3k-5k depending on how many times the tests need to be repeated. You can look for a suitable testing agency near your area by contacting the FCC folks.

A SLR camera is a single-lens reflex camera.  The single-lens reflex is a type of camera that uses a movable mirror placed between the lens and the film to project the image seen through the lens to a matte focusing screen. Most SLRs use a pentaprism to observe the image via an eyepiece, but there are also other finder arrangements, such as the waist-level finder or porro prisms.  You can visit the website below for a more detailed overview.Basically, it is a "What you see is what you get" camera, ie. the viewfinder shows what will actually appear on the picture. (Used to be, the older cameras without it had a slight shift because of the distance between the lens and the viewfinder).Since nowadays, digital cameras allow you to see exactly what picture is being taken through the viewfinder, the main advantage of a digital SLR is the fact you can use interchangable lenses.. . That, and the fact that the sensors on digital SLRs are larger, and produce images with less noise.. . There is also generally a much larger feature set on  digital SLRs since they are geared more for the advanced photographer.. . But will a digital SLR take better images? Not necessarily. The most important factor is always going to be the person behind the camera.

Then look for an fm transmitter for mp3 players that is not iPod-specific.. http://www.google.com/search?q=fm+transmitter+mp3. . I have both an fm transmitter and a casette adapter for my iPod. Consider finding a transmitter that you can open and add your own antenna. SLR stands for "Single-lens Reflex".  It's a way of constructing a camera so that when the photographer looks through the viewpiece, they are actually looking through the lens of the camera and can see how the photo will be framed.  The viewpiece on other kinds of cameras will be slightly off from the actual photo that will be taken.Single lens reflex.. . Essentially what it means is that the viewfinder operates optically through the actual lens rather than a separate optical tunnel like in cheaper cameras.  This means that what you see is what the lens sees, without any parallax effects at close range.  The viewfinder is much sharper than an electronic one, and it is much more useful in low light.  Also, the vast majority of SLR cameras allow you to change lenses easily.1. Single Lens Reflex.. 2. Others are super duper wastes.. . This has some real good information.Hi !!!. . "Single lens reflex (SLR).. . A type of camera in which the photographer looks through the actual taking lens when he or she peers through the viewfinder.. . Light entering an SLR camera lens hits a mirror installed in the body at a 45° angle, which deflects the light up into the viewfinder pentaprism. When the photograph is actually taken the mirror flips up out of the way, the shutter opens and light strikes the surface of the film behind it. (the one exception being fixed pellicle mirror SLRs). . SLRs have a couple of very significant advantages. First, they do not suffer from parallax error, which makes them useful for closeup or macro photography. Second, what you see is mostly what you get - you can see the effects of filters, for example, before you take the photo. The image in an SLR viewfinder is also not reversed or upside-down, as is the case with TLRs and view cameras.. . There are also a number of disadvantages to SLRs. First, the pentaprism is bulky - it’s the large hump on the top of an SLR. Second, the noise of the mirror slap means that SLRs are always much louder to operate than, say, rangefinders. Third, there is a brief mirror blackout period on most SLRs during which nothing can be seen in the viewfinder (fixed pellicle mirror SLRs being the one exception again). And finally, the mirror forms a physical barrier for the design of very wide-angle lenses, requiring inverted telephoto construction.". . I suggest you to go through the article "How Cameras Work" on www.howstuffworks.com for better idea with picture illustrations.  Link: http://science.howstuffworks.com/camera7.htm. . . >>> Naveen KumarSLR stands for 'single lens reflex'.  SLR cameras use an adjustable mirror to focus an incoming image as it passes from the lens to the focusing screen inside the camera.

This site should help answer all your questions.. . http://electronics.howstuffworks.com/digital-camera1.htmA digital camera works in much the same way as a film camera.  The camera (and its lense) allow light to come into the camera.  In a digital camera a sensor (typically a CCD sensor) captures and records the light that is captured coming into the camera.  The camera then takes this captured information and stores it on either a storage card or within the memory of the camera itself.i lets u take picsread instructions
Heat and cold DOES have an effect on how a battery functions. A battery in cold conditions doesn't function as well. Think about the difference between how your car starts in the winter and how it starts in the summer.It could possibly be just be a myth, but if it is true the reason would be because the sun heats up the molecules and particles inside of the battery causing them to become more active. . . In a abstract essence, it's like giving someone caffeine because it boosts the person's energy levels. It's the same with the chemicals located inside of the battery.
If your talking about services such as DISH Network or DirecTV, they deliver TV by means of DBS (Direct Broadcast Satelite). Heres how the signals get to a customers home. . . DISH Network sends their own relay satelites in to space, and they shoot it upwards up to 32,000 feet in to space. Within this atmosphere is called, the "Clarke Belt." It is possible for satelites to work is because of the clarke belt. In this atmosphere, satelites are able to spin with the earth. . . Next, to actually deliver the TV signal to the customers home, a technique called, "The M Pattern." I'm going to use HBO as an example. . . 1. HBO has on-ground satelites that send programming signal to HBO's transponders in space (the job of the transponders is, it relay's the signal to the ground). . 2. Then from HBO's transponders in space, it shoots down the signal to DISH Networks on-ground satelites. . 3. Next, DISH Networks on-ground satelites shoot it back up to DISH Networks transponders. From their the signal is digitized, compressed and encoded. . 4. From DISH Networks transponders, the signal is shot back down to the customers home satelite dish. . . The customers receivers contain a card which is encoded. When the signal is shot down to the customers home, the receiver only has a partial code to unlock the portion in which the customer has paid for.Satellite recorders such as Tivo works by using an internal hard drive that records any content that runs through it such as what is on your television screen.  When you rewind, pause, or skip, it gets that data off of the hard drive which is already recorded to it.  It is always recording content that your watching.. . The following links will help explain how satellites and recoders (Tivo/DVR/PVR) work.

That really depends on the specific device.  Certainly nothing cooler than 50 degrees (Fahrenheit).  Though if you have a LCD or Plasma TV I would be leery about taking those below 60 degrees.  Though your computer could survive (off) pretty good in 40 degrees.  If you are intending to do this, when you come back and turn the heat on, let everything adjust to the warmer temperatures before you turn them on.The answer depends on the equipment, and whether you're talking "storage temperature" (equipment not running) or "operating temperature."  Almost every consumer product will be OK at storage temperatures down to freezing, but you'll need to warm them up again before turning them on.  (Remember that all that stuff you see at Best Buy has to be able to put up with sitting in unheated trucks for days on the way up to Fargo ND in winter!)  Operating home electronics below, say, 50 degrees probably won't hurt them, but they may not work properly until things warmed up.

A dock is an easy way to recharge and transfer pictures from your digital camera. For example rather than removing the battery and putting it in a charger, then connecting a cable to your camera and in your computer asking the pictures to be transfered, you can just stick it in the dock and press one button on the side. The pictures will be transfered automatically and you will never have to wonder if the battery is charged if you leave the camera in the dock when not in use.No, I don't think so.  The dock is just a simple method to transfer pictures from your camera to your computer.  I would guess the camera comes with everything necessary to do that (probably a USB cable).. . The TiVo (t?-v?) personal video recorder is a consumer video component allowing users to capture television programming to internal hard drive storage. TiVo systems can function similarly to VCRs, but use non-removable hard-disk storage, and contain much more sophisticated software to record programming - not only programs the user specifically requests, but also other material the user is likely to be interested in. ...http://www.tivo.com. Basically night vision goggles work by boosting the gain electronically in the display unit to enhance the amount of light (infrared light usually) that we see. This is different from thermal imaging, which lights a pixel at a certian level dependent on the heat that pixel is picking up.Simply, night vision goggles amplify available light, mixing it with infared light, then enhance contrast to produce a visible image.
Have you ever heard of Gammadyne's DJ Jukebox (not to be confused with the Dell DJ Jukebox MP3 player).   This is a playlist generator where you can give songs numerical ratings and set other play criteria to control your listening experience.   You could create three directories and depending on the number of songs per directory and the ratings you assign, you should be able to approximate the experience you want.The first answer sounds like a good one!just do it!!!

A dark brown ink or pigment originally prepared from the secretion of the cuttlefish.Sepia is an earthy yellowish tone usually associated with old looking photographs. You can buy sepia toner to artificially create this effect on new black and white pictures... or you can apply a "sepia effect" to a digital image with many photo editing applications (such as Photoshop).. . Sepia is also the name of a tan/brown hue, as it pertains to paint or pigment.A dark brown color applied to photographs or other prints.

"Shutter lag, the delay between depressing the shutter button and capturing the image, measured an impressive 1/10 second when pre-focused using the optical viewfinder; use of the LCD monitor adds less than 1/10 second to the pre-focused lag because of the delay in presenting the live viewfinder image, one of the most responsive LCD's I've used."

will it depends if it is a power subwoofer and the receiver has a subwoofer preout you simply need a subwoofer cable and you would connect the preout from the receiver to the sub input. if it is a passive sub meaning it is not power by its our amp you then see several speaker jacks on the back of the sub. these jacks are input and out jacks. this would require you to run speaker wire from the front speaker jacks on the receiver to the input speaker jacks on the sub then you would run the out speaker jacks on the sub to you front speakers.. the fastest way to find if it is passive or not if is is powered by the wall is not passive.. also read the owners manual to see is your reciever would need to have the subwoofer preout turned on through the menu option of the receiver.The above answer is good. Organic LSD is produced by certain type of mushrooms - the so called "magic mushrooms". They have an extremely poisonous mimic, the only difference being:. when it is cut close to the ground the poisonous has pink circle, while the "magic" one has brownOrganic LCD crystals are grown.  When a current is passed through them instead of only generating a color (requiring a backlight to make the color visible) the organic LCD crystals also generate light or luminence with that color.. . Also, this type of LCD is much more efficient because it doesn't take much energy to get it give off color + light elliminating the need for a backlight.  The backlight in LCD devices is where a lot of the power goes right now.  . . Imagine if your cell phone would last for hours more just because the screen was more efficient... or your handheld PDA or gaming system... pretty exciting stuff.. . Go to those links others gave you for more information. I just wanted to give you the short summary version.A new type of display technology that is set to be "next big thing" in displays.. . http://www.audioholics.com/techtips/specsformats/organic_OLEDs_1.htm

To do this hold down the on/off switch and press the reset button on the back.  A message will appear asking if you want to erase all data, if you do, select yes and the device will reset. S-Video is only for video and no audio is transmitted.   To send audio from the headphone or line-out jack on your laptop you'll need a 1/8" Mini Stereo to RCA Cable.  The Mini-Stereo adapter plugs into your laptop and the RCA portion (the red and white connectors) will plug into your TV.   An example of one is linked below.S-video is only video.  You need to add the audio connection whatever that may be.  Try Radio Shack for an adapter.
TFT stands for "Thin Film Transistor" and refers to a type of LCD panel. It is the standard technology used by LCD screens these days.TFT. (Thin Film Transistor) The term typically refers to active matrix screens on laptop computers. Active matrix LCD provides a sharper screen display and broader viewing angle than does passive matrix. See LCD and thin film.

trans came from the word TRANSmit and CEIVER came from the word reCEIVER, hence  it means an apparatus that can transmit audio/video signals and also receive audio/video signals. video sender is also a transceiver like videophoneA transceiver is a device that has a transmitter and a receiver which are combined. The portmanteau term originates around World War II. Technically, transceivers must combine a significant amount of the transmitter and receiver handling circuitry. Similar devices include transponders, transverters, and repeaters.. . http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transceiverin simple terms , a tranceiver is an electronic device that can do two things , one recieve signals and the other send signals electronicaly! this may be by wire or wireless. most noted units were the C.B. radio! Now the most noted units are cell phones. A video sender takes a video signal ..processes the information and "transmits" that information to another reciever most likely attached to a vcr or vcd . i use a wireless video sender on my camcorder for recording remotely on a home powered recorder! saves battery life and the tape is usually better quality unless i connect directly to my computer and record directly to hard drive. hope that helps.

DivX® is a video codec created by DivX, Inc. (formerly DivXNetworks, Inc.), regarded for its ability to compress lengthy video segments into small sizes while maintaining relatively high visual quality. DivX uses lossy MPEG-4 Part 2 compression, where quality is balanced against file size for utility. It is one of several codecs commonly associated with ripping, where audio and video multimedia are transferred to a hard disk and transcoded. As a result, DivX has been a center of controversy because of its use in the replication and distribution of copyrighted DVDs.. Its a high quality codec though has a smaller size(MB) than other codecs.Divx is a file format commonly used for video files. The divx player is a program for playing video files (divx and otherwise) with. It's an excellent player and I highly recommend it.Well divX also compresses hugh movie files into small ones < without compromising picture quality >.Like for eg a 1GB file can be sized down to 200mb using divX.
A sound format that produces five discrete channels of sound in the left, right, center, left rear and right rear positions. 5.1 systems also have 1 channel for LFE (low frequency effects), which is normally sent to a subwoofer.it's for srereo. it means there are 5 speakers and 1 subwoofer. . 1 center channel. 2 fronts L & R. 2 rear L & R. 1 sub
The best answer is, it depends on the computer architecture. In a personal computer, cpu and microprocessor are one and the same. In a larger computer such as an AS400, the cpu is a seperate unit with lots of microprocessors and other chips. The larger the computer system, the more spread out the cpu functions are among components."In the world of personal computers, the terms microprocessor and CPU are used interchangeably."Technically a microprocessor is an element/part where as cpu (central processor) is a unit/set of microprocessor(s)

I believe you mean the difference between interlaced and progressive.  Interlaced means it shows every other line in first and then fills in the gap the next one.  Progressive means it displays all the lines at the same time.. . See link below for more details.Wrong, progressive scans ahead.
Issues of compatibility.The Palm E2 PDA uses Palm's new HotSync connector, which debuted in the T|5 and Treo 650 models.  The E uses a mini USB connector not supported by most dock accessories.  Unlike the Palm E PDA, you can purchase a cradle separately for the E2.
sound quality is everything depending on the brand will depend on the effeciency along with the frequency response of each speaker and watts supplied from the stereo or receiveryou can buy a spl meeter, sound pressure level meeter at radio shack, not very exp.. determine what your ratings are via labels on speakers and measure that with spl meeter. If you are not reaching the specs, more amplifier power may be required. some speakers are more efficient than others based on the power handleing capabillities, and more power than said requirments is ussualy better!
magic!  try it some time.The camera is mechanism that flickers a lense to capture pictures and blast them onto a roll of film that you can take to any store and get it developed.A camera is a device used to take pictures (usually photographs), either singly or in sequence, with or without sound recording, such as with video cameras. A camera that takes pictures singly is sometimes called a photo camera to distinguish it from a video camera. The name is derived from camera obscura, Latin for "dark chamber", an early mechanism for projecting images in which an entire room functioned much as the internal workings of a modern photographic camera, except there was no way at this time to record the image short of manually tracing it. Cameras may work with the visual spectrum or other portions of the electromagnetic spectrum.

SP = Short Play; LP = Long Play. SP has a higher quality, but takes up more or the tape. Whereas LP has a lower quality, but uses less tape. Longer recording time comes with lower quality.sp is short play but good quality. lp long play is long but not as good quality
Not all DVD players read +r. Also; older DVD players don'r read alot of burned formats.Older DVD players may not read all bookypes. If you are trying to play burned DVD's the best option would be to burn in DVD-ROM format, rather than DVD-r or +r. Many DVD burners will have an option or utility that will change the booktype for you.. . If it's commercial DVD's that are not playing, try cleaning the DVD Heads with a cleaning disk, and make sure that the disk you are trying to burn is also clean.

Most DVD recorders have copy protection detection though, preventing you from recording commercial VHS tapes, but for the recordings you have made off of a TV or camcorder, DVD recorders work just fine.Dazzle makes an external capture card.  This will allow you to connect your VHS machine to the dazzle board, use some software to capture the video that is going thru the card, then use another piece of software to burn a dvd.. . I did this with most of my VHS collection. digital ( DV ) also records to tape, they just do not use the nalog method that older cam corders use. most all DVd cams use a 1394 ( firewire ) connection to the computer and thus a digital connection and no generational loss when trasferring over . Analag must use the RCA cable connects and must be caputured over to the computer, bandwidth is not the same and thus thogh the foramt is RAW uncompressed AVI, it does not compared to the RAW uncompressed AVI from a DV cam. DVD simple trounces it, but analog cams are cheaper.. . Newer "digital" based cams that record to mem stick are a joke ATM, trying to be all in ones ( with camera still duty ) leads to resoltion / time comprimises. They are ok for web uplods were hi quality is not a factor, but I would never use them for anything serious.i like the digital ones because one time you buy a memory and its enough . its very easy to send them to pc and make dvd or cd's of them or a nice album and ... and for sure you can edit them whith nice programs  :)Without getting into the technology too much, an analog camcorder will record the sound and video to magnetic tape, like a VHS tape.  A digital records to computer memory.  If you are planning on transfering the videos to your computer and burning cd'd or dvd's out of them, go with the digital.  If you don't have a computer, go with the analog.
CD players play a different format than mp3. Even if you put 20MB worth of mp3's on there, they are converted into a different, much larger format. Standard CD players can't play mp3's.It says 700Mb data and "so many minutes" (probly 70 or 80) of music.  Come on.  Use your head.it depends on how u put music in the disc. If u made an "audio" cd..it makes the music files in WAV. WAV files are huge. If u made an MP3 CD, u can fit about 92 songs..but u need a CD player that plays MP3s.If you burn the disk as an audio disk the files are converted to the orginal CD format and are larger. MP3 and WMA are compressed and have a smaller file size.There must be files on the CD already; get another blank disc.A blank CD (or just about any CD) can hold up to 700 MB of data. When you convert the contents of a music or audio CD (the uncompressed music) to the MP3 format the files become smaller. MP3 files can be 10 times smaller (or more) in size when compared to the original audio track, depending on the quality and other settings you use when converting or "ripping" them from a music CD.

DIFFERENTIAL INPUTS - A signal input circuit where SIGNAL LO and SIGNAL HI are electrically floating with respect to ANALOG GROUND.. . SINGLE-ENDED INPUTS - A single-ended input has no commond mode range because there is only ONE low wire, which is shared by all inputs.Good input :-P
"A Digital Video Recorder is a generic term for a device that is similar to a VCR but records television data in digital on a hard drive as opposed to a VCR tape. A DVR looks like a VCR and has all of the same functionality of VCR (recording, playback, fast forwarding, rewinding, and pausing) plus the ability to skip to any part of the program without having to rewind or fast forward the data stream."A DVR stands for Digital Video Recorder. It records the show your watching and then it can rewind it so you can watch it overA digital video recorder (DVR) is a device that records video to a digital storage medium in digital form. The term DVR may be used to describe a piece of equipment such as a Personal Video Recorder (PVR) or a CCTV DVR. It may also be used to reference a function in a piece of equipment such as a digital video camera that has a DVR function built into it.. . Television and video are terms that are sometimes used interchangeably but in their narrow definitions are different. Video is the visual portion of television where as television is video and audio modulated onto, (combined with), a carrier frequency, (television channel), so that it may be transported either wirelessly or over cables with many other frequencies, (channels).a dvr is a cd that you can build movies with it

A digital camera is nothing more than a film camera with a different image capturing system.  You use a digital camera in the same way that you use a film camera.  The difference is that the sensitivity to the light that comes into the camera is much more in film than digital.  This means that you are able to capture more extremes of light and dark with film.Turn the dial to the picture of the green camera.. . Use the power button to turn the camera on.. . Firmly press the big button on the top right to take a picture.Refer to the USAGE MANUAL, or if you don't have it, go to SONY's website, you'll find it all there.

An ultrasonic humidifier uses a metal diaphragm vibrating at an ultrasonic frequency, much like the element in a high-frequency speaker, to create water droplets. An ultrasonic humidifier is usually silent, and also produces a cool fog.Ultrasonic Humidifier (Cool Mist Humidifier) - A metal diaphram vibrating at an ultrasonic frequency creates water droplets that exit the humidifier in the form of a cool fog. Although silent, Ultrasonic Humidifiers should be cleaned regularly to avoid bacterial contamination which may be projected into the air.

When someone calls the call goes through a series of computers. One of the computers jobs is to send the caller ID data to your Caller ID box or Phone with Caller ID a message encoded in 1's and 0's which is assembled as your name and phone number information. This process is very similar to the way data is sent over the internet from modem to modem.whenever someone calls it tracks the number in which it is calling from and shows it to you on the screenCaller ID is really what your phone is registered under at your phone company. When the call goes through to your phone, the phone company sends information about that caller. This information is in a series of 1's and 0's. Your phone then decodes this information and displays it on the screen. If you were to block your name/number, the phone company would send the message, Blocked Call.. For more information go to:. http://electronics.howstuffworks.com/framed.htm?parent=question409.htm&url=http://www.ainslie.org.uk/callerid/cli_faq.htm

The phone buttons have alphabet characters on them, and since we read from top to bottom, left to right, it makes sense to have the numbers go top to bottom, left to right.  On a calculator, there are no letters, and as our hand rests on the ten-key portion of the keyboard, it makes sense for us to reach farther to hit the higher valued keys.  No doubt this is a carryover from mechanical adding machines of yore.This is more for ergonomic reasons - 0's and 1's are the most used numbers. I wish I had just one 0 added to my paycheck (before the decimal)!Calculators were developed first, around 1893 Thomas Edison first transformed an abacus into a calculator using his new telephone technology.  Phones were developed in the Mirror Kingdom, where as you know, all things appear upside down and backwards.

You can simply clean a CD with window cleaner and a soft non-abrasive cloth. If you have scratchs on the CD, toothpaste works well to fix the disc. Just coat the disc with a dab and use the same soft cloth to work it around. It works extremely well.when you wipe, go from the middle out, don't go in circles, that ruins the coating finish and could make your CD/DVDs skip.gently wiping with a soft non-abrasive cloth. Be sure that the cloth is clean and does not contain any dirt or abrasive particles that can scratch the disc or what i've heard's been done is boil it for a minute or two then let it air dry on a lint free surface then gently wipe with a soft cloth. Boiling the disc removes contamenants.

Bass connection is at the sub pre-out jack on back of the system. The 9 speaker hook up could be Speaker A/B or in some cases (usually high-end models) the extra 2 channels are surround channels that extend the 7.1 channel experience, using steering logic technology, such as the way many Denon and Pioneer receivers do.Your receiver should only have 9 speaker outputs and 1 rca output for the subwoofer. 7 speakers outputs our for your 7.1 surround and the other 2 speaker output our for your Speaker B side. You will have a speaker A and a speaker B button on the front of the receiver. you will use the speaker A connection for your two front home theatre speakers and the speaker B output you would use if you where going to run another pair of speakers in another room. If not don't plug anything into the speaker B connections. YOur subwoofer will plug into your rca input that says subwwofer out on the back of your receiver.. . I hoped that will help you!!

The satelite and cable companys make more money this way. It's called bundling. Congress is trying to get satelite and cable to offer single channels. As for when this will no one knows.Well, actually, you can.  They're called PPV.  You can buy those channels, individually all day long.  And you'll pay through the nose.. . You've actually got it backward.  It's not that you CAN'T buy one channel.  What happens is that they're actually selling you packages of channels for the price of only one or two.  It's like buying in bulk.  Cable/satellite companies could offer you one channel, but they'd have to charge $30/month for it because of all the overhead with handling your account, manufacturing your equipment, distributing your equipment, etc.  They actually LOSE money by selling or giving equipment away, then make it up in selling subscriptions.. . If they offered you only one channel for, say $5/month, they'd have to sell you the equipment for $500+ to make up for the lost revenue.. . Trust me, the current setup is pretty much the cheapest offering they can devise.  Remember there's LOTS of competition.  If there was a cheaper way to offer you that one channel you wanted for a price that would beat the competitors, they'd do it.

You'll find an 'Aux' (Auxiliary) mode in the Bose Radio Remote. Activate that, and connect the audio output of tv to bose radio aux-input (you'll find it at the rear).. There, now you have the crystal clear output of bose working for your TV!when you follow the steps above, don't forget to check in the menu of the television what kind of outputs you have on the back.  if they are "variable", you would have to disable them (in the menu) and turn the volume of the television up to about 3/4 of the max.  if they are "fixed" outputs, then you would not need to worry about the volume of the tv.

BitTorrent is the name of a client application for the torrent peer-to-peer (P2P) file distribution protocol created by programmer Bram Cohen. BitTorrent is designed to widely distribute large amounts of data without incurring the corresponding consumption in server and bandwidth resources (and typically, monetary fees attracted as a result of that).. BitTorrent logo. . The original BitTorrent application is written in Python and its source code has been released under the BitTorrent Open Source License (a modified version of the Jabber Open Source License), as of version 4.0. The name "BitTorrent" refers to the distribution protocol, the original client application, and the .torrent file type.. . . Yes, you can download all that stuff with it.yes you can.. its a pretty interesting system.. you download a quick program.. and then go to different sites that offer torrent files. unlike kazaa or limewire you search the site to find people to download from. usually sites will separate the different categories for easy navigation.BitTorrent. A popular file sharing service developed by Bram Cohen that prevents people from downloading constantly unless they are willing to share in the overall transmission load on the network. Released in the summer of 2001, BitTorrent is similar to KaZaA and other distributed swapping services where users download from other users and do not use a centralized directory as in the original Napster service. However, BitTorrent is also different than all of them because it makes every downloading user an uploading user.. . . Large Files Become Torrents. . Instead of downloading an entire file, BitTorrent breaks a file into chunks and distributes them among several participating users. When you download a "torrent," you are also uploading it to another user. BitTorrent balances the load because broadband download and upload speeds are not the same. Users download files faster than they can upload them, which makes them less interested in sharing bandwidth to upload to someone else. BitTorrent ensures every user participates in uploading.. . BitTorrent has become widely used for transferring huge program files as well as pirated movies. In 2004, one estimate placed BitTorrent files as a third of all Internet traffic. Although the specific amount for BitTorrent may vary, the combination of all file sharing applications in use account for a huge chunk of traffic. For more information, visit www.bittorrent.com. See peer-to-peer network, Napster and KaZaA.BitTorrent is a peer-to-peer (P2P) file distribution tool written by programmer Bram Cohen and debuted at CodeCon 2002. The reference implementation is written in Python and is released under the BitTorrent Open Source License (a modified version of the Jabber Open Source License), as of version 4.0. . . BitTorrent is a protocol designed for transferring files. It is peer-to-peer in nature, as users connect to each other directly to send and receive portions of the file. However, there is a central server (called a tracker) which coordinates the action of all such peers. The tracker only manages connections, it does not have any knowledge of the contents of the files being distributed, and therefore a large number of users can be supported with relatively limited tracker bandwidth. The key philosophy of BitTorrent is that users should upload (transmit outbound) at the same time they are downloading (receiving inbound.) In this manner, network bandwidth is utilized as efficiently as possible. BitTorrent is designed to work better as the number of people interested in a certain file increases, in contrast to other file transfer protocols.

It's an analog video link between two devices.  It is NOT, and I mean absolutely, NOT a digital signal.  This is a common myth.. . S-Video cables have small rounded ends with pins, similar to a PS/2 Mouse port.What is S-Video?. -------------------. S-Video is one of the high quality methods of transmitting a television signal . from a device such as a Camcorder, VCR, or a game machine (PSX/Saturn/SNES . etc).  It separates the color information (Chrominance) from the brightness . (Luminance), which prevents nasty things like color bleeding and dot crawl, . and helps increase clarity and sharpness.  You can greatly improve the image . quality of the PSX by simply converting to S-Video.It is an input which if your TV and your computer has, you can connect the computer to the TV through a special cable and use the TV as a monitor.
Bluetooth provides a way to connect and exchange information across devices (PDAs, phones, laptops, printers etc.) through a radio frequency.  . . Anything you transmit is secure, so no need to worry about someone else getting your data.  The only drawback of bluetooth is that it only works within a short radius, and tends to consume a good amount of your battery power (depending on what device(s) you use and how new/old they are.). . Take a look at the Wikipedia article below for additional details.It's a way for computers & other electronic deviced to "talk" to each other.. . Here's more...Who'd have thunk that!!! LOL! But there are also boosters to streghen the signal.something to do with cellphones

A condenser microphone is a very sensitive microphone with a good frequency response. It requires phantom power or an external power source. It is particularly valuable for doing vocal recordings, as well as acoustic guitar recordings.. . It is very well suited for home recordings IF you use a box to hook it up - a computer will not provide it with phantom power through the mic jack.In a capacitor microphone, also known as a condenser microphone, the diaphragm acts as one plate of a capacitor, and the vibrations produce changes in the distance between the plates. Since the plates are biased with a fixed charge (Q), the voltage maintained across the capacitor plates changes with the vibrations in the air, according to the capacitance equation:. .     Q = C &#92;cdot V. . where Q = charge in coulombs, C = capacitance in farads and V = potential difference in volts. The capacitance of the plates is inversely proportional to the distance between them for a parallel-plate capacitor. (See capacitance for details.):. .     C &#92;propto &#92;frac{A}{d}. . Capacitor microphones can be expensive and require a power supply, commonly provided from mic inputs as phantom power, but give a high-quality sound signal and are now the preferred choice in laboratory and studio recording applications.. [edit]. . Electret condenser microphones. . A foil electret microphone is a relatively new type of condenser microphone invented at Bell laboratories in 1962 by Gerhard Sessler and Jim West [1], and often simply called an electret microphone. An electret is a dielectric material that has been permanently electrically charged or polarised. Electret microphones have existed since the 1920s but were considered impractical, but they have now become the most common type of all, used in many applications from high-quality recording and lavalier use to built-in microphones in small sound recording devices. Though electret mics were once considered low-cost and low quality, the best ones can now rival capacitor mics in every respect apart from low noise and even have the long-term stability and ultra-flat response needed for a measuring microphone. Unlike other condenser microphones they require no polarising voltage, but normally contain an integrated preamplifier which does require power (often incorrectly called polarizing power or bias). The integral preamp usually forms part of the mic capsule in modern designs, sensing the electric field from the diaphragm stretched across in front of it directly, and this sets the limit of noise performance, which though it can be as low as 26 dBA SPL (38 dB SPL 468-wtd) cannot currently rival the best capacitor mics. Electrets are frequently phantom powered in sound reinforcement applications.

Buy an audio interface.  Goto http://www.samash.com and call them 1-800-4-samash then ask them on the phone for pro audio.  Then be willing to buy a 200-1000 dollar interface.  You ask them for a 96kHz audio interface.  This speed should run about 400 dollars.  The faster the speed the better.  It can go upto 196kHz.  By the way you may also want to listen to audio on DVD's insted of audio CD's.   When an audio DVD comes from the manufactuer it is played at 96kHz.  A CD is only recorded at 44.1kHz.  MP3 Files and AAC files (iTunes files) are 44.1kHz also.  So don't expect good quality unless the file was recorded at a high sample rate.You could try purchasing some high quality samples such as the East West Quantum Leap Symphonic Orchestra packs. They are quite expensive, but if used properly they can sound quite convincing.

It is a direct magnification. 2X would mean 2 times the magnification, 3X would be three times.. . A way to visualize it would be to take a picture, and think of drawing a horizontal line and a vertical line to divide it into 4 equal pieces. Take one of those four pieces and blow it up to the size of the original picture, and that would be the effect of 2X zoom.usually it means how much the image is "magnified" or enlarged, based on the number that follows the Xx=to the power of one

Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition. The term refers to a large-scale, distributed measurement (and control) system.. . cctv is closed circuit television, pretty much what a security camera is. A camera sends the signal directly to a viewing monitor, it's not broadcast for general use.SCADA is the acronym for Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition.. . CCTV is the acronym for Closed Caption Television.

Red-eye occurs when light coming into the eye reflects off the retina, the back surface inside the eyeball.  The rods and cones which give us vision are there with a large supply of blood vessels.  The color of the blood gives the reflected light its red color.  The eye of a cat is particularily good at causing red-eye since their pupils are usually wide open in room light.The light in the flash reflects off something in your cornea in a wierd way. I hate red-eye too.I'll skip the science, so--. . We get red eye when you look straight at the flash of a camera. Red eye reduction technology works by flashing several weak intermittent lights before the real flash for the eyes to adjust.um..sometimes it depends on the camra or whatever you said.the light of the flash reflects off the back of your eyeball well behind your cornea, if you notice this usually only happens when the person is looking staight towards the camera.

RegardsWith the microphone closed on the headset, press and hold the silver multi-function key.  Hold this key until the light on the headset stays on.  With the light on the headset on, open the microphone, and set the headset aside.  Next take your phone.  Go to:  Menu, Settings, Connection, Bluetooth.  If Bluetooth is turned off on the phone, turn it on.  Selcet devices, and look for devices.  Your phone will find the headset, and ask if you want to bond with it.  Select yes.  The phone will then ask for a passkey.  The passkey for the headset is 0000 (all zeros).  The headset and phone will link up, and you can start using the headset normally.  Good Luck.

Fifty-seven varieties doesn't mean 57 varieties of ketchup, you dope, it means 57 varieties of food products in general. There are only three varieties of Heinz ketchup, regular, hot, and low-sodium, but there are far more than 57 varieties of Heinz pickles, Heinz sauces, Heinz soups, and Heinz God-knows-what-else. In fact, if you count everything Heinz and all its divisions and subsidiaries make, there are something like 1,300 varieties, including 108 varieties of baby food, 60 kinds of pickles, and so on.theu have 57 varietiesNo, they don't make 57 varieties of ketchup!  Way back when I was a kid and the Heinz corporation was a lot younger, too, they made 57 varieties of condiments.  I suspect the phrase is retained on the ketchup bottle out of nostalgia.Very interesting question.  No there are not 57 kinds of ketchup... many years ago Heinz had a variety of products... 57.  and used that saying as a catchy advertising ploy. It really did catch on.  Since then the saying "Heinz 57 Varieties" has taken on new meanings  like a dog that has many blood lines... he is said to be "Heinz 57 Variety" or something that has a varied combination of things making up its whole... This is why they keep that now vary valuable piece of advertising as part of their logo.We all know how Al Gore lies about the NUMBERS he THINKS he has...Heinz wanted to show that their company had a vast array of products, so they chose the slogan "57 varieties."

The program will do all the work. . . There are a great number of programs that will do the trick. Most of these programs will also burn DVDs as well. What you need to look for is one that will burn VCDs from video files. Since VCDs dont have menus like DVDs, it should be a "drag and drop" operation.. . Nero & Roxio make excellent software. Pinnacle (Studio 10), Adobe (Premiere Elements 2.0) and Ulead make editing software that will burn VCDs and DVDs. . . The software you get will decide how you create VCDs.. . night recording in camcorders means that the camcoder is put in a mode where it is more sensitive to low-light conditions and is capable of higher resolution at the expense of colors. Night recording is most often done with an Infrared lamp shining.In addition to what was said above, if your camera is equipped with IR lights, then night mode would actually translate to infrared mode, because you are viewing the infrared spectrum (which has no colors except for green). This technology is a toned-down version of the high-powered IR beams used in the military. If your camera does not have IR lights then all it does is amplify the brighter areas of your focus, sacrificing depth and color clarity to make objects more visible.
A VGA camera will shoot in a resolution of around 640x480, not quite suitable for printing.  A megapixel camera's image will be larger and of more detail, possibly producing a decent 4x6 image.My VGA cameraphone takes shots that are around 300K pixels, which is 640x480.  A megapixel camera takes many many more dots, which makes for a clearer picture, at least in theory. when recording music stereo sound is acheived by the placement of two (maybe more) microphones in the stupid. . in the olden days, one (mono) microphone was used. obviously stereo has much more depth in the sound, and you can heard more subtlies in the music as well. in playback it's the same principle, but instead it is reproducing the sound.Mono produces the same sound from both speakers (assuming you have two.) Stereo gives you a sound track for both speakers. For example if you were listening to a ping pong game on stereo you would hear the ball hit on the left speaker then the right while on mono both speakers would respond to each hit of the ball.the term mono comes from "monodic" which means one line of sound.. Mono usually uses the same "stream" to give out all the different layers of sound.. (you have all layers of sound coming from the same place). Stereo breaks up the sound into different groups of these layers and uses a different "stream" for each group.. (you could have the lows comming from one side and the highs from the other side)mono sound is a sound of one unique source mixed together to come out of (normally) just one speaker. If you have 2 speakers the it's the same sound that comes out of every one.. . Stereo is a sound that is recorded on 2 channels, a left one and a right one. that means when you hear that sound on a 2 speaker device, you will hear on the left speaker the left channel and on the right speaker the right channel.. You can try this by just come near of one of the speaker and you will realise that the sound is not always the same as the other one.. it may happen that they often talk about stereo music, but in fact nothing is divided so it sounds almost like Mono.. take care ;)

Why would you hook a pre-amp to a receiver?  You hook a pre-amp to a power amp...A reciver is made up of an amp (power), a pre-amp (controls& inputs/outputs), and usually an AM/FM tuner.. You wouldn't hook up a pre-amp to a reciever, because:. a) the reciever already has one. b) it's redundantit should hook up inline with the rca lines if i remember correctly....all it realy does is amp the signal...the more voltage the rca line carries the louder it will be..
Most cameras/recorders have one CCD, which is a chip that senses and combines all three colors (red, green, blue) into one image.  A 3 CCD camera has a separate chip for each of the three colors.  This allows higher processing and better resoluton of images.. . Btw, CCD=Charged Coupled Device.3ccd has got 3 of it loool :D

transistor working in saturation and cut-off region acts as a switch.in saturation emitter and collector are almost short ckt. and in cut-off they are open ckt. so by applying input to emitter,output to collector and proper control voltage to base of transistor,it acts as a switch.A transistor is controlled by voltage coming into base. It can be used as a switch in the sense that when it has enough voltage applied to the base it turns on and when it doesn't it is off and stops current flow.

It would be too dangerous, obviously they store a fair deal of electricity in electric plants, but those plants are already huge and highly secure. More electricity would pose extra risks and more space, often unavailable.To add to the previous post, capacitors can also store electricity, although batteries are the best source for storage, while capacitors are well suited for, among other things, providing a quick increase in power when the load suddenly increases.  . . You can store enough power to run a large building by using large banks of batteries for ~20 minutes.  Usually that is meant as a temporary measure until generators are brought online.  The trouble is that you need so many batteries that maintenance and safety become serious problems.. . In summary, the technology we have is limited.  Even the newer Lithium-Ion batteries, while they can store quite a bit of power for their size, are prohibitively expensive on a large scale.So far all we can store electricity in is batteries. The chemicals make them bulky and sometimes dangerous.It can.  However it is not cost effective or needed.. . Theoretically you could build a battery or capacitor the size of the empire state building but what for.. . Now if you’re thinking of “capturing” lightning bolts and storing them in a big battery the problem of too much at once comes into play.  The current conductors we have can’t handle that much voltage they melt or burn.Try to think of a battery. As you should know a battery is one of the simplist electricity storage facilities. An average battery stores like 1.5 voltes. It's size is similar to a size of a human fingure. Ok.. the larger the electrical amount in a battery the bigger it gets, which is very rational. Then imagine if you want to store 1000000 voltes, which is conciderd huge, in a battery. You can imagine the size of this battery.. And as you can see it is very not-practical and unsafe to do this.. The Nano is far more popular then the mini, and almost anyone who likes the mini would prefer the Nano.  The thing is that when the Nano came out, the after market price of the mini fell greatly, thus increasing its popularity.  People who always wanted a mini now could afford one, even if they like the Nano more.They were popular becasue they had quite the reputation for being "indestructible" and they did have some nice colours... haha, but apple discontinued them to "move on" and bring the nano into full production. Also I think eliminating the mini as an option for people that wanted smaller apple Mp3 players forced them to get the nano's."Did Jobs Kill the iPod mini Too Soon?. . Maybe not. His decision to jettison the hot-seller in favor of the nano equals just the kind of tough love that has kept Apple so hot. . A harsh law of the high-tech jungle says only those companies willing to kill off their most successful products to make room for even better ones can hope to remain on top. Few chief executives actually follow that tenet, however. One of the exceptions is Apple Computer's"
the mp3 player plays .mp3 files and it has a hard drive or flash drive and.  . the cd player plays .wav files and it does not have a hard drive or a flash driveon a CD player u can listen to music . on a MP3 player u can download musicthe cd player you have to have cds for and a mp3 player you can download all of your favorite songs on it. That way you dont have to carry around a million cds!mp3 PLAYERS HOLD more songs and you don't need to change CD'sA CD player uses CDs with 700 MB of storage on each one. Meaning for every 700 MB of music you have, you have to get a new CD. . . A MP3 player uses a hard drive (like in your laptop) or flash memory to store data. Sizes range from 128 MB to 20+ GB. Most of the time MP3 players are smaller than CD players. Most MP3 players have screens to see basic info on the songs you have on the decive. Some MP3 have extra features like color screens, FM tuner/recorder, video playback, and built-in mic. However once you are out of space, you cannot get more. You must delete data to get other data on the device.

I bought some special lense cleaning tissue from my local camera store. But if you want it done really really well you can take your camera in and they'll clean it all up for you! ;)If the lens isn't extremely dirty, I use a lens cleaning pen.  It has a retractable brush on one end, and a small felt-like pad with special dry cleaning compound on the other end.  After cleaning the lens with the cleaning pad, replace the cap and give it a half twist, that replenishes the cleaning compound and is ready to use again.   The cleaning pen lasts a very long time, is compact (easy to take with you), and only costs around $10.  I bought mine at www.bhphotovideo.com, however, they are widely available at just about any store which carries basic camera supplies.We all know the camera lense is very delicate, and the best way to clean it, must first be solved, by what to clean it with. . .  Okay, so! .... ((googling it, is not the best idea, since internet sources are full of junk)). . . To clean your camera and any separate lenses you own- keep it simple. I've heard too many stories about people damaging their cameras by doing too aggressive a cleaning job. For most purposes, I suggest you use just three tools to clean your camera-. . a microfiber cloth, . . a sable artist's brush, . . and a rubber squeeze bulb. . . Most of your cleaning should be on the camera's exterior. . . .  use a microfiber cloth to give a general cleaning to the camera body and the front of the outer lens element. In a pinch, if there's no microfiber cloth handy, I suggest using a well-worn cotton t-shirt or handkerchief to clean a camera or lens. Why suggest a worn t-shirt or handkerchief? . . Because, the more worn the cotton fabric is, the more likely it is to be soft and lint-free. If you have a really stubborn fingerprint to remove, you can breath very gently on the lens to let a little moisture from your breath condense on the lens, and then wipe it with the cloth. . . sable artists brush---...why this?. . Just to wipe off any dust on the lenses, make sure not to touch the metal on the shutter, if it's a modern exposure camera.. . Rubber squeeze bulb--  well, just basically to blow away any access dust and dirt, without actually breathing on the camera.. . . Need more info?There's also special lens cleaning tissue (e.g. Thorlabs).Never use paper, a soft cotton cloth is always best.use cotton and achoclGo from the least amount of touching and rubbing to most as needed.  As much as possible, you want to avoid touching the lens. Use air canister, camel brush or special cleaning tissue.  Also a small amount of haze or dust usually does not even affect the picture quality, so avoid the urge to clean.  Put a UV filter on the lens as the shield so you don't have to clean he lens itself. Some purists, however, may advise against filters arguing that you degrade lens quality on an expensive lens by using a cheap filter.
Speakers produce a back-EMF that counters the incoming signal.  Unless the amplifier has low output impedance, the sound will be "muddy".  The muddiness is related to amp impedance divided by speaker output impedance.. . Achieving really low amp impedance is called "damping".is often noticed with a jarring sound due to impedence mismatch.

A brown out is when wattage is reduced, causing lights to be not as bright. A black out is when all electricity is cut off, resulting in no power.brown out : example when your fuse burns out. Black out?: complete power outage or failure. it could be a whole community or city.

it's normal, although many LCD TVs offer a way to expand the image to fill the entire screen. Often this ends up cutting off the edges of the picture. Check your manual, on my Sony there is a button on the remote called "wide" that provides this zoom function.Some DVDs will have options in them to either play in widescreen or regular mode.. . Your TV may have have this feature in the setup mode.Does your dvd have a zoom option?. . thats one way the other is to go into the option menu of the dvd player select correct option.The problem is that while your lcd is a 16:9 ratio, the movie is displayed in its native format.  This is rarely 16:9.  It is still considered widescreen because its something like 1:2.31 (varies movie to movie).  Most lcd's have a zoom feature to get rid of the bars.  Also, some dvd players have this feature as well.  The only other thing you could do would be to get full screen movies, but they will look distorted.your lcd may be on the 4:3 setting you want 16:9 this should be in your display seetings menuCheck your TV and DVD display settings, it should be in there

a relay is basically a sort of switch which you can on or off using a considerably small vol.the strip containing the phase(signal to be swithed) is touching some point and directly below that point there is another point(connector).so when an ON pulse is given a coil joined to strip gets magnetized and strip touches the connector point.this way using a small vol. pulse you can control any large vol. signal.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relay. . probably the heads are clogged or very filthy at least, and maybe a drive belt slipping. take it to a repair shop. there is not much most people can do inside oneI'd weigh this one carefully. It really depends on the VCR and the caliber of the equipment... or if you have a real need for one. . . Unless you have to have that particular VCR working, and it has some sentimental value to it, I would consider just purchasing a new one. The repair costs alone someone would charge you would be equal to or exceed the cost of buying a new one. . . Keep that in mind before you go out and spend the money to repair it. Try shopping around for a new VCR online and get some prices first. You can try a shopping comparison site. (I always have had good luck www.shopzilla.com.)Get a Bottle of Denatured Alcohol,and a Coffee Maker Filter Paper. Tear It in Half.Crumple up Filter 'til it looks like an Old Dollar Bill.Take the Cover off Your VCR.[unplug it!]That Big Shiny Wheel with the Grooves=Video Head.Put Your Left Hand on top of it & turn it, to see how it works. Next,wet the 1/2 Filter w/ Alcohol,& press it to the Video Head while turning it.Don't move your Hand up or down,keep it steady.Turn it a few times.Lift Paper, look at that Black Gunk.That's why Your Picture is distorted.Move the Paper to a clean spot, and do it again.keep on until You see no more Black Gunk coming off, onto the Paper.Okay, next, see that Black Round Rubber Thing to the Right? That's the Pinch Roller.Press onto the Top of it with a Small Jewler's Screwdriver and Rotate it, and press onto it with a Clean Spot on Wet Filter Paper. Keep on 'till You don't see any more Crud coming off. It'll take awhile.All that Crud is why Your Picture is so distorted.Let everything get good & dry.Then,Pop in a Tape,with the Cover off, and with it hooked up to a TV .Don't let any bright light shine onto the VCR with the Cover off, or it will shut down. Ever watch a Tape play with the Cover off?Try It!.Picture OK now? If not, put in a Video that is expendable, and gently press against the Tape as it's playing on the Head.Don't move Your Hand up or down.The picture should clear up as the Tape takes the embedded Crud off the Head. This is a last resort of desperation, if You're going to Junk it anyway.You said the Sound is ok, and You just have Lines in the Picture, right? so, the Belt is probably ok.Changing It is a bit more involved, but I bet You could do that too!I'm glad to see more Women getting into the Electronics repair Business!Please let Me know if this worked OK for You.Video Head Cleaner Tapes are a Waste of Time & Money.Want to get into Electronics? Start by Subscribing to www.nutsvolts.com Hope this helped! Please let Me know! gvaporcarb@yahoo.com
Well, let me explain this in a simpler way. . . VGA camera has 0.3 mega pixel quality while a Mega pixel camera has 1 mega pixel quality. . So that means a mega pixel camera gives you a better resolution(clearer image) than VGA camera.a vga is 640x480 and less than a mega pixel.  vga is something like 800000 pixels where a mega pixel is one million and a 2 megapixel is 2 million pixels.

High speed storage cards/sticks save photos much faster than the regular cards/sticks.  This helps when you are taking a lot of shots very quickly, which is mostly something that a pro will run into.  I recommend the high speed cards because they store the picture faster -- when you go to turn the camera off if you turn it off too quickly the card will get corrupted.  This has happened to me several times and I've lost hundreds of shots due to my impatience -- which is why I've switched to the faster/more expensive cards.the main difference is like it seems in speed.... the high speed memory stick will save ur docs or pics in a very high speed in comparison with the regular memory stick..The memory stick is used for a camera or mp3 player or devices like that so u need ur memory stick to be a high speed one..

They work pretty much just like an LED, except the light emitted is in the infrared range. The important material is the two pieces of doped silicon that are combined to create a diode (that happens to emit infrared light)One way is a diode.  2 layers of oppositely doped gallium compound.  See:. . http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/electronic/led.html. . Another way is to use a common headlight and select a current just short of the filament going incandescant.
HTiB stands for "Home Theater in a Box."  G. . enerally it is everything you need to get up and running.  Usually includes speakers, a DVD player, and a receiver of some sort.  Some might include other things but most of them include the items listed above.. . SRA "home theater in a box" (HTIB) is a common name for a relatively inexpensive integrated home entertainment package, usually including a DVD player, surround sound capability, and a radio tuner in one box. While they lack the features of a custom-assembled home theater system, HTIBs are an inexpensive (and generally space-efficient) way to take advantage of the surround sound capabilities of the DVD format. They are manufactured by most makers of consumer electronics; Bose in particular markets their integrated home theater systems especially aggressively, though other traditional manufacturers such as Sony, Philips, and Panasonic market systems that tend to be considerably cheaper.

The difference is the recording medium.. . In both film and digital cameras -- the camera is a light-proof box that has an opening that controls the light that hits the recording mechanism.  In film cameras the silver nitrate in the film changes when light hits it which creates an image on the film that is the opposite of what it sees (a negative).  The digital camera uses either a CCD or CMOS sensor to record the image on some storage medium (either a memory card or in in-camera memory.A digital camera doesn't have FILM.A conventional camera takes photos. A Digital Camera takes videos and photo stills.The digital camera is one of the most remarkable instances of this shift because it is so truly different from its predecessor. Conventional cameras depend entirely on chemical and mechanical processes -- you don't even need electricity to operate them. On the other hand, all digital cameras have a built-in computer, and all of them record images electronically.A conventional camera uses chemistry to capture an image on film.  That film then needs to be chemically developed, and then, if it's negative film, usually paper prints are made.  In positive film, the image is just how you see it (slide film).. . In a digital camera, the process is entirely electronic and not chemical.  There's nothing to "develop."

if the upc has enough bus pins to access 1Mb connect all address lines of the chips together, all data pins together. then connect them to the upc and use a 4x1 demux or decoder, outputs to the chip enable line of each memory module. two address lines of decoder to the 2 msb addreess lines of upc.On what? an Atari ST?

Bluetooth is an industrial specification for wireless personal area networks (PANs). Bluetooth provides a way to connect and exchange information between devices like personal digital assistants (PDAs), mobile phones, laptops, PCs, printers and digital cameras via a secure, low-cost, globally available short range radio frequency.. . The name Bluetooth was born from the 10th century king of Denmark, King Harold Bluetooth who engaged in diplomacy which led warring parties to negotiate with each other. The inventors of the Bluetooth technology thought this a fitting name for their technology which allowed different devices to talk to each otherhttp://www.bluetooth.com/bluetooth/

A lot of electronics don't work very well when they are extremely cold. You should warm them up first.When gear is brought from cold into warm, condensation will build up on the circuit board inside causing the whole thing to short out and not work.  Always let your gear warm up for a while (I let it stand for 1/2 hour) before firing it up.They can have alot of affects. Some things could freeze and then the electronic might not work anymore. Be carefulReally, cold weather in itself will not affect electronics..unless it is severe cold (-40F or below).  Humidity on the other hand is probably the culprit.  You may want to invest in a voltmeter to check your leads.  Also, in transportation, you may have joggled something loose.

Typically, there are multiple sets of A/V connectors on a satellite receiver.  Just use any available set of red/white/yellow output jacks to the similiar input jacks on your VCR.. . If there is only one set of outputs on the sat receiver, you could route the satellite output to the VCR and then the VCR output to the TV.  It would just mean the VCR would have to be on to watch the satellite.put a scart socket from receiver to video then make sure video station is on AV1 or AV2 or AUX and you will then be able to record of your receiver.scart sockets are only about £5 or $9 or so. remember you cant tape 1 satellite station and watch another. good luck.

This is also because the cell phone doesn't have a dedicated circuit and must first ask the central office if it can make a call which it does by you pressing send.  Hope this helps.
They are the same thing.  Secure Digital (SD) is trademarked so any card with the SD logo will work with SD devices.  The link below takes you to the association.Same thing.  Technically, "flash" media stores data on a printed circuit board (as opposed to disk media), but if the card has an SD logo on it, it should work in SD devices.  The term "Flash" has no laws behind it's use, so it's probably just a marketing term slapped on the package to make you think it's better/faster/less likely to not work/etc.

If you are near a window, the signals can usually make it indoors within sight of the window.. . The ohms rating is how much impedence the speaker has. It is very important to use the ohm speaker specified by the manufacturer or you can burn up the speakers and/or equipment. For example if you have a receiver rated at 100 watts with 8 ohm speakers, and put 4 ohm speakers (which is half the rated load) it will consume 200 watts of power.that is the speaker "resistance", differrent from "impedance", etc... to make a long story short:. . if you don't know what that is, don't play with 'em speakers, you can burn the speakers and/or the audio line.. . my best advice - ask for qualified helpthe higher the number the the higher the resistance.
Freon gas dramatically cools when expanded.  So, freon is compressed, and a fan cools the gas.  The compressed freon escapes compression through a tiny hole, into expansion tubing, where it becomes supercool relative to the atmosphere.  This cooled freon cools your refrigerator..Here is a good reading material for you http://home.howstuffworks.com/refrigerator2.htm.

Are you sure it is ac "voltage" sensor? I think you may mean "ground fault" sensor. Most newer ac wall sockets (for example) now come with a ground fault sensor built in. This is to protect against possible shock hazard if the ground should fail. And that is "earth ground" as referenced to the high side and the common side (or neutral), which is not grounded. That's why the socket has three contacts.It would depend on the application.  Do you have any further information that you can elaborate further?It depends on the system it is being used in and for.  A standby generator would use it to sense a loss of AC power and then startup to supply power and also to sense a return of normal power and shut down.

The bare speaker wire goes through the hole in the side, then the screw is tightened to bind the wire.  Do this with both speaker leads.  Banana plug are useless unless your binding posts/wire clips accept them.mrnozitall is correct! I love this type of banana plug. It gives you a solid push in and if you need to remove it a nice way to pull on it to remove it without damage to the wires. Do be sure to trim any excess wire that might stick thru the hole, no need to cause harm to fingers or the amp.

Setup your webcam and mic on your computer in the baby's room, login to your IM (Yahoo, MSN, whatever), enable video chat. That's it. Now, wherever you are with your handheld device, login to the IM with your other account. varies how mig the songs are. Put them on your computer and check out the size.About 2000 minutes worth of music using the normal 128kbps encoding.  I tend to encode mine at the higher-quality 192kbps, so I'd be getting about 1300 minutes worth of music.. . How many songs that is depends on how long your songs are.  If you're listening to Orbital's 28-minute version of "The Box," well, you'll get rather fewer of them in that 2gb than you will Blur's "Song 2".Well, Mp3s vary in size due to sampling rates and song lengths.  An average length CD quality song is in the neighbourhood of 3 megs.  Using that, you can expect to fit about 650-680 songs on the card, give or take a few songs for file system differences and directories.500

1. Locate the wall studs that you WILL secure the bracket to. 2. Locate & drill the holes for the wiring.. 3. Run the wiring.. 4. Attach the TV last.. . Smartest idea is to get one of the brackets that swings away from the wall so you can access the back and anlge the Tv as needed for viewing.depends on the type of tv and the type of wall bracket. There are many different types of brackets that all fit differently.Reading the instructions might help... or go the manuf. website?whatever you do... make SURE you attach the bracket to the stud in the wall, it would be very pricy if you dontOk, I hang these things for a living. The first thing I will say is if your not confident you know what your doing, find someone who is. People go to school to learn rigging because it can be dangerous. You don't want someone getting hurt because your TV fell on them.. . The first rule in rigging is the 5 to 1 rule. This means that if your TV weighs 100 pounds, you shoould be able to hang 500 pounds on the bracket without it coming down!. . If your hanging on wood studs, get yourself some heavy duty 3" lags. They will most likely come with the bracket. . . If your hanging on metal studs you need to mount a plywood board first and then hang the TV on the board. You need to use toggle bolts on the metal studs which can be tricky. you need to probe the wall to find out exactly where the edges of the studs are and then drill a large hole dead center. . . If your hanging on stone or brick get some heavy wedge anchors. If you've never used them before, buy a few extras and try them out on a test brick first before you go drilling holes in your wall. . . Remember you need the most support at the top of the bracket. If it falls, the top will pull out from the wall first. The top is where most of the stress will be. . . Once you hang your bracket, test it before hanging the TV. We like to get a couple guys to hang on it first, flailing their legs around. If it doesn't come down, it's safe to hang the TV. . . Just think safety.
If you mean "smart media" and "secure digital", essentially they are two different physical form factors.  Both formats are used in digital cameras, but they are not interchangeable.  They both use the same flash technology.  Hope that helps.Smart Card can record the information very much like a picture of bearer name and personal information and secure card is block the third person to use the card maybe secure card not have Chip for Smart Card but Smart Card technology is security itself.

So easy, resistance is the electron flow opposition in electronic circuit, impedance depend of the frequency of operation of a circuit. in continuous DC circuit you not see impedance, in a DC pulse circuit the story is different.. think in a lighthing storm, pulse of electric current, the discharge circuit, ground, is an impedance.Impedence is the imaginary form of resistance (from an EE standpoint)According to wikipedia.org:. "Electrical impedance or simply impedance is a measure of opposition to a sinusoidal electric current. The concept of electrical impedance generalizes Ohm's law to AC circuit analysis. Unlike electrical resistance, the impedance of an electric circuit can be a complex number. Oliver Heaviside coined the term impedance in July of 1886.". . and.... . "Electrical resistance is a measure of the degree to which an object opposes the passage of an electric current. The SI unit of electrical resistance is the ohm. Its reciprocal quantity is electrical conductance measured in siemens.. . "Resistance is the property of any object or substance of resisting or opposing the flow of an electrical current. The quantity of resistance in an electric circuit determines the amount of current flowing in the circuit for any given voltage applied to the circuit."

Tweeters are the small speakers in a multi speaker enclosure - they reproduce the higher pitched sounds in music (cymbals, high guitar notes etc), the sybilance in human speech (S's T's etc) or the glass breaking in sound effects -- just a few examples.... The tweeter's counterparts are the woofer - which produces the bass or low frequencies such as an earthquake or bomb blast and a tweeter also has another co-worker (in the better speaker systems) called a mid or midrange speaker which handles most of the normal stuff like vocals in a song or regular elements of speach. OH and there's the subsoofer - which is popular with home theater systems -- for the really low effects like thunder or bone shaking explosions...   Hope that answers any and all of your questions about tweeters :)Tweeters are the little speakers that people put in the cars.Tweeters are speakers or a part of a speaker system that produce the high pitched sounds you hear from songs, like the cymbals.................................................A tweeter is a loudspeaker that produces high frequencies. The range of frequencies is typically from around 2,000 hertz to 22,000 hertz (20,000 Hz is generally considered to be the upper limit of the human ear). Some tweeters can reach upto even 30-35kHz.tweeters are two things that are used to pick up noodles.

It depends on how many KB's your transferring at.  If you add them to your ipod from say, windows media player, check the quality rate.  They usually transfer at about 128kb.  You can lower the quality rate, which is barely noticeable, to 96kb and therefore take up less space and fit more songs onto your ipod.The number of songs you can store also depends on the encoding format and bitrate.  AAC (the format used by the iTunes music store) is more efficient than MP3, so to get the same sound quality in an MP3 you'd have to use a higher bitrate, which would take more space.That was so racist what the Hot 21 Year Old said.You are probably using the mp3 format wich will take up about twice as much memory as files using the acc formatThats easy... To put the difference simply:. . Both pass current but transistors are controllable and diodes aren't.A transistor will allow current flow through various paths, while a diode will allow it in one direction only depending how it is byassed.transistor consists of 3 terminals unlike diode . transistor is used for amplification . diode maybe p-n or n-p junctions . whers transister n-p-n or p-n-p . "change in resistance will bring change in voltage ". thus trans - resistor = transistordiode only lets current go one waythe diode is a pn  like a switch as the current flow in one way only when it opens but the transistor is a pnp or npn device which is for passing current between different regions so there is a decrease and increase in its values . and the transistor is work like 2 diodes in the same time fw,rs,....Instead of asking on here u could have just searched that on yahoo search
