southwest.........the same as a satellite dish...southwest has best reception towers.........Southwest is WRONG!  HD just depends on where your local stations have their towers at.  Depending on where those towers are, you might just have to do a little 'trial and error' to find the best position for the antenna.Hobbiehound gave you the correct answer. You need to point the antenna toward the transmit tower. Hopefully in your city the major stations all transmit from the same location, if not you may need a rotor to turn the antenna to the proper spot based on what channel you want to watch.. With digital signals you don't get snow or ghosts like you can on analog broadcasts, you either have enough signal to get a picture and if you drop below that level you probably will just loose the picture. While adjusting don't forget that height can have a big effect, raising or lowering the antenna just one foot can make a huge difference.

You'll get longer battery life by using high-capacity, long-life rechargeables or by turning the volume down.The problem is not your MP3 player but you're charging of the batteries,most  batteries that need charging have a built in memory for charging,if you charge the batteries before they're fully drained of power,they won't take the full charge next time around because the memory has been reset to that charge.this can go on and on untill the batteries will only hold only a portion of it's original charge.It is probably because of the brand of battery you are using. Current flow enters the emitter, is regulated by the signal at the base, and exits the collector.. . Think of it this way - the reason they call that thing a transistor is because it is a resistor whose resistance is transformed from the base signal current - transforming resistor = transistor.  By placing a transistor in series with a fixed resistor, you have created a voltage divider, whose output voltage is directly affected by the transistor's resistance, which is directly affected by the base current.  So base current determines output voltage of the circuit.hey...... i dont know the answer to your question but i have a question for you...... . . ok, your id is  *scott91191* right?. . . the levels of older cd's were generally lower so when you remaster the actual old pre-mastered mixes you can increase overall volume and sound quality. It's a modern way of touching up older music, or in the case of a CD like rush's Vapor Trails, removing some clipping/artifacts that were introduced in mastering. However, certain records would benefit from Remixing and remastering...where you adjust buried parts/resurrect old takes, etc...Many newly remastered CD's have added bonus tracks. Also the technology has improved on how much digital information can be put on the CD from the early days in the 1980's. Often times they will remix the sound (purest types don't like this, even if it makes it sound better). There are several new formats such as SACD which sound better, at least I think it does. And my favorite is DVD audio disks which can have a PCM stereo mix and DTS and/or Dolby surround mixes on them. Really like Billy Cobham "Spectrum" disk, I own it in LP, CD and now DVD-A format.generally that means the master tape was used and new technology was used to lay down the tracks on the CD.  It may have a better sound, but I suppose that is a judgment call.The quality has been improved through digital means, rather than buying a CD of original quality music.The producer is either trying to enhance an old analog recording that was originally released on vinyl, or they are taking another stab at older tunes (like a best-of album).  Most times, the remasters are better.because its mastered...and then mastered again

They're actually both great cameras, depending on the models you're comparing.  For the small digital cameras Nikon's generally provide more options while Canon's are easier to use.  They both have great optics and produce good quality photos.  The larger SLR-type digital cameras from both companies are very good, but Canon has more expansion capability in the EOS line.I use Canon.  Some of my friends use Canon.  Some use Nikon.  Having compared results over the years, I see less difference from the equipment than technique.  My personal opinion is that both companies make great cameras and lenses.  It really comes down to preference.  If there is a specific new feature you desire, it may be in one brand and not the other, but give it a couple of years, it would be in both.. . So, if you focus on the techniques and the joy of photography, and you're in it for the long haul, I really think it doesn't matter which.. . By the way, my very unscientific observation is this: I see many more studio and indoor photographers use Nikon.  I see more sports photographers use Canon.nikon. just because i trust and own one of them.i trust only CanonBoth are great. I have a Canon, and it's really easy to use, and takes great photos. Having said this, Nikon cameras (especially the better ones) are truly amazing & very professional. Maybe the Canons are a little easier to use. You won't go wrong either way. I also love Olympus cameras. Great optics.With my personal experience,Nikon is much more precise,the focus is so perfect and more durable.Canon is a fine brand too,but I guess it lacks that durability.I have both these brands, guess what;a 1983 Nikon gives me much precision than the 2005 Canon (even its digital!)canon has some nice photo software, but Nikon is better. They are just brands.djeff95 gives the best answer to this question in my opinion.  This could turn into an unecessary dispute that ends without a true answer....because there isn't one.    Both companies (as well as others) offer products that are more than capable at producing stellar images.  A photographer would make a choice based on what the individual product offers against what he/she requires.  To answer your question indirectly, both companies have known advantages over each other, but none of those advantages makes either one 'better'.  In the end it is the photographer that makes the image.

The fax machine reads the paper like a grid.  For each of the tiny tiny squares it breaks it down into, it gives a value positive or negative to represent black or white.. . Then it sends the info through the phone in order (I think probably top left to bottom right).  Phones can send different tones at different megaherz ranges, which tells the fax machine on the other end which squares to color in.  It then pieces it back together and prints it out.. . Fax machines are still black and white because phones don't have enough different tones to represent lots of colors.Simpliest way to answer this is;. . The scanner will scan the document being feed into the fax machine, the information are converted into digital formats or bits, then it is coded and sent out through telephone line by means of an internal modem, the receving end with an internal modem pick up the call, receive the data, decode the data back to human readable forms and print it either using thermal imaging, inkjet or toner.

I couldn't answer that better my self. - Apple EmployeeYou don't create the On The Go playlist in iTunes.  You create it on the iPod itself.  When you find the song or playlist or artist, etc., that you want in the On The Go playlist, hold the button and the filename or artist, etc., will flash.  Then when you want to listen to it, it should be at the bottom of your Playlists.

I-Pod is the brand name of the Apple MP3 player. . . All other digital music players are called MP3 players even if they play more than the MP3 file formati pod is xpensive n mp3 is cheaperThe iPod is a highly hyped MP3 player from Apple, and an insane marketing success. The difference between iPod and normal MP3 players is that the iPod is specifically designed for the iTMS in terms of buying songs, and can't be used with the new Napster, or other music stores. Do you want to put Windows Media Player on your task bar?. . If you want to do this, right click on your task bar.. Go to toolbars, then click on Windows Media Player.. .  Now, whenever you minimize Windows Media Player, a "mini" version of it will appear on your task bar.I'm guessing you mean the menu bar at the top which says "File", "View", "Play", "Tools", "Help".. . There are several ways to do this.. . In the upper right hand corner of Windows Media Player, there are four icons that look sort of like "v _ [] X".. Clicking on the down arrow (v) will access the menus.. There is even a menu item called "Show Menu Bar".. . Another way to do this is with the "Maximize" icon ([]) in the upper right hand corner of the window.  When the WMP window is maximized, it'll show the menu bar as well.. . Hope this helps.

intergrated=built in,ready for work. ready=buy another tuner for hdMany television sets are HD-ready, but not all of them have HD tuners built in. When you're looking at your new TV it's the tuner that's the key part. If your set has a tuner, then the HD is "built in." If it doesn't, then you'll have to get an external tuner or cable box that can provide you with an HD signal.If you have a cable or sat box then a tuner is not a huge part of buying the TV.  It would be more for the future.  If you are looking at big screens almost all the new models are having the tuners built-in.  If you do have the tuner integrated or built-in(same) then you can get your local stations over the air via a roof antenna which would make the programing  free.  You cannot however take advantage of all HD has to offer right now.  Don't forget to get a surround sound system if you get a big TV with hd because hd is all broadcast in digital sound.  What type of TV are you looking at. Micro-Display,LCD,plasma,traditional rear projection, or direct view?
i=interlaced. 420 is regular old tv. 720 is the minimum standard for hdtvi have no idea what you are talking about, but this question puts me on level three. thanks broresolution.  The greater the number, the more resolution you have.  You also want to go for progressive over interlaced since it technically gets the picture to the screen faster, but I doubt you'd really notice the rate unless you were at seriously high def.If you have a high-definition TV, setup all of your components to output 720p or 1080i (whichever your hdtv has).  If you don't have a high-def TV, don't ever try to use any resolution ending in p, or you won't be able to use that component at all, at least until you find someone with a high-def tv that will let you bring your component over, so it can be reset to use the interlaced output.
He's right, but, to take it a step further, look for the fiber optic port on your cable box, if it has one, and run a fiber optic cable from here to your receiver fiber optic input, if it has one.  . . You mentioned "surround", speakers well, this is the ONLY way you will get 5.1 "surround" sound.  Go to your receiver then and look for this input and route it through whatever input you are using to watch Cable TV.  You can route video this way too.  If your receiver has the inputs, and your Cable box has the outputs, you can use the Component video in/out, for a much much better picture.  . . If you don't have any of this.  Dear God. Well just a fyi this voids the warranty.... I dont have this phone so im going to guess.. . Take the battery out and check to see if theres any screws remove any/all. most small devices are press fitted, so you need to find whenre the two parts are fitted together and pry the two parts apart, becarefull because you can break the tabs that hold it together...It does void the warranty, so don't do it unless you have to. I've done it a few times and it's not too difficult. You'll need a Torx T-5 driver and a small phillips head srewdriver to get it open. When you slide the battery cover open, you'll see two small phillips screws, take those off and you can remove the back plate. You have to be careful because you have to pry the casing off and too much pressure will break it. Once that is off and the battery is removed, you'll see two torx screws by the SIM card holder. Remove those, and then you can pry off the front faceplate. One can actually completely disassemble and reassemble the entire phone in a few minutes, but I wouldn't suggest more than removing the faceplates unless you know what you're doing or are willing to risk destroying the phone.
vcast from verizon costs you a monthly fee if you purchase a phone that is Vcast capable.First you will need a VCAST capible handset. This will allow you to download music to you phone or to you computer. The cost of each song download to your phone is $1.99 and to your computer it's .99. If you download to your computer you can transfer the music to you phone via a usb cable which is included with the music essentials kit available for purchase with the phone. The format for music for the phone is in .wma. You can also transfer existing .mp3's on you computer to your phone and the VCAST software will convert these to the proper format for you. The VCAST feature if $15/month. This will include Mobile Web, unlimited data airtime with mobile web and vcast and unlimited video clip downloads. You should purchase a memory card for you phone, this will allow you to store somewhere around 5,000 sounds to your phone.VCAST – the nation’s first third-generation (3G) wireless multimedia service for consumers – beginning February 1, 2005. VCAST will bring high-quality video, 3-D games and music straight to new 3G phones that will run on the Verizon Wireless broadband EV-DO (Evolution-Data Optimized) 3G network, delivering the fastest, most widely-available fully-mobile wireless data experience in the nation today.. . RADIOFANVCast Music from Verizon Wireless is music that you can download to your phone and listen to it for as long as you want. You have to get a VCast capable phone such as a Moto Razr or a Samsung. You have to pay a monthly fee for it.

In electronics, the max range of the power supply.. . In single 5V system, like digital, its 5 volts.. In split rail, like +12/-12, its 24 volts.Please clarify the point.The general supply Voltage in Rail is Single phase 66Kv.I usually think of rail to rail, as another message stated, concerning a bi-polar power supply or source.. Are you perhaps inquiring about a electric railway, like with a overhead wire? Talking in the KV or kilovolt levels, makes me lean in a direction of a high voltage differential between 2 rails or wire to rail. 66 KV would be kinda high for electric railway. But there is also power distribution , normally 3 phase, that can be a 66 or 69 KV range, depending on where you live. . Clarify the origin of the question........

Very good answers, but you need to know one more thing:. . Thermal paper is very inappropriate for storing images for a long time, especially where the stored paper cannot be kept cool.  Over time the undeveloped areas darken.  . . Sometimes totally unused paper rolls have been sent to a hot place such as Pakistan, and after sitting in a hot warehouse there have been found to be so damaged by heat, turning the paper black, as to be ususeable.. . Facsimile (FAX) machines sometimes involve this kind of paper for printing out received messages and documents.  Useful, but you need to copy anything vital onto regular paper for retaining it a long time.. . Not good for places like Florida, Texas.Instead of having ink cartridges to apply the print.  The paper that is being printed is treated in a way that when it is heated and pressed to make a print it will come through the paper. Rather than ink applied.A thermal printer (or direct thermal printer) produces a printed image by selectively heating coated thermochromic paper when the paper passes over the thermal print head. The coating turns black in the areas where it is heated, producing an image. Two-color direct thermal printers are capable of printing both black and an additional color (often red), by applying heat at two different temperatures.. . Thermal transfer printing is a related method that uses a heat-sensitive ribbon instead of heat-sensitive paper.A thermal printer (or direct thermal printer) produces a printed image by selectively heating coated thermochromic paper when the paper passes over the thermal print head. The coating turns black in the areas where it is heated, producing an image. Two-color direct thermal printers are capable of printing both black and an additional color (often red), by applying heat at two different temperatures.Thermal printer. From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia. Jump to: navigation, search. For the type of printer which uses sparks and aluminised paper (and is sometimes referred to as a "thermal printer"), see spark printer. . A thermal printer (or direct thermal printer) produces a printed image by selectively heating coated thermochromic paper when the paper passes over the thermal print head. The coating turns black in the areas where it is heated, producing an image. Two-color direct thermal printers are capable of printing both black and an additional color (often red), by applying heat at two different temperatures.. . Thermal transfer printing is a related method that uses a heat-sensitive ribbon instead of heat-sensitive paper.

You want a two wire cable with RCA phono connectors on both ends about 6 feet long. One RCA connector is red and the other is white. These will connect to your stereos 'audio out' connections and then when you want sound you need to put the stereo on the right input; usually the VHS/VCR mode.Hook up the cables together

When you press the "record" button, the needle that is recording the info onto the magnetic tape is already on the tape when the rest of the mechanism completes its movement into recording position.  So, this last movement makes a click sound, which of course is recorded.. . If I can recommend something,  you can buy a cheap digital recorder from radio shack or circuit city which doesn't need tapes, and works much better without the click.  Good luck!Internal noise in the tapedeck.
cheap version: take a 9volt device, hook up the wires instead of the batter at the device, hook up the 9volt batter to the other end of the wires(make sure positive is still positive all the way via wire color and is on the right connector).  If the device works, both wires are good.NickName's answer is great! How cool is that?Use a multimeter.  Set the meter on Ohms(200 setting).  Looks like an upside down horse shoe.  Put a probe on both ends of your wire.  If the meter goes to around zero you have continuity.  . . If you don't have a meter and are wondering if you have a bad speaker wire.  Switch the wire over to a speaker that you know works.  If it still works your wire is fine.I have to tell u a yet simpler way.. Disconnect the wire from both ends, (speaker and the amplifier). Get a cell and lamp from your torch, connect . Short the ends of the wire that connect to the speaker.. Out of the 2 leads on the amplifier end, connect one to -ve (or +ve) terminal of battery. connect the other end to one of the terminals of lamp. place the remaining terminal of lamp on +ve (or -ve) tip of the cell.. Light should glow.Another way to test a speaker wire (really useful if the wires are buried in the wall and not labeled) is to use a C or D cell battery, match negative and positive on wire and battery and the speaker that it's connected to will produce a small, audible "pop" (not enough to damage the speaker, though).

cause vhs was an open licence, and beta was owned by sony who wanted money for people to use their format. even though beta had better quality.. . As mensioned above, its happening again with the whole dvd thing.wasn't it just sony making betamax? vhs was used wider. just like the whole HDDVD or BlueRay.VHS was cheaper and had better marketing.Hi danielinthefront,. . The VHS format's defeat of the Betamax format became a classic marketing case study, now identified with the verbal phrase "to Betamax", wherein a proprietary technology format is overwhelmed in the market by a format allowing multiple, competing, licensed manufacturers, as in: "Apple Betamaxed themselves out of the PC market." . . Sony's confidence in its ability to dictate the industry standard backfired when JVC made the tactical decision to engage in open sharing of its VHS technology. JVC sacrificed substantial potential earnings by going the open sharing route, but that decision ultimately won the standards war. By 1984, forty companies utilized the VHS format in comparison with Betamax's twelve. Sony finally conceded defeat in 1988 when it too began producing VHS recorders.. . Hope this helps

Email is the transmission of messages over communications networks. The messages can be notes entered from the keyboard or electronic files stored on disk. Most mainframes, minicomputers, and computer networks have an e-mail system. Some electronic-mail systems are confined to a single computer system or network, but others have gateways to other computer systems, enabling users to send electronic mail anywhere in the worldWhateverElectronic mail in general; but I can try to find sth new for 10 points :)electronic maile-mail is electronic mailIts electronic mail,above dat its a fastest way to contact ur dear ones.Man in which world u r? Megapixels are calculated as follows:. . # pixels wide x # pixels high = total pixels.. . megapixels = total pixels / 1,048,576Usually by multiplying the height and width and then dividing by a number with a large quantity of 0s after it (I think it's 10000, but am not currently motivated to confirm this).  Check out www.dpreview.com and compare the image height and width statistics with the advertised megapixels to get your answer.Not sure, but I know that the more pixels, the smaller the image.
These are just levels...if the numbers are 1 to 10 then they could be considered as percentages of the stereos capacity where 1 = 10%,2 =20% etc. They dont have anything to do with the decibles(sound measurement units).just to help you keep track of how loud it is.

Possibly the light switch is creating an arc when it makes and breaks and if it is on the same circuit as your subwoofer that could be the problem. Does this happen when you turn on a light in any other room?ummmmm, actually, the first guy is right.  The spark is coming from a cheap switch which arcs when voltage is applied.  You can replace the switch, and/or try a new branch circuit in your home, read, try a different outlet, or, get yourself a good surge protector and plug the subwoofer into this.  This should filter out the spike voltage.. . Or, unplug the offending subwoofer fast and throw it out the window before the demons come out of it and eat your family!  LOL!  I watch way to much TV.Because turning the switch on or off causes a disruption in the magnetic field. The driver (big magnet) in your subwoofer reacts to it.The light switch is causing AC line noise that carries through to your audio system, as they are likely on the same circuit.  A surge protector that features line conditioning would likely solve your noise issue.  Ultralink and Monster Cable make these products.

Alternatively you can write them down in a little notebook, but that can be rather slow and not appropriate in some situations such as sporting events. (LOL)In the west, during the Industrial Revolution, use of child labor was commonplace, often in factories, but on the decline. In England and Scotland in 1788, about two-thirds of persons working in the new water-powered textile factories were children. Subsequently a series of Factory Acts were passed to gradually restrict the hours that children were allowed to work, and to improve safety. It is widely argued that the industrial revolution increased hardship for children. Historian E. P. Thompson notes in The Making of the English Working Class that child labor was not new, and had been "an intrinsic part of the agricultural and industrial economy economy before 1780", however he argues that. . "there was a drastic increase in the intensity of exploitation of child labour between 1780 and 1840, and every historian acquainted with the sources knows this is so. This was true in the mines, both in inefficient small-scale pits where the roadways were sometimes so narrow that children could not easily pass through them; where - as the coal face drew furher away from the shaft - children were in demand as 'hurreyers' and to operate the ventilation ports. In the mills, the child and juvenile labour force grew yearly; and in several of the out-worker or 'dishonorable' trades the hours of labor became longer and work more intense.". . Anyone who thinks that industry would not go right back to where it was before legislation to stop the exploitation of children needs only to look to American companies like Wal-Mart operating in unregulated countries like China to see how even the so-called "family" businesses are driven by greed and the explointation of children is just another step toward their goal of meeting the bottom line.Here's one: so that parents can't force their children to support them.Look to the Industrial Revolution for your answer. Parents were shipping their kids off to do manual labor all day and as a result they were dying left and right.I personally see no reason why they should ultimately continue, but if you need a good reason for them to exist I suppose that I would say it saves hundreds of Children from cruel people who want children to work in the hard labor departments.for the same reason the laws to stop sexual preditor should be inforced: kids want to experiment with life and are easily taken advantage of(sometimes with their blessings). all it takes is one rotten employer to ruin a child's expectations.

Global System for Mobile communication. A European digital standard for mobile or cellular telephonyglobal system for mobile communicationsGlobal System for Mobile Communications.. Used in across all over Europe/India/China/Koreas/Japan. and lately even here in the US
Well, they are small memory chips or cards, produced by Sony, that you could use in several devices, such as digital cameras, PDAs, etc. There are several memory chips standards in the market and you could say that Memory Sticks are one of the most importants. To use the MS in your device, you must be sure that it is compatible with MS cards.Memory sticks (or most all ram [random access memory] for that matter ) are like a bunch of very small bar magnets in a scrambled pile. When you "write" to them, they line up in rows with the poles pointing in one of two directions. Say, for a logic high or a (1) they point to the right and for a low or a (0) they point to the left. This then would "look" like a row of (using N for pointing right and S for left) magnet poles in a pattern, such as: NNSNSNN which would decode to 1101011 as a logic word, command, or what ever the stored data was.You use them on your subordinates heads until they remember who is boss!

Plasma TV usually shows a bit sharper of an image than plasma when motion is involved. You can also usually get larger sizes that LCD. The problem with them is they get worse over time. Although its hardly noticable the first few years, buying a 50" plasma TV for $3000 every 10 years gets expensive.Other than LCD being Liquid Crystal Display and plasma being a gas.  It's the resolution.  If you are looking for something that's not necessarily the best, but cheaper, then LCD is your best bet.  However, if price isn't an issue for you, then by all means get plasma.  Plasma TVs are usually maxed out at 1080 horizontal lines of resolution and it's also progressive scan.  You are going to get a much better picture quality with plasma.  You also won't have the narrower viewing angle that LCDs have.  Oh yeah, the lifespan has been a problem in the past, however; plasma screens have gone through a few generations now.  Manufacturers are working out the bugs with the shorter lifespan.Hd is just high definition, you can get a plasma or an lcd that is highly defined you know what i mean?. . plasma(gas) and lcd(liqid crystal display) are the types of screens and they dictate how the picture is produced, hd just describes how the screen is definedplasmatv operates on gases, and in about a timespan of 5 years or so all the gases leak out and the tv will no longer work!!!

Buy a 10$ soldering iron, $2.99 rca connectors at radio shack and put it together yourself.  really easy to do.  If you hear a reduction in bass when you plug it in, it means the wires need to be swapped.  Bam, you're done!Whoa! You are treading on dangerous ground there friend. It is not a good idea to use non-compliant cabling for your system. Just go to Radio Shack and get an RCA cable.Just make VERY sure you are comfortable soldering. The solder joint must be clean, good connection, no fray wires cross touching, etc. If in doubt, go buy one pre-made, there's plenty to choose from.I wouldn't advise using speaker wire for an RCA device. RCA cables are cheap. Just got to Radio Shack or Fry's Electronics and buy some RCA cables!

there is many losses that take place during transmission of Mw signal but the general formula is. Pr=Ps-Losses. Losses =feeder losses+Free space losses+....If you are a novice in RF this can be a complicated setup but high level answer would be the "Microwave Input" strength is the power level between the receiver and the radio and the "Received Level" is the power being level at the receiver from the far end radio. There is alot to setting this up.. What exactly are you looking for?

Save your money.DVI short for Digital Visual Interface is a true digital signal to a TV, Digital Projector Display.. . Using a component connection, also know as RGB short for RED GREEN BLUE  is an analog connection, so your HD source has to down convert to analog and back to digital, sacrificing some quality in the process.

Actually, flat screens are still rear projection.A rear projection TV is your average CRT (i.e NOT flat-screen plasma OR lcd) and the image is projected onto the screen from the rear.  A front-projection TV would be like the movie theatre or a slide projector, where the projector has a lens and is "shooting", if you will, the image at a blank screen, wall, etc.

Optical zoom is the lenses ability to enlarge.  Digital zoom is enhanced digitally by the camera electronics.  I find digital zoom to be almost useless.  You want to look for a camera with "more" than the usual 3x or 4x zoom.  The more megapixels, the better the images resolution will be and the better your prints will look.. Also a preview screen is a big help.  You can delete the picture before it is saved to the camera.  A lot of digital cameras let you use the window to set up your shot (as opposed to the eye piece). I don;t know anything about the model of camera you are considering, but you can look at reviews online.  Try Amazon.com and you can read the product reviews from people who have actually used the camera.megapixels and that's not a bad camera for $200This seems to be good value for money. the 6MP is fine for up to A3 size pictures - but your main concern should be for the OPTICAL ZOOM rating. . Cameras such as the Olympus sp500 will give 10x opitcal zoom which is all most users would want.. Optical zoom will give a clear picture - while the use of the digital zoom reduces the picture quality.. You can get the same effect as a digital zoom by using your photo editing software -so it's not really necessary unless you are printing straight from the camera (not using a PC).Mega Pixals and company, Zoom feature, software included or not. Compare others with as well.Optical zoom is all you need. In fact, most professionals suggest turning it off, so be sure the camera has that option.  We have always been Canon people, but have also recently acquired a digital Minolta and HP and am happy with both, although I prefer the HPs smaller size. I find that I prefer carrying the smaller camera and tend to have it handy at school or on the road. (I am a teacher, so it gets a lot of use.) Good luck!
There is a film of iron particles on the plastic tape. The recorder uses an elctro-magnetic head to magnetize the particles either North-South or South-North, which can then be read by a magnetic head that converts the signal back into electrical impulses, which the player can amplify.Hi Clueless. The tape is pulled past a head that when activated places the information on the tape. when the tape is played back the head senses the magnetic field on the tape and translates that into music you can hear. Hope this helps. VCRs use the same principle,Tapes are known as magnetive tapes for a reason. Like a magnet, it attracts .So they stick on.It is actually done through magnetism. On a crude level it is like iron and magnetsits magic;)
The number one, most important thing is to have a charged battery and a battery charger. Camcorders use a lot, a whole lot, of battery power. If you have or are thinking about purchasing a used camera and there is no battery or the battery is dead and there is no charger, you may be paying more to replace them that you did for the camera.. . Camcorders have 2 modes, the Camera mode for recording and the VCR mode for playback or for viewing what you have recorded. This information is based on recording to a digital 8 tape. Simply, to record to the cam, turn the selector to the camera mode and press the red, record button. To watch what you have recorded, turn the selector to VHS and look for a row of buttons that resemble those on a VHS tape player, Forward, Rewind, Play, Pause, Eject, etc... Rewind the tape and press play. You will see your movie in the LCD display which most likely needs to be pulled out from the camera body to view.Read the manualThis is a very difficult question, you need to be more specific. ie:  the type of digital camcorder you are wanting the info on, because the are hundreds or them.Go online and check the manufacturers website for the manual.
SLR Camera: Single-lens-reflex. This is a camera where the photographer sees exactly the same image that is exposed to the film and can adjust everything by turning dials and clicking buttons. Since it doesn't need any electricity to take a picture, a manual SLR camera provides an excellent illustration of the fundamental processes of photography.Good answers above, but why SLRand not, say "ILC" (Interchangeble lens camera) or something? That stems from the earlier versions of cameras that had two lenses...one to look through and one to take pics from.  These were TLR or Twin Lens REflex cameras.  When companies figured out how to use a mirror and a prism to use one lens to both look through and shoot pictures with, the SINGLE lens reflex camera was born...SLR stands for Single Lens Reflex. It refers to the way a camera is built and operates internally. SLR cameras also allow the user to change lens types for different applications. The single-lens part is pretty self-explanatory, one lens. This is contrasted to the dual-lens cameras that are used in professional photography and cost more than a car. The reflex part concerns the mirror that is part of the view-finding assembly. The mirror is moved out of the image path just prior to the exposure. This allows the image to pass through the lens and be focused onto the film. Another part of this assembly is the shutter. It consists of two "curtains" that open and close to allow light onto the film. The timing of the opening is controlled by the shutter speed. Some newer Digital camera say that they are SLR types, but these do not operate the same way as a film camera internally but allow for the flexibility of a true SLR camera. For now, film is still has a much better resolution than most all digital cameras.This acronym stands for Single Lens Reflex. It stems from the days when film cameras started offering a better way to capture an image with the movement of the internal lens mechanism. Now even digitals offer this. Some of course are far advanced & charge hefty prices. But it is also synonymous with the ability to interchange different lens's for a varied image capture. Say you are shooting really close up, you might want a Macro lens, or farther off, you might want a wide angle, or way out, you'll need a telephoto zoom lens. Hope this helped. The name Bluetooth was born from the 10th century king of Denmark, King Harold Bluetooth (whose surname is sometimes written as Bluetooh), who engaged in diplomacy which led warring parties to negotiate with each other. The inventors of the Bluetooth technology thought this a fitting name for their technology which allowed different devices to talk to each other.Yes there is a connection wireless technology, blue represents the sky and tooth the technology.

A wav file is an uncompressed container for sound. An mp3 file is a compressed format (that is not lossless), so given the same audio, an mp3 file will be generally be smaller than a wav file.wave because mp3 is compressed for portabilitywav is bigger because it is uncompressed. Even a lossless MP3 is smaller than a wave.
The memory types on mp3 players vary (256mb, 512mb, 1gb, etc.). . I would say the average good quality song is about 5mb.. . So just do the math on the number of songs u would like to be on the mp3 player and then u can decide how much memory is needed.MP3 players come in many different forms.  The style the memory is kept in is the same, but different amounts of memory and manufacturer make them different.  MP3 amounts of memory come in 512 MB (holds about 120 songs), 1 GB, 2 GB, 4 GB, 20 GB, 30 GB, 40 GB, 60GB.  Manufacturers each chose their own program to put music into the MP3 player (example: Apple with itunes).  It doesn't make a difference which you get, much.I don't know the answer but if you look in the Argos catalogue it tells you all the info you need near the mp3 players! Hope this helps!In addition to the information of the other posts, there are physical differences in mp3 memory.  With the current (as of 4/06) technology and market offerings, any mp3 player with double digit memory capacity (e.g., 20GB, 30GB, etc.) is hard drive based and any mp3 with memory in MBs or single digit memory (e.g., 128MB, 512MB, 1GB, 2GB, etc.) is flash based.  What's the difference here?  Hard drives have moving parts and don't deal well with lots of sudden physical movements.  Flash memory is in the form of chips with no moving parts.  So, if you want a mp3 player for the gym or jogging use a flash based one; hard drive mp3 players are not advised.  It is a trade-off between resilience (flash memory) and capacity (hard drives).The more memory the more songs you can down load into your mp3 player. 128MB 512MB and the 1g. the bigger the better and more songs you can have in it.

In simple terms, 1080P handles motion better (less chop/blur).  You will find 1080p with video games, but it's too much information to send via TV cable for example.  If you want to just watch TV, the best is 1080i (because they won't sent the single for 1080p).  If you want to play with a XBOX or PS3, you are better off with 1080p.1080 'I' stands for interlaced and 1080'P' stands for progressive.  The Progressive will give you a better picture.1080p has double the amount of information, and therfore better picture qualityIn each of the 60 frame rates for interlaced'i' there only half of the rows of pixels are refreshed (even ones, then odd). interlaced has an effective frame of 30. On progressive, 'p' all pixels are refreshed with each frame--giving a true 60 frames per second
A measure of resolution that reflects the ability of a digital camera to record detail. The more megapixels a camera has, the more detail its images can contain and the more they can be enlarged without losing clarity. More megapixels aren't always necessary, however. For more information see DCHQ's First Time Buyer's Guide.. . In digital imaging devices megapixels define the resolution range when the number of pixels is equal to, or greater than 1,000,000 pixels.Found by multiplying the active horizontal by active vertical pixels. eg SXGA is 1280 x 1024, or 1,310,720 pixels. This could be called a 1.3-megapixel device. MPEG Moving Pictures Expert Group. Designers of the MPEG formats standards.. . A measure of resolution that reflects the ability of a digital camera to record detail. The more megapixels a camera has, the more detail its images can contain and the more they can be enlarged without losing clarity. More megapixels aren't always necessary, however. For more information see DCHQ's First Time Buyer's Guide.The grand master in pixy landAbility of the camera to record details in fine particles.  This will be more helpful only when the picture is enlarged. If we enlarge a small area the details can be seen more clearly and with depth, the details will not be lost.A unit equal to one million pixels. The higher the resolution, the more pixels in an image and therefore the greater the image quality. An image file that is 1 megapixel (MP) can make a photo realistic print of 5 x 7 inches; a 2 MP file can make an 8 x 10-inch print; a 3 MP file can make an 11 x 14-inch print.

The video from the DVD goes to the TV on 'Aux Input 1' for instance,. and the Cable box usually uses Channel 3 of the TV,. if you have sound OUT on your TV, then connect that to the auxiliary input of you home cinema, and MUTE the TV sound,. you want to use your Home Cinema speakers, then when you watch a DVD, select that as the sound channel on the Home Cinema, else select TV for normal viewing. all you are using your TV for is to watch the video portion of a pr gramme be it TV or DVD. ALL sound goes via the Home Cinemaconnect the cable box to tv. then connect the output audio wires in input of home theater system. n connect output video wire from home theater system to tv.does your tv have RCA inputsYou are in need of a piece of audio equipment called a receiver. It has several channels and all of the audio lines from your various equipment are sent to it. A receiver will have an amplifier in it and places to plug in satellite speakers. Also a nice receiver will have a sub-woofer connect. Your Home theater system may have places to connect RCA cables but not enough. The more expensive typically the more features, inputs and outputs are provided.your home theater system should be able to plug into the back of your Digital Box, & your TV should have a coax adapter in it, for the Cable Box, unless it's a monitor...
Global System for Mobile Communications. . The Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) is the most popular standard for mobile phones in the world. GSM service is used by over 1.5 billion people across more than 210 countries and territoriesT-mobile and cingular use GSM for there phones Sprint and Verizon phones use the TDma network .The most widely-used system for mobile phones, which allows roaming almost all over the world.It is "Global Service for Mobile"It is "Global Service for Mobile". . That is . G for Global. S for Service. First you have to have a working VCR player and a working DVD recorder.  Next you will need the propper cables to connect the audio and video out of the VCR to the audio and video in on the DVD recorder.  After all this is connected, put the VCR tape in the VCR player and push the play button.  Once the VCR tape is playing and you have it at the point you want to record, start the DVD record (after inserting a blank DVD of course).Easiest way is with a DVD Recorder (but a bit more $). Just play the tape when its recording. If you get one with a hard drive you can edit out the commercials before dubbing to DVD. Just copy to hard drive, use the chapter tool to seperate, then delete the commercials. Then record to DVD.. . You can also do this on a computer with a DVD recorder but you have to have decent software like Pinnacles. Some of the commercial stuff produces low quality video. Pinnnacle has great devices for patching in too, like the MovieBox. . . HOWEVER - note that if you have commercial videotapes, they have a copy protection signal on them that will either block dubbing on a DVDR or break up the picture. To get past that you need commercial equipment that filters off the signal. The Brits have that easier and cheaper. But they use different TV technology. . . Check out: http://www.videohelp.com/guides. Search google for Macrovision remover

I think that the laser driver circuit is designed for extremely close controls causing little or no fluctuation to the laser diode.. . I am not a specialist on this subject bukt I believe a laser driver circuit is to generate a bias current based, at least in part, upon a reference average power signal and a measured average power signal, and to generate a modulation current based, at least in part, upon a reference swing power and a measured swing power signal.drives the laser, duh

The answer is mostly because the audio between stations and programs is never recorded at the same level.. . Also, audio for television programs is recorded to reflect a good dynamic range- that is, quiet scenes are really quiet so that there is more impact when any action occurs.  Commercials don't have the luxury of time to accomodate for differences in audio dynamics, so they hit you up front with "in your face" audio.Because TV stations also control how loud of soft something is. TV stations generally turn it up during the ads, and down during the television program.. . Its anoying i know. The same applies for radios.

If the house is wired with "standard" 4 conductor cable, the first line should be on red & green.  . . You can use yellow & black for the second line... just like the phone company would do it.Are we talking about wiring just one jack?. . How old is the current wiring in your home?. . Telephone wiring usually has 4-8 wires.  Your current phone line is only using 2 of them, and the others are spare.  You should be able to run to the store and get a dual jack (has two plugs) and replace the existing jack.  Connect up the second set of wires, and then connect the corresponding wires in the network interface, located where the telephone cable comes into your home.. . The problem with this is hoping the current line isn't messed up too bad, or that the installer didn't hook it up wrong.Wiring phone lines is very simple.  A phone line is just 2 wires, or 4 for 2 lines.  Get a phone jack and some wire at a local hardware store or a Radio Shack.. . Drill a small hole in the floor where you want your new jack to be, then run the wire from there to the outside phone box.  On both ends, simply strip a small amount of shielding off the wire and form it into a little hook, then put it under the screw terminals of the phone jack box.  Should just be a flathead screw terminal that you just loosen, put the wire under, then screw back down tight.. . When you look at the terminal box outside, you should see at least one wire coming out and hooking up to 2 screws for your existing line.  When they activate the second line, you may need to use trial and error to find out which of the other sets of screw terminals they activated.  Just make your new wire look similar to the one you see for the existing line.. . If you have any more questions on this just post a comment or modify your question.. . P.S.  The voltage in normal phone lines is very small.  Be carefull, but don't be afraid.  It would be more like the buzz of a 9 volt if anything.You can't pre-wire a house if it's already built. If you don't know how to run telphone wire, I wouldn't attempt it. There's voltage in those lines.RadioShack will have the wire and accessories you would need.  I don't think they sell books any more but the people who work there might help you with the information - it's fairly straightforward.. . If the people at one branch don't know, it's worth visiting more branches, you're sure to find someone who does.  . . Look for information in your public library too.take fredcdobbs answer.  That is best answer.  It would be a very rare occasion that someone would run line with only 2 conductors in it.  Now if the cable is Cat5, the colors will not be red, green, yellow, black.  They will be blue/white and orange/white.  But same principle applies.  You would connect the orange/white pair to the module in Network interface for the second line as well as the jacks where you want that line to appear.put the wire from point a to point b

mode=most...the number that occurs the most frequently in a set of dataThe mode is the number that is repeted the most times in a set.The mode is the most common number in a given set of numbers.  For example, in the set {1,2,2,3,5,5,5,6,7} the mode is 5 as it appears more than the others.mode is the thing in the list that appears the most. so in: 1 1 1 4 2 8 2 5 1. 1 is the mode because it appears 4 times

You can read from this link, and do it.. www.cdc.gov/nasd/docs/ d001401-d001500/d001473/d001473.pdfAll the tall buildings are protected against lightning in the same way.. A metal rod is planted on the top of the roof, and the same is connected to earth.. as soon as a charged cloud comes over it, opposed charge is developed on this rod which attracts the lightning or the charge,. which then goes to earth safely without causing any damage
It refers to screw mounting lenses used by the camera.There are "CS-Mounts" and "C-Mounts" in the CCTV industry. CS-Mount is the standard screw mounting for 2/3" and 1" camera lenses. The distance from the flange surface to the focal point is 17.526mm. A C-mount lens can be used on a camera with a CS-mount by adding an adapter ring to reduce this distance to 12.5mm.

USGS Geographic Data Download. Data Sets Information:. These data files are for use in geographical information systems(GIS) for analysis and integration with other geospatial data. They are not directly viewable using WWW browser or image viewing tools. The USGS offers free software for viewing some digital cartographic products, including DLG-O, DEM, DLG/SDTS and DRG data. They are tools for data preview, and are not substitutes for commercial geographic information system software. . Status Maps are available for a limited number of data sets. . Geographic Data Download Metrics . Public Domain Software for use with DEM, DLG, DRG, LULC, and SDTS files. . Spatial Data Transfer Standard (SDTS) information. Note: Please be aware that not all Native files have been converted to SDTS format. For a complete listing of data available in Native and SDTS, please go to EarthExplorerIn "geekdom", this also stands for "the Guide for Occupational Exploration" published by JIST. Check the GOE section of CareerOINK.
to complete the connection circlebatteries that are connected together in a line have the positive of one battery up against the negative of the next one.. . If they're inserted into a device where the batteries are side by side it's easier to connect the positive on one battery to the negative on the battery next to it if the two ends to be connected are side by side.. . If the batteries were all placed next to each other with all the positives at one end and all the negatives at the other end you'd have to have wires running between each positive and the negative of the adjoining battery.. . So the reason is purely for convenience.Because u gotta go with the the flow!
noise and sound waves (if loud enough) could (in theory) shake the camera which could produce a blurry picture.. . Noise in photography refers to 'grainyness', which looks like you would think that 'static' (from like a radio) would look like, thus the term 'noise'.I wonder if you mean photographic noise, or the grainy look that a picture gets on high ISO settings.  Canon is famos for making the best DSLR cameras in that regard.  Their noise is minimal.Due to loud noise, some dust particles or some foreign matter might fly in the jurisdiction of the object, and this may affect the clarity of the photo.it doesn't, unless it is causing the camera or subject to vibratesome cameras can pickup vibration from VERY loud noises and it will show in a wave on the photo (these are usually old SLR's) also of course it can make it shaky looking but both are very very rare and has to be very loud noise.It is assumed that you are talking about a digital camera noise specification. This reference to NOISE is not sound, it's electronic noise. This refers to a measurable signal that comes from individual image receptor pixels with NO light hitting them.  In other words, if you had the camera in an absolutely, totally dark room and took a picture, (no flash), there would still be something to look at on the computer screen. These would be individual pixels scattered all over the image that are a bit lighter than other pixels. Some would be totally black, others not quite as black. This is the NOISE that we are talking about. It often shows up in pictures where some of the image is very bright and some is very dark, all in the same picture. The dark areas will be mostly black with random pixels of a lighter black, that's the noise. Whatever the particular noise rating measure is, obviously you would want the lowest noise level possible, but don't pay a lot for a little bit of difference.Each pixel in a camera sensor contains one or more light sensitive photodiodes which convert the incoming light (photons) into an electrical signal which is processed into the color value of the pixel in the final image. If the same pixel would be exposed several times by the same amount of light, the resulting color values would not be identical but have small statistical variations, called "noise".

bump up the iso settings.. . . change to apperature mode and try to prolong exposure"mtoung" is correct ... change the aperature setting. But you'd better have a lens with a large aperature to do this (at least a f/2.8).To be more specific, try this.  Set the ISO to 800, set the camera to aperture-priority mode and open it wide.  The camera will meter the light and give you the fastest shutter speed for that situation.  It may be slow, so the pics may be blurry.  For that reason, use a tripod or place camera on a table or something to eliminate hand shake.  If your lens has image stabilization, turn it on.  If you can, bring the ISO even higher, though the image may get noisy from that.  But that is the best you can do.  How well your pics come out depends on your lens and the amount of light in the space you are shooting. Have fun.. . ps. Of course you can also use the flash...I am assuming you don't want to do that.

the "afterglow" on a television screen is the residual glow of the phosphorescence on the front of the screen dying away. the screen when working is being hit with electrons from an electron gun at the back of the Cathode ray tube and this exited the front inside coating to make the pictures. This assumes that your TV is a Cathode ray tube type & not a liquid crystal or plasma type tvIt's the TV watching you....i cant be positive, but i imagine it to be the nature of a television screen and the display technologies. test you're discovery with other tv's and see what you can learn!. . //edit//. watchdog: i believe she was referring not to the afterglow that lingers a few seconds, but to the mysterious glowing hours into the night, where i must believe the nature of the television screen reflects small amounts of light that most other materials absorb, thus making itself more visible when all else is shrouded in darkness

The name LG comes from an abbreviation of "Lucky Goldstar" (hangul:????), the company's name until 1995. Before changing their name, many electronic products were sold under the brand name Goldstar, while some other household products (not available outside Korea) were sold under the brand name of "Lucky." The Lucky brand was famous for producing household cleaning products and laundry detergents in South Korea. Before massive industrialization of South Korean society, the name Lucky was synonymous with toothpaste (similar to Kleenex referring to a facial tissue paper).Life's Good. http://www.lge.com/index.jhtml

Both offer nice video rendering in that case.in the way the file is compressed, besides they're different usage, IE mp3 is used for audio files and DVD for video files. you may mean the difference between the mp4 and DVD, which are both video files compressors. DVD quality is considered better of the both.

Which model are you talking about, and what is the problem with the Din plug? Some DIN plugs are soldered in while others are just crimped on, others are connected directly to a circuit board. So that people who use these items without looking at them, either because they're blind or they just do it without looking, can find the center. You can tell where your hands are on the keys without looking.. . Look at the F and J keys on your keyboard. An HDTV set is a set capable of receiving High Definition broadcast signals, it however, is not able to decode them by itself, it needs a decoder box such as the ones your local cable or satellite operator provides. An HDTV-Ready tv is the same type of tv as the previous one but it already contains an HDTV decoder built into its circuitry. This type of tv is kind of like a plug-and-play device, if you live in an area where HD signals are brodcasted by your local tv station, you can just plug an HD ready antenna to receive off air signal without having to pay for a set-top box.. . Hope that helpsHDTV's are equiped with the box to receive the HD signal. HDTV ready are not equiped with this box and it must be purchase seperatly. They retail for about $500.HDTV means it has a built-in OTA (Off The Air) HDTV Tuner.  This means the set can, typically with antennae, tune in any HDTV programming you have floating around on your local air waves (if any).  If you live in the boonies, these are essentially worthless unless you have a BIG antennae. :-)  However, in a city you could be able to pick up potentially quite a few HD channels.. . HDTV Ready means the tuner is not in your unit.  HD formats can be rendered (1080i, 720p, 480p), but there is no tuner to receive them OTA.  If you want to watch OTA HD programming you will need to buy an external tuner.  This tuner will then plug into your HD Component Inputs in older HD sets, and in newer sets may plug into the HDMI / DVI port.  Some tuners have multiple output types.. . If you plan on receiving your HD content from the cable company, DirectTV, Dish, Voom, etc. then this is a non-issue.  Using one of those providers means you need their box.  It used to be in the old days this meant you would then only consider the HD sets w/o tuners so you could save a few bucks.  These days the price of the tuner doesn't greatly affect the overall price of the unit.. . The recent development and exception to this is if you are using a Cable Company HD and it is a standard service (non-premium), then newer HD's with QAM tuners built-in can actually watch cable HD channels without a box!. . So what does all this mean?. . - if you live in an area with decent OTA HD programming, get a set with a tuner built in if you can.. - if you plan on using cable, first check with cable company to see if QAM will work. If so, try to get a set with QAM tuner support.  This will save you the box rental fee per month.  However, if you want premium channels for that set you'll probably still need the box.. - if you plan on using DirectTV, Dish, Voom, etc. then HDTV vs. HDTV-Ready has no real impact on you.. . The bottom line is the tuner is a relatively unimportant and cheap part compared to a good HDTV.  Don't let the tuner or lack of make the decision for you.  Other considerations like raw tech LCD vs. DLP vs. Plasma and what works best for you are far more important.  Go with what looks great and fits within your budget before anything else.

mag particles on plastic strip,elec signal line particles up,pickup head magnifies signal-sound & voice. check out tvradiomuseum (in ny)The tape contains magnetic particles (iron oxide) which, in an unrecorded tape, are distributed in a random manner across the tape.. . To record on the tape it passes at a constant speed past a recording head.. . The recording head is an electro-magnet.  The audio signal to be recorded is fed to this electro-magnet which produces an electromagnetic field which varies with the audio signal - it converts the electrical signal into a magnetic signal.. . The magnetic field makes the magnetic particles in the tape change their positions and they get bunched together more or separated more depending on the signal at any moment.   They form a magnetic copy of the electromagnet's signal. . . To play back the recording the tape is passed by another head, the playback head., which is very much like the recording head but it works in reverse.. . When the magneic copy on the tape passes it, the changing magnetic field in the head is converted to an electrical signal again.  It is (should be ! ) a copy of the original signal which was sent to the recording head. The signal is amplified and sent to earphones or a loudspeaker.they stopped working in 1995They use magnatized strips on which the music or other audio is stored and read from.The tape has iron oxide particles on a plastic coating when it passes the record head of the machine magnetic impulses arrange the particlae in a pattern that can be read when played over the same headwell I think that particles of light or sound are excepted on to the film and are read and produced in a hearable or seeable way

Because the inventors did WAY too many drugsBluetooth is the name given to the standard for the way devices communicate with each other. So any device that can communicate using that standard is considered a bluetooth device.
In the simplest terms, when using an S(ingle) L(ens) R(eflex) camera, what you see, is what you shoot.  You see exactly what the lens sees.. . This is on top of the obvious answers of assorted lens, variable shooting modes (and manual ones so you are not simply stuck with "presets").Because you're looking straight through the camera, therefore what you see is what you get.FULL CUSTOM CAPABILITY. YOU CAN CONTROL NEARLY EVERYTHING.An SLR camera is fitted with a mirror system that enables you to have a clear and accurate view of what you are shooting, but they do not show you exactly the image you will get:. . - most camera viewfinders only show 90 to 95% of the field covered by the film/sensor. Only pro cameras viewfinders show 100%. Manufacturing perfectly aligned mirrors is quite costly.. - depth of field is not rendered accurately except for some cameras that have a preview button. . That said, SLRs have lots of other advantages : . - A (aperture), S (speed) priority shooting or full manual modes (plus 'programs' for the entry level ones). - more frames per second in burst mode. - personalized functions and custom controls. - interchangeable lenses for more versatility. - accurate and fast autofocus. Possibility for manual focus that is often lacked by compact cameras. Better AF working range, several AF sensors.. - better flash exposure modes, possibility to use external flashes.. - possibility to reach higher ISOs (film or digital). - high end cameras are weather proof and very sturdyYou don't have to contend with the annoying problem of parallax error when you are close to your subject, as was the case with range finder cameras.

Get a "Privacy Block" on your phone so that the phone will not ring unless the person states who they are.  The phone will then ring -- you can pick up and hear who is calling-- then decide to answer.  If you do not answer, they simply get the message, "This number did not pick up the phone, call again later," or something to this extent.. . They do not know that you picked up the phone, heard who, and then hung up.block the caller adding him to your block list or something.
Go to this site:. http://www.xs4all.nl/~reneslkh/canoncam2pc/. . and download CanonCam2PC.  It works with most Canon cams and is a great FREE program (it doesn't transfer video files, just pictures).I'm guessing your laptop is new enough to have one or more USB ports, and you got a digital (not film) Canon.  The easiest way to download photos, IMHO, is to buy a card reader for the type of memory card the camera uses. Just turn off the camera, take the memory card out of the camera and put it into the reader, and plug the card reader into a USB port. The card reader acts like a "thumb drive" when plugged in, so there's no need to  hassle with special camera drivers or software.Use USB (from camera to PC) and then upoad the pictures to a specified folder.. . Assuming you have the correct driver and are using WinXP.  Good luck!

An ohmmeter does have a DC supply (commonly a 1.5V cell or a 9V battery) and does send a small current through the circuit under test. The resulting current or voltage drop is then measured and displayed as a calibrated resistance reading in ohms.. . WKIT has nothing to do wit voltage.resistance of a given value is use to control the current in a circuit,that requires a safe load to a component.Usually in mil.amps,the analogue or digital ohm meeter measures the colour bands that signifies the resistance code,that lets you know watt the resistance is required for a circuit to work properly.SAY  the resistance is 220 ohms,and you get a reading of 90 ohms then it is defective,if the reading is 4000 ohms then there is to much resistance to cur-ent,the curcuit is at default.Replacing the resistor is reguired. ect...

If you are in the US you can buy a 12v DC convertor at Big Lots stores or at most electronics stores. You can also buy them on eBay.Hey there,. I'd just use a transformer and a diode, but it's probably more complex than thatYou would have to wire an interposing relay 120Vac onto the motion detector then supply your 12Vdc camera through one of the relay contacts.. The motion detector must give you a switched 120Vac output i'm assuming... Connet this 120Vac to the relay coil then the other side of the coil to neutral. Every time the motion detector activates, the relay will energise.. Supply one of the contacts (Common) with 12Vdc from your battery and take the supply for your camera from the Normally Open contact of the relay then back from your camera to -Ve. . Sorted.you'd probably be best off look a opto-isolator circuits, these will keep the high power circuit away from the low power. one, but it will still be able to control it using a LDR on the low power circuit that will turn it on when the bulb on the high power circuit is turned on.You can get a converter at your local electronics store. it will look like a cell phone charger . The ac unit wont circulate air as affective as a fan will.  Circulating the air will while the ac is on at the start will allow the mass of the air to be more consistently cooled.. . When you first fire up a fan the air that is currently in the room is not "mixed up" good, when the fan mixes it up it feels as if the ac unit is not working properly.. . You can actually save energy by using a fan due to a more constant air temp keeping your thermostat at an average temp instead of varying temps because of stale air.warm air rises to the top and cold air sinks.  so it's colder at ground level. if the room fan is on, it stirs up the air thus mixing the warm and the cold air. the general effect will be that of a slightly warmer environment. of cause there is also the heat generated from the fan motor.. but the thermostat will eventually brings the temperature back to its original level albeit you'll feel colder now cos of the cold wind.You are cooling a larger volume of air.More hot air mixing with cool! Good Luck!

"Line out" is a clean output, at a fixed volume used to connect your mp3 player to a stereo (usually) that has its own amplifier.  If you connect the stereo to the headphone jack, you run the risk of having the volume too high or too low, causing unwanted noise.  Normally, you would not use this for headphones, although they will work, but you cannot change the volume.  I never use mine, except to connect the MP3 player to my surround sound system."Line out" is a stereo output that is used for connection to an external system. So, for example if you want to connect it to an amplifier with speakers you'd use the "line out". It's not really for headphones...there should be a separate headphone jack for your headphones...but check your manual to be sure. . . If you do want to do any of this you'll probably need a stereo mini-jack to stereo RCA-type cable. Your local Radio Shack can help you find the right cable to do the job.It's probably a line level output.  You can think of it as an attenuated headphone jack with a fixed output rather than a variable output (meaning it will be at its loudest regardless of the volume setting on your player).  With the right cable/adapter, you could use this output to hook your player up to a stereo using the stereo's CD or TAPE input, but understand you would adjust the volume with your stereo's volume control or remote, not with the player.  You can bring the player with you to a Radio Shack and they'll fix you up with the proper cable/adapter (they're not very expensive).It's either for your headphones/another pair of headphones, or can go to a stereo, maybe, but highly unlikely to be the port to your computer.

readable. read/writable. ...beyond that is just a guess from meDVD-r you can only record onto the disk once. DVD+r never heard of it probably the same as above. DVD-RW you can rerecord onto the disk multiple times. DVD+RW never heard of it probably same as DVD-RWdvd-r and dvd+r you can record on once only, dvd-rw and dvd+rw you can record on limitless times. the difference between -r/rw and +r/rw is simply the format, like betamax and vhs. they do the same thing but the format is different.the difference between - and + are two different brands who produced similar DVD technology.  the "R" means "read", as in your drive can only read DVD.  RW is Read/Write, as in your drive will read or write (make) data to a blank DVD.. . There is also a symbol which I can't type, but it is a + above a -   which means the DVD drive will do either + or - technology.RW means re writer usually, well the other is just a writer.  Not sure about the dashes and pluses though. Ask someone at a computer shop.they are just dirrent formats. rw stands for rewritable, so they can be written to, and erased many times. r can only be recorded to once. the + and - is just a formatting, some burners only work with +r and +rw, but most work with both.DVD-r is a DVD that you can burn, and DVD-rw is rewriteable, so you can burn something on it more than once.DVD stands for Digital Versatile/Video Disc, DVDR stands for DVD Recordable and DVDRW for DVD ReWriteable. If you're familiar with regular audio/music CDs or regular DVD-Video discs, then you will know what a recordable DVD looks like. A recordable DVD stores up to 2 hours of very good quality DVD-Video, including several audio tracks in formats like stereo, Dolby Digital or DTS and also advanced menu systems, subtitles and still pictures that can be played by many standalone DVD Players and most computer DVD-ROMs. If you choose to lower the video quality it is possible to store several hours video on a recordable DVD using low bitrates and low resolution with video quality more like VHS, SVHS, SVCD, CVD or VCD. It is also possible to have up to 4.37* GB ordinary data or mix DVD-Video and data on a recordable DVD that can be played by most computer DVD-ROMs.. . There are three competing DVD Recording standards, DVD-R/DVD-RW and DVD+R/DVD+RW have pretty similiar features and are compatible with many standalone DVD Players and most DVD-ROMs while DVD-RAM has less DVD Player and DVD-ROM compatibility but better recording features.. . DVD-R and DVD-RW. DVD-R was the first DVD recording format released that was compatible with standalone DVD Players.. DVD-R is a non-rewriteable format and it is compatible with about 93% of all DVD Players and most DVD-ROMs. . DVD-RW is a rewriteable format and it is compatible with about 80% of all DVD Players and most DVD-ROMs. . DVD-R and DVD-RW supports single side 4.37 computer GB* DVDs(called DVD-5) and double sided 8.75 computer GB* DVDs(called DVD-10).. These formats are supported by DVDForum.. . DVD+R and DVD+RW. DVD+R is a non-rewritable format and it is compatible with about 89% of all DVD Players and most DVD-ROMs. . DVD+RW is a rewritable format and is compatible with about 79% of all DVD Players and most DVD-ROMs.. DVD+R and DVD+RW supports single side 4.37 computer GB* DVDs(called DVD-5) and double side 8.75 computer GB* DVDs(called DVD-10).. These formats are supported by the DVD+RW Alliance.
The batteries are part of the film pack. When you put in new film you automatically get new batteries.WITH A HAMMERYou don't. It is in the film.
Because calls are handled by local radio transceivers, which can communicate with each other and with switching stations by land lines or directed microwave transceivers.  So, the overall structure of the network is lots of small areas coordinated together by the overall structure, like cells in a living organism, thus the terms "cellular network" and a "cellular phone".   This was shortened to "cell phone".each antenna has it's own cell or reception area.The mobile phone system works on the concept of dividing areas into small cells. Each base station covers a particular group of cells. For simplicity a large area is divided into a group of 7 hexagonal cells and this is repeated throughout the coverage area.cell being short for cellular. . also cause americans are crazycause the net that provides the coverage of the phone is devided to cells, which are powered by stations.It's short for cellular,in Ireland they are called mobile phonesShort for 'cellular telephone', its because they they split up the city into cells - looks kinda like a honeycomb, each cell is about ten square miles. Each cell has a base station, and thats where you'll get your signal from.our mobile phone is called a "cell" phone coz, the system used for mobile communication-- GSM works on an architecture called cellular architecture.so "cell" word came from a part of this system called a cell.....

A Retriever is usually Golden in colour and is a working dog whereas an amplifier is something used by Eddie Van halen .a (not an) receiver is an (not a) amplifier with a radio receiver built into it. an (not a ) amplifier is just that , an (not a )amplifier ......without the radio receiver in it.One receives the signal and the other amplifies the signal.receivers usually comes with a radio tuner and have your basic hook ups to speakers or vcr or dvd....amplifier do not come with radio. it does help boost the sounds of the speakers. a classic combo of a stereo system usually comes with bothe receiver and amplifier....from there if u want to get serious ..there's power amplifiers and pre amp ...equalizers and so on.....A reciever is what takes in the signal and converts to a sound wave frequency that we can hear (5kHz-20kHz). The signal recieved is in a digtal form sent from either a satelite, or an antenna that needs to be converted to analog wave. The Amplifiier end is there the increase the intensity of the sound.

If you entered into the agreement in NYC, and you have a regional plan that only covers the local NYC area, then it means you are out of your calling area and you will be charged more.  Or if you have a national plan with a local smaller cell phone carrier, not Cingular or Verizon or T-Mobile, it means you are on another carrier's network.it means you will probably pay a buttload of money if you use the phone while roaming.It basically means.. well let me give u an example... You arent picking up a signal from your own carrier check you settingsRoaming is defined as the ability for a cellular customer to automatically make & receive voice calls, send & receive data, or access other services when travelling outside the geographical coverage area of the home network, by means of using a visited network.

Repeating dialing means dialing the most previous number being dialed on that same phone.Repeat dialing is to dial again.It's basically auto redial and allows a user to press a code such as *66  the central office switch will continue to dial the number until the line you tried to call becomes available. You should receive a distinctive ring that notify's you that the busy line is available to accept a call. This is normally available on a charge per use basis or at a monthly rate as a service feature on your phone lineits when the phone will continue to try the number and when its no longer busy you get special ring cus the phone is auto connecting for you
SD cards(secure digital  cards) and MMC info are all here. http://www.geocities.com/romidar/mmcvssd.htm. . I would say both are good.SDs are cheaper and slightly more secure. MMCs are thinner. If your device can take both i suggest SDsMMC appears to have been introduced first.  SD uses same physical form factor but adds a small (tiny) slide switch on the side edge of the package allowing you to 'secure' your data (prevents recording/writing to the memory chip), by sliding it to the 'secure' position (away from the contact pins in my experience).
