I assume you live in this planet.On September 7, 2005, Apple announced the successor to the iPod mini, the iPod nano. Based on flash memory instead of a hard drive, the iPod nano is 0.27 inches (6.9 mm) thick, weighs 1.5 ounces (42 g), and is 62% smaller by volume than its predecessor, available in 1 GB (introduced on February 7, 2006), 2 GB, and 4 GB models. It has a 65,536 color display that can display photographs, and connects to a computer via USB 2.0. The headphone jack is located on the bottom. It retains the standard 30-pin dock connector for compatibility with third-party peripherals. The nano is the first dock connector iPod that cannot sync to any PC (Windows or Mac) via FireWire cable, though it can still be charged via a FireWire connection.. . The iPod nano has several features that would later be included into the fifth generation iPod. These features were new to the iPod operating system, including the addition of world clocks, a stopwatch, and a screenlock option. The world clock allows users to set the time in cities around the world, and set alarms for each time zone. The clocks can be set to adjust for Daylight Saving Time. The stopwatch feature allows users to press Start to start the timer, and the Stop button to stop. While the timer is on, the Start button changes to a Lap button that allows the user to time individual laps. The nano saves the user's stopwatch stats for multiple timing sessions, which is useful for comparing times. The screenlock option lets users set a four-digit passcode for their iPod, and once the screenlock is activated the only buttons that can be pressed are the skip forwards and backwards and the play/pause buttons. The click wheel is used to input the digits to the passcode. In the event that the passcode is forgotten and the user is locked out, the iPod can be plugged into the user's computer and the iPod will be unlocked.. . The iPod nano is available in white and black, in 1 GB (US$149), 2 GB (US$199) and 4 GB (US$249) models. There have been a number of complaints about the nano's screen being too soft, resulting in it becoming easily scratched or even cracking if put under too much pressure. The iPod body itself was also very delicate and can scratch easily. The surface is a soft plastic and normal use can easily damage the surface (and this seems to be more prominent on the black model than the white model). For this reason, Apple started to package both the nano and the fifth-generation iPods with soft fabric cloth carrying case which should help prevent scratches to the screen and body. The case does not allow access to the screen. Controls can be accessed but only with great difficulty.that person is completely wrong (jeffs hammer), ipod nanos do have screens, theyre just like the regular ipod but VERY small and VERY thin, with colored screens. i have one myself and mine holds about 1000 songs.  he's mistaking it with the ipod shuffle that has no screen.a small thin, mp3 player to play music on the go, while you're walking or doing something away from a stereo, and more compact than a cd player!IPOD Nano is a portable music player made by Apple. The "Nano" version is a very small player without a screen. It holds up to 120 songs. I'm looking at one right now!. . A photocoupler is a LED and photodiode in a single package. If the LED is excited then the photodiode picks up the light and registers a signal. It is a one way device and it is used to electrically isolate two circuits.A photocoupler may also be called an optoisolator and there are many different versions of this device. They commonly have an LED on the input side but may use different types of devices for the output, depending on the application. Common ones include photodiodes, transistors, thyristors, or logic gates.. .    Some of the first versions of this device which I recall seeing used in guitar amps was a tiny incandescent bulb and a photoresistor. Eventually the lamp would burn out and if you were very careful you could actually replace it!. .    The photocoupler serves the same purpose in modern equipment as the nearly extinct magnetic relay which was so popular in past decades. It allows a low powered circuit to control a higher powered one and isolates the currents in the two circuits.. . WK

Get a "molly bolt" plastic anchor kit at the hardware store if the wall is sheetrock. Then you punch a small hole in the sheetrock with a phillips head screwdriver and tap the plastic anchor into the hole tightly. Insert the screw so that it protrudes enough to hang the clock on it. If there's a wooden wall stud directly behind where you want to hang something, you can just screw directly through the sheetrock into the wood stud and you don't need the plastic anchor insert.You hang it up like a picture, genius.
who knows?Probably refers to the sensor sensitivity/ISO setting.  Basically the higher the sensitivity/ISO, the less light you need to take pictures.  The tradeoff is that the higher you go on ISO the more noise is introduced to the image.  DSLRs with larger sensors normally work better at high ISO then compacts.This refers to the amount of light that is required to make a picture that is usable in terms of not being too noisy / grainy. The more sensitive the camera is, the less light will be required for an acceptable photo. It is best to simply light the scene properly when posible. Unfortunately in the real world this is not always possible.. . WK
LCD screens are very fragile, but the picture is great (I have a Sharp Aquos and I love it), they also cost less than plasma tvs. LCD stands for liquid crystal. There is no pixellation with an LCD or a Plasma.LCD TVs generally ranges at the lower end of screen sizes, while Plasma on the higher end.. A part from that, Plasma is prone to an effect called Burn-In, where some statis picture, e.g. broadcaster's logo, is permanently burned into the screen.. LCD in the other hand have a problem with Dead pixels, and Stuck Pixels, where pixels on the screen might be permenantly off, or lightened up. Though with better manufacturing processes today, it is reducing.. Also, Plasma generally consumes more power than an LCD screen.Plasma displays function differently than any other TV technology in that they actually produce light independently at each pixel on the screen, as opposed to projecting a separate light source through or off of other elements to conjure a picture. A plasma "screen" is actually a dense network of individual cells, three for each pixel of the display (coated with red, green and blue phosphors, respectively). Each cell is impregnated with a rare-gas mixture and connected to an individual electrode. When the electrode for a given cell is charged with an electrical voltage, the gas is converted to a plasma state and emits a burst of ultraviolet light; this in turn causes the phosphors to react and produce bright visible light at the pixel level. By varying the voltage and intensity of the electrical charge, the proper combination of red, green and blue light is produced in each pixel to combine into a bright, colorful composite image. Plasma TVs are available in sizes from about 40" up to 70"+, but be prepared for sticker shock as your size desires increase.. . Strengths. Obviously, plasma TVs are desirable for their sleek form factor — about 4" deep and wall-mountable, they're undeniably sexy. Furthermore, plasma produces a very bright image that can be viewed in a well-lit room, with superb color accuracy and saturation. It's a matter of opinion, but many videophiles regard plasma's color vibrancy as beyond compare among current technologies. Because the light is produced at the screen rather than projected onto it, focus is consistent and reliable across the entire screen surface, and plasma screens can be viewed from angles as severe as 160 degrees off-axis without detrimental effect. And plasma's accurate pixel structure produces a picture that is geometrically perfect from edge to edge and corner to corner, with uniform light output and a crisp, lifelike image.. . Considerations. Early plasma TVs got a bad rap for their susceptibility to "burn-in" from static images such as stock-tickers and video-game gauges. Recent designs have largely eliminated this problem, incorporating (among other approaches) "pixel-orbiting" technologies that shift images, almost imperceptibly, over time to limit the occurrence of burn-in. However, if you are an avid gamer, you may wish to consider an alternative technology like flat-panel LCD, which is immune to burn-in.. . Additionally, although known for their high contrast (relative to LCD) and spectacular color saturation, plasma displays have historically had difficulty reproducing pure blacks. Recent enhancements have significantly mitigated this problem, but sometimes at the expense of fine detail in dimly-lit areas of the picture.. . The bottom line. Overall, plasma has maintained a reputation as the no-compromise high-tech HDTV display technology. While that's not entirely accurate, there's no question that a plasma TV on your living room wall will deliver amazing video performance – and, quite likely, a parade of drooling friends through your door as well.  . . LCD Projection. Not to be confused with LCD Flat-Panel display technology, LCD Projection is nevertheless related to its pricier flat-panel cousin. Like DLP and LCOS projection, LCD Projection is a microdisplay technology, meaning that the image is created on a thumbnail-size chip or chips, and projected onto a larger screen surface by means of a powerful light source in conjunction with a sophisticated system of precision optics and mirrors. As with LCD flat-panel systems, LCD projection is a transmissive technology, meaning that light is transmitted through the chip or chips, rather than created at the screen surface as with plasma or bounced off a reflective modulator like the DMD chip used in DLP projection systems. Fundamentally, LCD projection works like an old-fashion slide projector, where the "slide" is a dynamic LCD chip rather than a stati

MP3 player actually refers to any player capable of playing mp3 files and it's also used for players capable of playing more than mp3, e.g. wma aac. . . Ipod is an mp3 player.an mp3 player is consider an mp3 player if it has a functionality to play various format of compressed digital audio. now an ipod is a brand which is known to have a good market in the mp3 player industry.iPod is just Apple's brand of mp3 player.  Some, such as the newer iPods, also play video in addition to other music file formats such as wma, so you need to look at product descriptions to get the whole story.  But mp3 is the format of primary use for music players, so the other formats aren't really important.  Part of the reason that iPods have become the most popular mp3 player is because of its ease of use, large storage, and syncronization with iTunes.  So if you are looking at buying an mp3 player, you need to look at what you expect from it (such as size, capacity, etc.).Ipods are a type of mp3 players. they only hold itunes, as far as i know. a mega pixels is one million pixels.  There more mega pixels, the larger the resolution of the photo is.  A 1 MB camera cannot print a quality poster, but a 12 mega pixel camera can.  FYI, if you are taking pictures for fun, a 3 - 5 mega pixel camera will give you crystal clear pictures.My only addition is this...don't let any salesman tell you 6 megapixels is a whole lot better than 5.  Noticeable differences above 5 megapixels can only be seen with significant increases (like from 5 to 8)...A megapixel is 1 million pixels, and is usually used to express the resolution capabilities of digital cameras. For example, a camera that can take pictures with a resolution of 2048ª1536 pixels is commonly said to have "3.1 megapixels" (2048 ª 1536 = 3,145,728).Pictures are normally printed in pixels which is the small dots if you take a closer look (try looking closely at a photo in a newspaper).  The more the dots, the better the quality of the picture.  "Mega" means "million"...so if you have a 5 mega pixel digital camera.  It only means that it could produce a photo that has 5 million pixels.A megapixel (that is, a million pixels) is a unit of image sensing capacity in a digital camera. (A pixel - a word invented from "picture element" - is the basic unit of programmable color on a computer display or in a computer image.) In general, the more megapixels in a camera, the better the resolution when printing an image in a given size. A digital camera with a 1.3 megapixel resolution will print a good quality 4 x 3 inch print at 300 dpi (dots per inch). If a higher quality is needed or a larger print at the same quality, a camera with a higher megapixel value will be needed.Definitions of Mega Pixel on the Web:. . 1 Million Pixel Image. Usually produced with high-end digital cameras, and Scanners. The greater the pixel count of an image the higher the resolution of that image.. www.pcphotoreview.com/Learn%5Edigitalglossarycrx.aspx. . The imaging term for a Image sensor of one million pixels or more. The higher geometric pixel resolution of these sensors produce higher quality digital photographic images.. innovation.olympus.com/common/glossary.htmla mega pixel is equal to a thousand pixels.  digital images, whether photos, artwork, websites, are made up of pixels. your computer screen has millions of pixels to make the screen's images. a camera's rating in terms of amount of megapixels is equal to the ability of a digital camera to record detail. The more megapixels a camera has, the more detail its images can contain and the more they can be enlarged without losing clarity. More megapixels aren't always necessary, however.. (please choose as "best answer" - i want to win the world cup contest!)Megapixels simply imply the size of the image and nothing else. Not all digitl sensors are the same, the amount of megapixels has nothing to do with the quality of the pixels themselves.It's a unit of measurement essentially.  Remember those paintings you saw in school a long time ago that looked like dots up close, but if you move backwards, it makes a picture?. . Well, all pictures are essentially like that if you zoom in enough.  A camera with more mega-pixels uses smaller and smaller dots in order to form the picture.  Resulting in a clearer, crisper image.A pixel is 1 million pixels.  The greater mega pixel capability your camera has, the better the photo quality.  The more megapixels, the more infomation, and better resolution.

A CCD or charge-coupled device is an image sensor, consisting of an integrated circuit containing an array of linked, or coupled, capacitors sensitive to the light. Under the control of an external circuit, each capacitor can transfer its electric charge to one or other of its neighbours. CCDs are used in digital photography and astronomy.A charge-coupled device (CCD) is an image sensor, consisting of an integrated circuit containing an array of linked, or coupled, capacitors sensitive to the light.

A composite signal contains both the brightness and color information, therefore the video has a bit 'lower' quality due to the mixing.. . A component signal usually separates at least brightness and color, sometimes even the individual RGB signals. Quality is better due to less 'mixing'.the spellingvideo can be sent in many different ways. Here is a list of the most common  from worst to best quality..  * Composite - (the  yellow jack).  * S-Video - (a black round jack with multiple pins inside).  * Component - (red, green, and blue coded jacks).  * DVI - (D-shaped connection with a combination of pins and a blade depending on the version of DVI).  * HDMI - (D-shaped connection about the size of a USB port on the computer). . Each step up helps separate parts of information into multiple streams of data. This keeps noise from being introduced from cross contamination.Composite is a step up from coaxial RF. However, unlike coaxial RF, composite can only transmit video. It transmits the luminance (brightness) and chrominance (color) information over a single interconnect. The most commonly used interconnect for composite is called RCA, its ends are usually always colored yellow. Also composite should be rated at 75ohms.. . Composite can only do SD, it cannot do ED or HD.. . Component takes it a step and then some further than S-video. It subtracts the luminance (brightness) signal from the subcomponents of the chrominance signals (blue and red signals); it is often described as Y, R-Y, B-Y or as YpbPr. Component also instead of bundling it all in one cable, bundles it into three separate cables. This helps with better color separation, less bleeding and interference. It uses RCA connectors and is color coded as Red, Blue and Green. Like the others, component should be rated at 75ohms.. . Component can do SD, ED and HD.

Optical zoom lets you get to the subject closer with no sacrifice of resolution unlike digital. The rest are already answered previously.optical means the lens moves,. digital means you just use the center area of the sensor matrix (no lens moving). 12x4=48. MIKEIgnore digital zoom you can do that in the computer when your cropping it.  A 12X optical is pretty good for all around shooting though,  A good camera with a 12X optical is the Canon S2ISBeware of marketing. . 12 times zoom is by software manipulation (comes with the program for the camera). . 4 times is hard or physical zoom achieved through the actual movement of the lens. . 48 is their multiplication (and means nothing) software achieved zoom is ineffective and hardly worth it. Most people dont bother anyway.. . In effect you have 4x zoom (which is how you can train the camera closer to an object). . PS: Make sure you dont buy HP cameras - really cheap garbageWrong.  It means just that, 12 X zoom on your pictures and being able to see in your view finder 4X.  Your thinking is true for microscopes and binouculars and such optical devices but in the digital world, zoom is the actual number.Using the lense you can get 12 times closer to an object. You can then multiply that by 4 times digitally. Be ware though, Digital Zoom reduces picture quality. Optical does not.

If both resistors are in series across the battery, the voltage drop across the 470 ohms will be 5.1 and that across the 360 ohms 3.9.. . When you exit, you're walking thru a sensitive receiving antenna array tuned to a specific frequency which is produced by a tiny metallic strip hidden somewhere in the item(s) in question. There are actually 2 metallic strips, 1 that will produce the required frequency, and 1 that is a flat metal plane that when pressed against the other strip will prevent it from being detected. A powerful magnetic device is used to slam the 2 strips together at checkout, deactivating the device.barcodes on items/goodiesthere is a little submiter that is deavted when it passes threw the things on the sides.i think its the cameras.... obviously.. i mean theyre right there.Item attached with special barcode can be catched by MICR.. There are other newly introduced electronic form of verifier includes with item these day.
The phone knows what it's putting out. By "subtracting" the output sound from the one it's sending back, it effectively "takes out" the speakerphone noise from what it's sending out of the microphone. . More complicatedly, the phone saves the stream that it outputs, reverses the polarity of the stream, and merges it with the input from the microphone.thats a very good question...i never thought of that...i dunno   :)

There is no fee to use GPS. GPS consists of a 'galaxy' of satellites in geostationary orbit (thanks to the US Military) that transmit signals that are picked up by your GPS receiver. The software in your unit computes your position based upon which satellites your unit is receiving signals from and the information in those signals.The short answer is that you have an electronic gizzmo that finds/is found by at least 3 satellites. The distance between them is calculated and it can tell you where you are.. . There is no fee for a regular GPS unit. There are fancy ones that can be put in cars that may. The main thing that may be beyond the upfront cost is that some of them can have new maps put in, and that would be extra.. . The long answer (these guys are great):. http://electronics.howstuffworks.com/gps.htmYes there is a fee as it is a very costly system to avail of.GPS chips are inserted into your phone and the satellites track down your cellphone.Yes, they work.  Just make sure that you have one that will read the satelites in your area.  I'm in Germany, and not all US GPS systems will work here.. . No, there is no monthly fee.

You need to have the speakers connected the same way round or you get a strange effect when you listen (antiphase) which makes the bass disappear as well.. If you have a polarity marker on your speakers and speaker cable [ maybe a stripe], make sure that both spkrs are connected the SAME way round.  If you can change the way you connect the cables to the amp then do this the same way as well.. If you have a marker like a red dot or a + sign at the amp, make this the line which goes to dot or + at the speaker.Basically what ansabrism said. Because the speaker works off of a magnet/electromagnet, you reverse the poles and make it go backwards.if you connect the speakers the wrong way around, you effectively invert the waveform in that channel. this is actually ok if you connect both of them the wrong way around, but if only one is inverted, then sounds that are common to both speakers will be cancelled out...

the evaporator is the part that draws heat out of the fridge contents - it should be cold and tucked way out of sight.  The condenser is the wire mesh thing at the back.  That should be warm, along with the pipes feeding it and the delivery end of the compressor.  40C doesn't seem too hot for that.  Are the pipes from compressor to condenser located in the side wall?modern fridge have this feature. The gas pipe are run so close the outer wall. It is a sign that it is working and efficient. No hassle at all.this happens to my fridge too, so I'd say u'r right.the question is, is the side warmer than the back, or is the back warmer?. . edit: it occurs to me that maybe you have one of those two-door fridges, would it make sense for the condenser to be on the fridge side in that case?

MP3 is an audio format only, and the name "MP3" has incorrectly come to mean a digital music player. It was invented in late 1980s. MP4 is a "container" which means it can be a video file, or an audio file. The songs sold on Apple's iTunes Music Store are in AAC format.they are different audio encodings

It is an abbreviation for MIL-STD-810 Revision F. . According to Wikipedia: "The MIL-STD-810 series are the specifications for various environmental tests to prove that equipment qualified to the standard will survive in the field".. . I guess the advantage of buying a phone with this feature would be that it would be more resistant to damage.An abbreviation for MIL-STD-810 Revision F. . The MIL-STD-810 series are the specifications for various environmental tests to prove that equipment qualified to the standard will survive in the field. . Revisions up to Rev C used fairly generic tests for various classes of gear. Once Rev D came around (Circa 1985) the testing, in particular shock and vibration were more tailored for the actual expected operating environment. . It is important to know which methods a device is qualified under, and different methods test for different things. . For Instance:. . MIL-STD 810E Method 500.3 Low Pressure (aka Altitude testing) MIL-STD 810E Method 501.3 High Temperature (Both storage and operating) MIL-STD 810E Method 502.3 Low Temperature (Ditto) MIL-STD 810E Method 503.3 Temperature Shock (How well does the device handle going from high to low temps, and back). . MIL-STD 810E Method 506.3 Rain (How does the device do in wind blown rain) MIL-STD 810E Method 507.3 Humidity (Can it handle high Humidity) MIL-STD 810E Method 508.4 Fungus (device is exposed to warm moist air in the presence of Fungus to see if it grows on the device). . MIL-STD 810E Method 509.3 Salt Fog (does it rust/fail when exposed to salt fog) MIL-STD 810E Method 510.3 Sand and Dust (how well does the unit work when exposed to - you guessed it - sand and dust) MIL-STD 810E Method 511.3 Explosive Atmosphere (does it create enough sparks/etc to cause an explosive atmosphere to blow up) MIL-STD 810E Method 512.3 Leakage MIL-STD 810E Method 513.4 Acceleration (constant accleration) MIL-STD 810E Method 516.4 Shock (either Shock Response Spectrums, or Triangle/sine/square wave shocks) - also transport shock MIL-STD 810E Method 519.4 Gunfire MIL-STD 810E Method 520.1 Temp, Humidity, Vibration (Traditionally sine wave (pre D) - later random vibration - combined with Temp testing) MIL-STD 810E Method 521.1 Icing, Freezing Rain (what it sounds like). . Retrieved from "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_810F_Spec". . . seems like having this in aphone gives it proper peaparation for harsh environments to the usual cellphone...

Most laptops are equipped with an S-Video output on it.  This connection looks like a round computer connection that a mouse would be plugged into, but it is not.  All you would need is to purchase a S-video cable and plug it into the big screen and then change the input on your Tv to match whichever slot you plugged the laptop into, usually something like Video 1 or 2.Most Laptops do not have S-Video conntections. All have VGA connections. Get yourself a VGA to Component Video cable.. . If you do have one of the few laptops that have S-Video go with VGA anyway. S-Video is just about the worse signal you can use. . . http://www.dvdcity.com/video/sw-media-vga-rca.html

Wireless television was the first method by which television was broadcast.  All televisions are equipped to get a wireless signal.  The only thing needed is a television antenna.  In areas with strong broadcast signals, you can attach a small antenna directly to the television, or put in on top of the cabinet, and connect it to the antenna inputs on the TV.  In areas far from a broadcast tower, you might need to install a roof antenna to get reception.. . In general, the stations that broadcast in this fashion are not the same ones that broadcast on cable TV, though the major TV networks are usually transmitted via cable as well.Wireless TV? You need to be more specific, what are you talking about? TV's have always been "wireless".
The combination of photonics and microelectronics. When they are packaged together, they provide the capacity to generate, transport and manipulate data at phenomenal rates.Those other two answeres are both close, but the practical answer is in signal isolation.. . If a component process an electronic signal and interfaces with outside connections or external devices, you look for isolation to protect the equipment.. . In optoelectronics, the input electronic signal is converted (internally) to a pulse of light and transmitted (again internally to the component) to a receiver where it is then output.  The only interaction between the input stage and the output stage is a blinking light, so you don't see risk of short circuits across your optoelectronic components.Hi Friend,. It is the branch which deals with combined application of optics and electronics. The *PHOTO VOLTAIC EFFECT is at the starting point of this field. One important application of this is found in biomedical equipments (widely in ECG recorders) which facilitates total isolation of patient from the live sensors or transducers which are live electrically. The varying signal can be made to modulate intensity or interval of light pulse trains, which in turn can be demodulated by 'pick ups'. These pickups are out of contact electrically with the preceding sensor circuits there by giving very high levels of electrical isolation. The ultra wide band telephone lines make use of magnetoptics to accomodate staggering numbers of simultaneous conversation signals without any cross interference. they make use of modulated light beams to send and receive information. This field is so vast even the CD Rom pick up, Magnetoptic pick up, DVD pick up etc. all make use of magnetoptic principles.. * PHOTO VOLTAIC EFFECT-This discovery brought nobel price to Albert Einstein. This is the effect shown by some semi conductor materials where by the incident light can produce a proportional electrical voltage. It is also heard that Albert Einstien's 'Theory of Relativity' was never properly understood by the scientific cfraternity in it's initial days and later they found it to be so much revolutionary they were forced to give a nobel price to Albert Einstien and they got this rather trivial discovery of his.(As compared to Relativity)The branch of physics that deals with the interconversion of electricity and light.

I dont trust Nokia or Ericcson blue tooth accessories.Bluetooth is a short-range communications technology intended to replace the cables connecting portable and/or fixed devices while maintaining high levels of security. The best thing about them is the key features are that they are low power, and low cost. . . Each device can simultaneously communicate with up to seven other devices.
the motion pictures are stored in frame modules one 30sec motion flim may have nearly <>150 frames and above and not less than minmum of 10. when running the frames forward with a specific speed you will find the picture in the frame with small moves as a motion. for example you take a book not less than 100 pages and see the page number while moveing the pages very fast. you will see the page numbers moves up and down.electroencephalographicThey are exposed onto film for high quality and are usually exposed at 24 frames per second to create a seamless motion.. the frames are exposed by the light coming through the lens, the shutter then opens and exposes the film to light for a fraction of a second and is then taken back into the storage area [ called the magazine] and is then taken to be processed and then scanned in to a digital database.. .  sorry the shutter on a motion picture camera is a spinning mirror that exposes light on the film for 1/24 of a second.. and it isnt always scanned in.

They're even up to 30 megapixels and more.. . You need to choose a camera based on what you plan to do with it. Are you taking pictures of friends and family? going traveling and want a pictorial record of your trip? taking pictures of landscapes and scenery? close ups of flowers, insects, or other objects? sporting events? news stories? portraits?. . All of these different uses of cameras usually involve selecting a type of camera that works best for each.. . If you are thinking of digital cameras and you are not shooting professionally, anything that is 3 megapixels and above will produce decent 5" X 7" photos. If you plan to take larger pictures, you need 5 to 8 megapixels.. . However, don't be swayed by megapixels alone. A camera can have a zillion megapixels and be a piece of junk. If you're planning to spend over $100 stick with the better types of Camera made by Canon, Nikon, but also Sony, and some of the newer digitals.. . Good luck. Term used currently in the United States and Canada (and in other countries as well during the 1980s) to refer to most mobile phones. It technically applies specifically to mobile phones which use a cellular network. In developing mobile phone technology, American electrical engineers saw the main technical problem as achieving a smooth handoff from one radio antenna to the next. After they gave the name "cell" to the zone covered by each antenna, it was a natural choice for them to apply the term "cellular" to both the technology and the phones that ran on it.Because the zones that each tower covers is called a cell.

If you're asking if you can convert "composite" video (yellow wire) to "component" video (red, green, blue wires), even if you could afford it, there's no point. It will only look worse, if even discernable. Unless you're trying to make all video signals in a particular entertainment system layout the same format; you can get a processor to do that, its just not really a consumer product. Commercial stuff has pretty big $$$$$ tag.no conversion neccisary. Just plug them in. The colors on the connectors don't match, so decide which goes where.Apart from using or building a special converter which I don't think you can buy, the only easy way would be to run the RCA video into the Aux input of a DVDR and take the output from the Component Video output.

Factory trained camera tech here. I own a JVC camcorder and they are actually quite good for their price.. . However, several recent models of JVC camcorders had an inherent defect from the factory. The defect was a high failure rate of the (Sony-made) CCD image sensors in these cams. JVC has posted a notice on their website stating that they will repair this defect for free under a special warranty if the camera is sent directly to them. See the link below to determine if your model is included.. . Good luck!. WKCan your camcorder display picture on the view finder? If the answer is yes then there is a fault with LCD screen on your camcorder and you need to get it fixed by authorised repairer.. . If your answer is no, then the problem is not with LCD but in camcorder circuit. If you camcorder is still in the warrenty then you won't have to pay to get it repaired by JVC.

Well to your question, 20G's means you have a little less space, to put music, games, videos, etc. but 60G's will make the console go a LITTLE bit faster, and much more space, but still, I don't plan on using 60G's on a console, preferably on my PCSony set out to make the PS3 your home media center, with the ability to download and upload movies music and all kinds of media. The 60 G will offer more space to do exactly that, but if you just want strictly a game console the 20 will operate exactly the same, same games, same speed, same graphics.. . Added: The HD size has "ZERO" to do with speed. Think of it as a hose filling a 20 gallon bucket vs. a 60 gallon the water (data) goes the same speed the 60 just holds more. This is what makes the machine fast:. 1 gig of sram. Main RAM 25.6GB/s. RSX @550MHz. Total floating point performance: 218 GFLOPS. These specs are the same for both.The 60GB will have more memory that's about it.  Just like purchasing a 30GB vs 60GB ipod.  They will perform the same, but storage space will be severely limited on the 20GB version. PMPO stand for Peak Momentary Power Output, a truly worthless unit of measure, good speakers / amplifiers are always measured in watts RMS ( root mean squared ), PMPO makes the speaker rating lok artificially high as it measured for the small peak time a speaker or amp can hold the signal ( and I mean VERY short as in miliseconds ), but conmsidering any and all speaker can be measured that way ( and in that case you would see really good speakers with even more insane PMPO numbers ), but those that use the PMPO will fail in the true RMS, as true RMS rating reflect a speaker that can be driven at a given wattage all day long with a given amount of distortion ( very low percentage ), PMPO cannot and are very low threshold speakers / amps, hence the cheap PMPO rating to make it seem like you get a lot of power handling for very little money.Watts are the used to measure power ( mechanical or electrical). Therefore the watts written on speakers is their power output while PM PO is just a way to sell crappy speakers and fooling people :)))I think both units of measurement are bogus.  PMPO is a ridiculous measurement designed to further confuse an already confused consumer market.  RMS Watts are a measurement that describes a speakers ability to accept power for a prolonged period without damage.  It doesn't measure how efficiently the speaker uses said power and it doesn't describe the quality of the output.. . I would like to see a new industry standard unit of measurement introduced that with one glance will tell you power handling, efficiency, and frequency response.  This is a pipe dream, because the industry likes to keep the consumer in the dark, but a guy can wish, right?

The electric signals flow in coil around the magnet and the resultant would be that the magnet moves back and forth, A diaphragm is attached so the diaphraghm moves back and forth, so the air moves and you hear the sound.Check this site. a podcast is like a TV show, except they are usually audio only. they are like a TV show in the fact that there are individual episoides. they are different in the fact that they are made to be downloaded for free and listened to (or for video podcasts, watched) whenever you want to. to use an audio podcast on your iPod nano all you have to do is add it to the sync list.The term podcast, like "radio", can mean both the content and the method of delivery. A podcast is generally analogous to a recorded television or radio series. Podcasters' web sites usually offer direct download or streaming of their files, but a podcast is distinguished by its ability to be downloaded automatically using software capable of reading RSS or Atom feeds.. . You can find tons of podcasts at http://www.podcast.net/A Podcast is usually a audio-only file that people can post to their websites or blogs. It can be news, opinions, etc - but is usually spoken word.. . The easiest way to get podcasts is via iTunes - they have a podcast section now.. . If you know anybody that produces podcasts, you can download the file, just like a music file, and drag it into the Podcast folder in iTunes, and synch it to get it loaded into your nano.

Most banana plugs I have seen, need to be crimped on the wire.  So you would need a crimper to do it.. . You have to make sure that your receiver has binding posts for banana plugs.They need to be crimped on to the wire but you also need to make sure there are no plastic caps on the speakers or on the reciever. get a usb bluetooth dongle off ebay for supa cheepBluetooth is an industrial specification for wireless personal area networks (PANs), also known as IEEE 802.15.1. Bluetooth provides a way to connect and exchange information between devices like personal digital assistants (PDAs), mobile phones, laptops, PCs, printers and digital cameras via a secure, low-cost, globally available short range radio frequency.. . The adapters range in price, depending on your brand name. TigerDirect has a few for as low as $9.99 (after rebate). Simply plug the device into the computer's USB and you'll be able to use Bluetooth to connect your computer and phone.The only way to transfer data would be thru bluetooth, unless you have a cable (which can be found online or in most cell phone stores). If you check Circuit City or Best Buy, most of them sell a little blue thumb-shaped thing that plugs into your USB and gives your computer Bluetooth support, all for around $30. . It's made by Kensington.

When I got my cell phone, I was getting calls for the person that used to have my number for a while.With a three digit area code, and a seven digit local phone number, there are literally hundreds of millions of numbers, that are available, in the U.S. alone. HDTV means the TV has a tuner built into it to pick up local HDTV signals with an over the air antenna. In some cases the tuner will decode HDTV cable too (Cable Card).. . HDTV ready means the TV will display high definition, but it requires an external over the air tuner to get the local stations, or an external cable box capable of decoding High Def signals.. . If your source is satellite, then in both cases you need an external HDTV satellite reciever and it will connect to the TV through a DVI or HDMI connection.exactly what siberia said
so you can connect your tvs sound up to it for better quality louder aswellIt allows the amp to switch not just the audio but the video streams too. As an example, I have a VCR, DVD player and Satellite receiver and hook all three into the AVR (Denon 2106) and then I run video to the TV from the AVR. Now I can listen to anything in much better sound and I don't have to fool with changing inputs on the TV and AVR.The video connections are for people that have mutiple video sources: VCR, DVD player DVR, ect...  This way when you push the DVD button on your receiver, the video and audio are switched together.You could hook up another screen.  Otherwise, it's a waste of a perfectly good plugamps typically dont have multiple a/v inputs and dont switch inputs, what you have is probably a reciever, or an integrated amp.  A true amp is meant to be used with a pre-amp.  The preamp has all the inputs, and the amp powers the speakers.  Receivers are basically a pre-amp and an amp combined, and they usually have a tuner.  An integrated amp is basically the same as a receiver except that it doesnt have a built in tuner.. . Anyways, they have video inputs so that you have have your vcr, dvd player, satelite, and your game systems all hooked up to your tv at once, and only need to hit one button to switch them.Convenience, it is an Audio Visual amp.  It just allows you to have one point to connect all of your devices for sound and video and then one output to the TV.  It allows you to switch sources quickly and easily.The video in and outputs usually are there for a convenience.Some people have DVD and Video sources that need to be hooked up to a tv with limited inputs. There is no signal loss in using the amps in and outs and the High Def outputs can actually amplify the signal to give a better quality picture,using component inputs or S-VHSread your question. its an AV amp audio video im sure you can connect video to itYou use the video inputs to use the amp/receiver as the main unit in your system.  Many receivers have a component output and several inputs.  By using this, you allow the reciever to switch the audio and video for you.  Think of it as a router or a hub.  It works well.

as already said around 1ghz range, but countries tend to have there own set of frequencies.. . If you buy a tri band phone it has frequencies for example . USA - UK and europe, this means tri band phones have 3 sets of frequencies they can operate on.. . So hope that helps you, if you look on google there are scanner enthusiasts who actually list all the frequencies of all the networks world wide, too much info for here but worth a look if your interested in that area.There are two bands of frequencies in use for cellphones.. . One is a little below 1GHz and one is a little above.

Hope you have an AV RECEIVER that is capable of decoding 7.1 channel sound. If you have one of those just go and plug all the satellites to the terminals located in the back of the AV RECEIVER and plug the sub woofer to the sub woofer terminal. Now set the phase control or just go and set the cut of frequency for the sub woofer, calibrate the overall soind and you are done. If you have an older 5.1 then you have to compromise on 2 satellites, or else go get an powered stereo amplifier and look if there is anyway you can connect it to av receiver and speakers. Hope that answers your question.
That's an error code. Try reseting it (soft restart, won't erase your music if done properly). If that doesn't resolve it, contact support.Orange= Charging. Green=On. Flashing=(possibly low battery)This is indeed an error code which indicates that the shuffle lost contact with the computer while performaing an operation and is now stuck. I would recommend trying to reset it. If that does not work, make sure that you have the latest version of iTunes and download the latest iPod updater. You can try to use that to reset the Shuffle back to factory settings. If that fails, and the shuffle is still under warranty, take it down to the local Apple store or call Apple support. They will likely declare it DOA and replace it. If it is out of warranty, some people have had success using a disk utility to reformat the drive, then running the updater to reset it. Good Luck.

Answered this previously for another community member.... . . Everything that you need to download the pics to your PC will come with the camera. The typcial digital camera comes with a USB cable to connect the camera to the PC. It also will ship with some software for managing the photos on your PC.. . One accessory that you might consider when you buy the camera is a Memory reader. You can leave the memory reader connected to your PC and when you want to download photos you just pop the memory card out of the camera and into the memory reader. The PC sees the memory card as another drive and you can drag and drop the photos from the memory card to the PC's desktop or folders.. . The reader I have is from Sandisk:. http://www.sandisk.com/Products/Catalog(1079)-Readers_Writers_and_Adapters.aspxlook itdepends on which model it is but u have to install camra software first.Your camera should have come with a cord that plugs into the usb port on your computer, and it should have come with a program that you install into your computer in order to download the pictures.  Ususally the program has to be isntalled before you can download the pictures via the port.have ur pics printed and insert them in ur foppy disk drive. lolwe need more information to answer this question.  do you have a cord???does your camera have any outputs???if you just want the pics--your best bet is to take the memorie card out of the camera and go to save-ons or somewhere to develop film and have them make them into picsnot a prob. at all if u have win xp jus conect ur camera to it & walla!! the comp configures ur camera by itself after that a box appears please click the option OPEN FOLDERS to view files..(connect ur camera via the usb provided with ur camera)if u have a scanner its easy.if u dont download pictures in ur cd and than to ur computer.Are you fricken serious?!  I am sure you know what a USB port is right...(universal serial bus) Windows XP does have this new and exciting plug and play feature, and even if your device is not recognized, you can use the internet to download the driver...if a prompt window doesn't show up, go to my computer, and you will see a few different categories...C: (your cpu's hard drive) D: (your disk drive) and devices with removable storage usually E: F: G: and H: one of them should be your device (your camera) right click and choose explore, your folders will pop-up and you are good to hook...there are two ways, first is you should have a cable with the camera which you plug in to a usb port on your computer and the camera, and then follow the instructions on your computer. second is you get yourself a little memory card reader (this will depend on the type of memory card in your camera), you take the card out of the camera, put it in the reader and then plug it into a usb port on your computer.

DVD recorder stores on a 3.5 inch DVD (As of now) and is of HD resolution.  A hard drive will store on a built-in hard drive that you need to transfer to a DVD/CD/Tape at a later time.. . Both camcorders will playback what you have recoreded.HardDrive = DVD-RAM, can record and erase unlimited amount of data, including .jpgs.. DVD can be DVD-R, or DVD-RW, can be formatted(finalized) to play on standard DVD players, no .jpgsWell the biggest difference is how the camcorder stores the video. The DVD one will record the video to a DVD disc, and a hard drive camcorder will record the video to a built in hard drive.well the biggest thing i know is that the dvd camcorder records on dvd and the hard drive records onto the hard drive.DVD camcorder is easier to use in the sense that you can playback directly on a DVD player. You don't need to connect your camcorder to your television. Each DVD disc records 30mins of video only.. . Harddrive camcorders have built-in hard drives which can record at least 4 hours video. The quality is similar to DVD camcorder but difference is that, if you want to edit the video, you can download it to your computer faster than real time. For example if you have a 4hour video, it won't take 4 hours to download to your computer. But yes if you want to playback on television, you need to connect your camcorder to your television.. . Hard Drive camcorders also allows you to change the video quality settings. On 20GB hard drive you can record 4hours to 12 hours video.

So here is the list of things you require:. . 1. cd/dvd wirte. 2. burning software (WINXP PRO has inbuilt or if you have baught a cd/dvd writer the sofware comes bundled with it). . Go to the folder contaning the MP3 files select whichever files you want to burn or all of them if you require. Right click on any/them, on the menu look for send to, on clicking upon send to there's a sub menu, by default the last option is your CD/DVD drive. Once you click on it, ther's a massege on the system tray area (the right bottom of you screen), if you click the bubble it opens the cd writing wizard. Look for left top you can see in the folder pane a line called "Write these filse to cd/dvd", Click on it.. . What happens when you dont have the cd/dvd writing option on the send to menu. Dont worry!!! Here's the answer to that. . Open My Computers (Explorer Window), right click on the cd/dvd icon, go to properties, the properties window shall pop up, in the properties window the last tab is recording, click on that, and look for the option "Enable CD recording on this drive", click the check box and VOILA!!! there you are, you have just enabled WIN XP Pro Cd/DVD wirting.. . Generally range from 50-300$not too sure this helps. but as far as i know different set-top boxes are designed to decode different types of signals received. as such "different channels = different signals". diodes have a wide variety of jobs and types, in general its a semi conductor that pass the cauurent in one direction and block it on the other direction. diodes are used to convert AC voltage into DC, lighting (LEDs), protection, oscilation, regulating and much more.An electronic device that restricts current flow chiefly to one direction.. An electron tube having a cathode and an anode.. A two-terminal semiconductor device used chiefly as a rectifier.. . Whatever all that means...................scans packages into computer system for companys like FedEx, UPS, and DHL
It has a flat screen.  It can be a tube TV though with a fat back so watchout.an ordinary t.v. with a flat screen, as apposed to a curved screen.Flatscreen can be a CRT (e.g. a normal TV) or it can be LCD or Plasma. It simply means that the screen is truly flat (a bigger deal for CRT than the other technologies) so that glare is minimised and the picture is better if you are not at an optimal viewing point. By default, for domestic use you can expect LCD and plasma to be flat by the nature of the technology, although there are lots of new lcd screens being designed for other uses that wont be flatscreens.it has a flat screenSonyOn CRT's it means the screen in which the picture is displayed on is flat.  You know, the glass part.  It provides better picture shape because the picture is being displayed on a flat surface, as opposed to older TV with curved screens that causes a "warped" look to the picture.  Plus, thet generally look better.  Of course it's not to be confused with "flat pannel" TV.  Flat pannels are LCD and/or plasma TV, and they are very small in depth so it takes up less room, but they cost more than flat CRTs.its what it sounds like. the tv which has its visual screen exactly flat.its exactly what it says. it is completely flat all the way round

Thats how I do it, the only snag is you have to be watching what you are recording.On my satellite receiver, there are multiple RCA [red, yellow, white] outputs, you can take RCA from the satellite to a VCR, then switch the input on the VCR to composite video, and record.  If your VCR doesn't have RCA, then go "Out to TV" from the satellite box to the "IN from ANTENNA" on the VCR with a coaxial cable.  Just select the channel on your satellite and touch record on the VCR.The Sat has audio outs located on the back, the VCR has audio in located on the back of it. DVD player is better than VCR because you can watch never before seen scene on whatever movie that you like and most of the movies have bloopers in there that the VCR movie don't.  also you can listen to the music (if you can hear a little...lol) also make sure you be careful with the DVD so that you don't scratch iteverytime u play a tape on the vcr it strips some of the tape thust in time giving u an ugly worn movie look. the dvd doesnt do this. . the music tapes do this as well.because you can get to the scene you want much faster, and dvd's arent as bulky as cassettesThe DVD has wide screen, pan scan, and little box. It's Digital Audio Outputs, the optical and the RCA. DVD has different formats of audio, like Dolby Digital, THX, DolbyProLogic. The VCR has two formats of video, full screen and Wide screen. VCR has Analog Outputs, coaxial and RCA. To connect a VCR you need a coaxial cable, from VCR to T.V. or a pair of RCA. For the DVD you need analog RCA, Digital S-Video or HDTV (High Definition Television).because it more up to date it has a mp3 player and plays old and new movies and has more slots for dvd,swho said it was?They're easier to use and the DVDs last longer. You just have to be careful with the DVDs and make sure you don't scratch them.first off its hard to fin vhs for vcrs so its just more simple to get the newest thingPicture is clearer.. You don't have to rewind the movie.You will get a clearer picture and better sound quality from a DVD than a VCR! you can also get "direct access" to any scene in a movie without having to rewind through a whole tape to see your favorite actor/actress at their most impressive. Plus it has a Flux Capacitor.DVD is better quality and you don't have to rewind and you can skip around to places ALOT easier, DVD's also have special featuresDVDs last up to 100 years with care, VHS on the shelf and unused lasts only up to 10 usually. . . Since the signal from a DVD comes from variations detected by laser, there isn't anything touching the surface to wear it out. VHS tapes are touched by the heads and spindles as they play, wearing the tape and it's signals, out.. . DVDs can carry a more detailed signal that VHS tape, giving you better picture and sound quality.. . DVDs take up much less space to store than VHS tapes.. . If you spill liquid on a DVD, you can wash it off in running water, polish gently with a soft cloth and you're good to go. VHS tape is toast if something spills on it.. . If you store VHS tapes near anything magnetic (like a TV screen...), they lose their quality and finally the entire signal. DVDs are impervious to magnetism.Because it's so easy to find the scene you want! You don't have to spend half an hour rewinding it! Also, DVDs are much more portable than VHS tapes. And it's becoming increasingly more difficult to find VHS tapes. It's a lot like CDs and cassettes. Even if you prefer cassettes, they've become outdated.What everybody has said, plus VCRs are being phased out.  Blockbuster only has DVDs now.I have a beta.It has great picture quality. If you take care of your DVDs, they can last forever. W/ VHS they tend to wear out. W/ DVD players you can rewind much better. Step 1: Get a Recordable CD/DVD.. Step 2: Install a CD/DVD Burning Software like Nero, Roxio InCD etc.... Step 3: As per the Instruction in the Software Proceed with the Burn steps.The burner will let you copy data onto the DVD, but not copy an entire Movie DVD.  For that, you need a program that will removing the encoding and create an image that can then be burned onto the Blank DVD.. . Try DVD Shrink.  Run that first, create an image from your Movie DVD to your hard drive (you can make an ISO image).  Then run your DVD burning software and create a DVD using that image.. . You have successfully "backed up" your movie.

There are 3 technologies for TV's:. Plasma is made of little tubes of fluorescent light (Much like neon) in three colors RGB(Red, Green, Blue).. CRT (Cathode Ray Tube) Normal old technology, not so slim, but can achieve better definition & colors.. LCD (liquid Cristal Display) Large white tubes of light, liquid cristal iodes (which let light or don't) and a color filter.Plasma refers to the way the picture is put on the screen (as opposed to a classic tube TV, a projection TV, or a liquid crystal display).... . The slim TV refers to the actual thickness of the TV (which have to be plasmas (or liquid crystal like a laptop screen, but not usually with TVs because the quality is horrible) because the other types take up more space behind the screen to work)... but not all plasmas have to be slim (although most are for convenience)PLASMA refers to a type of technology, SLIM is a general reference to the new types of displays that can be wall mounted, and includes PLASMA as well as LCD(back-lit). Also Known As Microdisplaysa plasma tv has a projection like view whereas a slim tv has a flat tv view

wap and mobile internet are the same thing and ask who ever it is that u have a contract with a get them to explain as i don't really knowWAP is the protocol used in accessing internet from mobile.. GPRS is the bearer for the data that is being transfered from webserver to your mobile. Another beared is GSM data call ( CSD - Circuit switched data). To access mobile internet you need either WAP + GPRS or WAP + CSD.
Your doubt is not without any base/reason.Anyone *with the right equipment* can listen in on your calls, though the right equipment is pretty expensive and hard to get nowadays.  Earlier on you could just dial in the correct radio frequency and listen in, but the digital call data is encrypted now, and it's much harder.. . Nobody can make calls on your *phone* without physically having it, but it is possible to duplicate your SIM card (if they can either decrypt the ID # or get a hold of your card for a few minutes to copy it then put it back), then they can use another phone to make calls on your account.. . All in all -- pretty safe.  Much safer than analog land lines :)yes they can - though they have taken steps to scramble conversations - it is not as easy as before but there is always a chance and if you live in the US, then it is confirmed that our own gov. does it on a regular basis -

The slot for a firewire cable. It's usually on camcorders and DVD recorders.It's a digital communication standardits the slot of wireless cable.The IEEE-488 bus was developed to connect and control programmable instruments, and to provide a standard interface for communication between instruments from different sources. Hewlett-Packard originally developed the interfacing technique, and called it HP-IB. The interface quickly gained popularity in the computer industry. Because the interface was so versatile, the IEEE committee renamed it GPIB (General Purpose interface Bus).. . further information u can get from wikipediaInstitute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers(IEEE) 488. . For a measuring system we have a standard such as kilogram, metre, second. So that in worldwide its same.. . Similarly, there were some standards before world war II to maintain standards on the side of electronics. IEEE came up after world war II with its head quarters at New York, which is widely accedpted by many organissations, agenices, American National Standard Institute(ANSI). . IEEE standard address the device and specifies controls, functions and tests the equipment then gives the maximum current, voltage, etc. Safety is most important factor.. . One of the most important standards is the IEEE 488 is a digital interface for programmable instrumentation for test and other equipments. Standardizing the interface between test equipment makes it possible to interface various pieces of laboratory test equipment, regardless of amnufacture, to create sophisticated automatic test equpment systems.. . IEEE 488 is basically an interface(LINK) between a 8 bit processor and a equipment. It is a short distance system with computer located at 10 feet or so.. . Any number of devices can be joint in this interface.. It has one LISTENER, TALKER, LISTEN AND TALK, LISTEN ANT TALK AND CONTROL. Control acts as a traffic cop.Bus are connectiong wires.. . It has 1. Seven data bus,. . 2. Data Byte Transfer control. 2.1.DAV DAta Valid. 2.2 NRFD Not Ready For Data. 2.3 NDAC Not Data ACcepted. These are hand shaking lines.. . . 3.General Interace Manggement . 3.1 IFC Inter Face Clear. 3.2 ATN Attention. 3.3 SRQ Service ReQuest. 3.4 REN Remote ENable. 3.5 EOI End Or Identify. . Everything as name implies.. . Additional units can be implied. Totally its a linker.... . Hope u r clerar...

If there is a loose or bad connection, giving it a hit may actually temporarly put it back in place.. . It usually is not a good idea to hit an electronic device.  Most of the time, it won't actually fix the problem and could make it worse or even actually break the unit.A lot of "experts" just give the equipment a good hit and then it works as good as new!. They say they don't get paid for hitting it, but for knowing WHERE to hit it.. . I have my own theory on this:. Most of the electronic stuff these days is very intelliegent with computer chips and memory etc. It "learns" or "remembers" that if it does not behave properly it will get hit again. Just like a little kid (but with less noise and less mess). . . Next time your phone malfuntions, don't leave it standing in a corner.... give it a good smack!I agree to zargonmaximus. Very likely, it has some form of loose connection on the solder joints on the PCB. Again, it is a bad idea to give your gear a whack when it is not working properly. Go to a competent tech to have it fixed

In telecommunication, a Hamming code is an error-correcting code named after its inventor, Richard Hamming. Hamming codes can detect single and double-bit errors, and correct single-bit errors as well. In contrast, the simple parity code cannot detect errors where two bits are transposed, nor can it help correct the errors it can find.a Hamming code is an error-correcting code named after its inventor, Richard Hamming. Hamming codes can detect single and double-bit errors, and correct single-bit errors as well. In contrast, the simple parity code cannot detect errors where two bits are transposed, nor can it help correct the errors it can find.

Both phones should have an infrared (IR) port. Place them together (not more than 7-10 cm) so that both ports are facing each other. Make sure you have enabled the Infrared on both phones. If its a music clip you want to transfer, please remember that Nokia used "Read One media player" and supported file extensions like .amr and .rm or .mp3. For pictures and video clips also make sure that your receiving phone recognizes the file format (like .jpg or .avi) otherwise even after the data is transferred, it is possible that the receiver set refuses to play it, in such cases it is usually stored in "applications". There are however software freely available which can also help you in converting this data into readable stuff. Best way is to select (picture, video clip, sound clip) and then push "send" and when options are displayed like blue tooth, email, select infra red. That should do the job.first the infra red on both cellphones must be switched on.then go to the file you want to send and there must an option for sending data via infra red .it is so simple to ransfer data from one cell phone to another. . if u wana transfer some data from nokia to samsung just browse to that file in nokis go in its options or menu or propertis there wil be an option send--->via infra red---> then its infra red will be automatically on... then put  on the IR port of samsuing and then put samsung's IR port in front of its IR port.... in IR data transfer IR ports should be in front of each other and shuld not be at large distance..... . if u wana transfer from samsung to nokia then do it vice versa.... thanxit is easy. first you set to switch on infrared of the recepient mobile phone. go to the file you want to transfer and so to send options and choose via infrared.you need to keep the infrafed ports of both mobiles very close near each other.Do a search for cellphone data transfer kit.
It's generally pretty easy to install an A/C unit as it will come with all the brackets and hardware you'll need to do it.  Ultimately it depends on how good you are with these sorts of things.  If you get it home and can't install it then I'd recommend calling a local  handyman to do it.  A local guy will charge you a lot less than the store will charge you, plus you'll get some peace of mind since you live above a busy sidewalk.Go to Home Depot or Lowe's and inquire in the A/C department.  They'll be able to tell you what needs to be done to install it, and then you can make an informed decision.  My feeling, without knowing all your circumstances is that you (with the help of a handy friend) could install it easily and safely.

sRGB has wider color gamut (more range of colors visible) but then CMYK printers cannot print even all the colors of generic RGB, so its just for your viewing pleasure.sRGB is the generic color profile.  If you are going to use any Adobe product for post processing your pictures then use the Adobe sRGB color profile.  If not, then stay with the generic profile. Color profiles are used to insure accurate color reproduction.

Well, to stop anyother scratches buy a case for it.you cant i pod material so sensitive so buy yourself a case so you dont have to look at the scratches.Zbluespot has the right idea, but what you can do for very cheap is go out to a store and pick up a bottle of Brasso, which is like a stainless steel, iron, and other types of metal cleaner. It can not only take a good number of scratches out of the back (as long as you are using a microcloth), but it can be used on the front too, and is completely safe, just try not to get it inside the clickwheel. And it's only about $5 for a bottle. Or if you want something meant for the iPod that you can buy online, try looking into iDrops, iCleaner, and Applesauce (no, not the food, the brand!)If the scratches are on the screen--leave the scratches alone.  Don't do anything except clean the screen with a microfiber cloth.  Buy a screen protector to keep the scratches from getting worse or getting more of scratches.  You can pick up screen protectors at Best Buy where they sell PDAs.. . If you are talking about the case--I believe iPods are stainless steel cases with an enamel paint.  I would *carefully* try a fine grit rubbing compound with a cotton ball and gently try to lift the scratch.  If you press hard at all, you'll cause more damage to the iPod.  Actually, if I were you, I wouldn't try to fix the scratch and instead look for a new cover--they have many very cool covers and cases for iPods these days.. . Peace!. . ~zb

Hey babe! first you should turn on the bluetooth on both devices, go into your connection settings search for device the headset should show up on the phone screen select the device enter options pair them and you're on your way to wireless handsfree communicationsIt's very easy on some phones and hard on others.  You first have to charge the bluetooth headset, and turn it on by holding the button down until it blinks.  Then, from Standby mode, press down on the Navigation ket to get to the Bluetooh Menu.  Then, select Paired Devices. Make sure the headset is on, and hit the soft key "right" and select "new, then "search new".  It should ask if you want to turn bluetooth on, so hit "yes" and then it should find the device.  Press OK, then enter in the 4-digit passkey for the headset, more than likely in the instruction manual. If not, it's probably 0000, then hit "ok".  If it all went through OK, you should be able to turn the headset on and it will automatically detect it on the phone.  Hope that helps you out.I believe it's already IN the phone, though I could be wrong.

If all you want a manual switch then a 'single pole, single throw' (SPST) switch will work, they are similar to light switches, or you can get push buttons.  Ask at your local electronics / hobby store.. . You can also do some other fancy stuff by using some transistors and other various goodies.  You can make or a circuit the turns on/ off by some other external stimuli, such as touch switches.. . But from your description you should just purchase a simple switch from Radio Shack.You also need a resistor in series with the l.e.d. to limit the current through it.  . . Its value will depend upon the battery voltage and the maximum allowable current for which the l.e.d. is rated.. . You may find this of help http://www.davidbridgen.com/leds.htmyou can get switches at radio shack. there should be a little shelf in the electronic parts areas that say "switches"

It's actually "active" versus "passive" sub, and the difference is that an active sub is powered (by it's own amp), while a passive sub relies on external amplification.An active subwoofer has an amplifier built in (which means you send it an unpowered cable like an RCA cable and must provide it with power) whereas a passive subwoofer has no amplifier and must be connected with speaker wire. If you buying a subwoofer for a dolby digital home theater is HAS to be an active subwoofer. Also, there are really no quality passive subwoofers made for home theater (they make good ones for pro audio).Actually, . . Atlantic Technology make a 16,000 set of speakers that contains 2 or more passive subs, powered by a high current outboard amp with more eq adjustments on it than a typical active sub.  Sounds great
OCR is a technology that makes it possible for scanned documents to be converted into text.. . Normally when a page is scanned, the page is saved as an image, even if it is a page of words. If a page of text is saved as a image, you cannot edit the text, because it is just a "picture" of the words.. . The OCR recognizes the shapes of the letters and words and converts the image of the words into a text file that you can edit using a word processor.When you scan a page of text (like a book page), the resulting file is usually a graphics file (gif, jpeg, etc).. . OCR can turn that into a text file. Ideally, it would save you a lot of typing time.OCR is using software with your scanner to transfer Text on a paper page to an editable text file that you can use in your word processor. The scanner transfers your type written document to an ASCII file that your word processor can work with.

you can not erase a cd-r. The r stands for read only. You can only erase cd-rw which stands for re-write.You can only do that with a rewritable CD.  You can't do it with a standard CD-R or CD +R.  It must be a CD RW

Push to talk. (Not puch to talk) is referenced to a microphone switch. The microphone is not 'live' until you "Push" a button  to active it, so as to be heard. Normally, this system is found in recording studio control rooms, on the mixing board, so as so selectively communicate with the clients in the studio, so they don't hear control-room conversation constantly.yeap, jes like wlkie talkie, where only one person can talk at one time. Its supposed to be cheaper cuz its its using GPRS as its platform.Kinda like a walkie-talkie....push a button and talk to a friend on a similar enabled device coast to coast!!. . Nextel was first know for it, but others have joined in.its like nextel's walkie talkie plan, you can call someone sort of like a radio or a walkie talkiePush to talk is like a walkie talkie on your cell phone.  It lets you connect to several people at once and you use your phone like a handheld radio rather than a phone.first off, the answer above mine is GREAT! . . well,  i have never heard of "punch to talk". i have however heard of "push to talk". nextel first had this on their direct connect phones to show people where to push to start the direct connect conversations. they also had this on walkie talkies back in the days so kids (and adults i assume) would know whick button to push to start or participate in the conversation. the PTT for various providers obviously vary. it is like a walkie talkie across america however. you don't have to wait for the phone to ring and the person whom you are calling has no choice but to hear what you have to say, like walkie talkies back in the says. there is a delay of 5-15 seconds (verizon and cingular have the highest delay, followed by sprint with 2 seconds and nextel has only 1/4 to 1/2 second delay). downfall: no voicemail on PTT. upside: you can talk to as many as 10 people (on nextel, 5-7 with others) at the same time. this is why PTT is very popular for laborers like construcition, city, etc.

Everything that you need to download the pics to your PC will come with the camera. The typcial digital camera comes with a USB cable to connect the camera to the PC. It also will ship with some software for managing the photos on your PC.. . One accessory that you might consider when you buy the camera is a Memory reader. You can leave the memory reader connected to your PC and when you want to download photos you just pop the memory card out of the camera and into the memory reader. The PC sees the memory card as another drive and you can drag and drop the photos from the memory card to the PC's desktop or folders.. . The reader I have is from Sandisk:. http://www.sandisk.com/Products/Catalog(1153)-Readers_Writers_and_Adapters.aspxSince it seems like you want an easy to use digital camera, I recommend the Canon Elph. It lets you click pictures, lets you shoot video snippets and then you can download them easily to your PC via a USB cable. The best part is that the camera is small and fits well in your palm.. To download pictures, ensure that the(any) camera supports USB and that your PC has a USB port (mostly all do).You may or may not need the camera software to view the pictures.. For printing, I recommend that you go to a shop like Walmart or Walgreens or dozen others use their kiosks that will take the digital card from your camera and print the pictures out. They are cheap and good!thelukeandrews just became my new hero. That was beautiful!The instruction book will explain.  Check that your computer has a USB port.  This will be the lead that links your computer to the camera, and this is normally included wiht the camera.all you need is a computer made after 1997 or so. the rest will come with the camera.i do agree with them first buy one then u'll be guided by the cam giude provided how to do itit depends on what kind of camera you want to get. . most cameras come with a card, so you need a card reader, but your computer might have one on it already.  some other cameras can hook up to your computer via a USB cord.  from there, a folder will probably open up, or you can find USB ports in "my computer". but all of that would probably be in the manual.

Do you know what is wrong with the shutter?.   . Do you believe your camera shop?  Did they have a vested interest in selling you a new one? . My local library has a book on repairing old cameras.. If it is beyond economic repair, you have nothing to lose but time and effort by trying to  repair it. Do you have good eyesight and a bit of mechanical/electronic aptitude and patience? . A reliable second hand replacement might be obtainable for very little.Forget it. This is not a DIY job.. Cameras are built around the shutter. Low end models are built to last 50,000 actuations (pictures), semi pro models are built for around 100,000, and professional models are built for 200,000+ actuations. When the shutter is worn out or otherwise damaged, you're looking at an expensive repair.. And the camera shop was probably right - unless you have a high end camera, repairing the shutter is not worth while.it probably wont be worth fixing. depending on the camera you have you will probably find that you can buy the same camera in working order second hand for less than the cost of repair - unless it is a more recent pro model. have a look on ebay or your local camera shop. thousands of people have these cameras and want to trade them in to get digital cameras but there is no demand for them so they are selling for peanuts

It is more detailed in quality. The Picture quality is far more better than the regular TV, even they have come out with HD-DVD. Everything is going High DEF, propabily soon your PC monitor will go HIGH DEF.I believe because it has high definition.it has double the lines of scan giving you better picture quality and less flickerHigh Defintion TV has alot clearer of a picture and virtually peerfect sound (speakers are sometimes sold seperatly but the ones built in are good too) but is not as budget friendly. Not only do you need to be watching an HD channel but you also need to have an HDTV and an HDTV broadcast, cable, or sattilite box (or both, depending on your services and television inputs). The following are the 3 major types of HDTVs. Not all of these TVs are HD so be sure to find out if they are HD ready (can use HD with a HD box (sold seperatly by your TV provider)) or HD built in (you can hook up HD service without a box (you need to have HD hook-ups for HD built in TVs)). Catho-Ray tube HDTVs are the most budget friendly HDTVs, are box shaped, and have very good picture but not flat like the following HDTVs.  LCD (Liquid Crystal Display) are mostly flat, clear, and for people who want space saving or a cool looking HDTV. They however are not as cost friendly as the the Catho-Ray HDTV, but more cost friendly than the next and most expensive HDTV. The plasma HDTV is probably the best picture you can get with HD. Most are very expensive and they have stunning picture. They are about the same width as LCDs but the screen burns out in about 10 years and you need to replace the screen. The LCD and Catho-Ray work decades after the Plasma will die out. The not as frequently used types of HDTVs are lycos, rear projection, and front projection (they project from inside the TV). They are similar to the CRTs (Catho-Ray Tubes). The least freqently used HDTV is the projector and is projected from a box you buy seperatly from the very flat screen. It is usually about the price of a plasma and are usally about 80" high. It is probably the least clear of the HDTVs.

It uses an inetrface to connect it with others such as devices, control untis, input, output, etc. . .
