they  don't have anything in common. but firewire is faster than USBIts really common to confuse the two.  Trust me, I get calls on this at my job every day!  :). . When a computer needs to "talk" to a peripheral device, like a keyboard or mouse, or even something more complicated like a digital camera, it uses a certain "language" to convey the message.  So think of USB and Firewire as two different languages.  They are so totally different that one can't understand the other.. . The big confusion is apparently because the two are used in somewhat similar situations: connecting things to a computer.  There are a lot of little differences between the two in terms of making one better than the other to use, but they're small things.  Basically, when a company wants to make a peripheral device, say a camera, for instance, they look at the pros and cons of the different connection types and pick one.  Recently, it's most often USB, because more and more PC computers (and Macs, now) have USB already in them.. . If you buy a device that has Firewire on it and you don't have Firewire ports on your computer, things get tricky.  I don't know of any way to convert the two.  Your best bet is to buy a Firewire card and install it into your computer so that you have Firewire ports available.  . . Hope that helps!It's totally two different connection for different use.  Uh... where do I start... Ok, make it simple, fireware is mostly for connection, as connecting a mac to another. USB is more common on connecting assessories to a pc. such, mouse, keyboard, webcam, jumpdrive.....etc.  Hardly use USB for connecting one pc to another. not even sure if that's possible.firewire is generally faster.. im sure its faster than usb 1, but not sure if its faster than usb 2Two different types of connections.. . Many Apple products use FireWire.  However, the trend is tyo USB 2.0 right now.

They are compressed to minimize file size so it's small enough to be copied to portable devices or cell phones with limited memory. Of course there is degradation in sound quality compared to uncompressed (wav) files, but it won't be to much for most application. There other compressed audio files are wma, aac, attrac, etc.. iPod is one of portable media player, a portable device to play (some can also record) multi media files. iPod video and iPod Nano, have color screen to view pics, iPod shuffle don't. There also portable player from Sony, Creative, Sandisk, and many others. If it is feedback, remove any sends from your stereo going to your DVD player. If that doesn't work something is routed wrong on your stereo. If it is an electrical hum, re-route the power so your stereo and DVD are on the same circuit. If that doesn't work make sure no power cords are crossing over any A/V feeds.Use an digital optical cable if you can, it wont transmit the noise.turn down the volume on your dvd player this should helpFirst i need to know where your left and right (red and white rca jacks) are put in to as a audio sourse from the dvd player . aux video cd phono??? its kind of hard to say what it is ,, feed back happens  when ya have a Mic to close to a speaker .. take a picture of the setup ill try to help out more . chris

red blue greenWhat the human eye perceives as a colored point actually consists of three tiny spots, of red, green and blue color respectively, each having a different intensity; the combination of these RGB colored spots define the color and the brightness of the image's point.. If you'll look with a magnifier at any CRT, you'll see all over the RGB spots which, from distance, appear as colored points of the image. . If you want a more detailed answer, please let me know.. Marius

It actually pushes and pulls.. The vibration of the cone, within the enclosure forces air in and out.  Since it does it at a low frequency and high amplitude (loudness), it has a noticable airflow.  All speakers actually do this, but because of the above factors it is more noticeable in a sub-woofer.It's not.  It is just vibrating air at a frequency that allows you to feel it.  Since the subwoofer is in one location it feels like air is moving from that direction.  In reality just the vibrations are moving from that direction.i dont knowit doesn't pushes out air just a lil bit.this causes the vibration to feel it

Protecting the circuitry in a metal box connected to earth is called a Faraday cage:. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_cage. It protects the insides from electromagnetic interference and static, and also prevents the components inside from broadcasting interference (old computers couldn't be placed too close to your TV, because it would give you a static-y picture).  You need to check the ground connection, and make sure that anything else connected to it is not electrically noisy.  Flourescent lights can generate a lot of noise on the ground connection, and this causes your metal box to INCREASE interference rather than protect from it (bad).2 reasons.. prevent electric shock.. sheilds from high frequency noise, so it dooesn't get out.. MIKETo prevent them accumulating a static charge.  . . Static charges lead to static discharges, which can be fatal to some semiconductors.

ipod is a mp3 playeriPod is a brand of portable media player designed and marketed by Apple Computer. Devices in the iPod family provide a simple user interface designed around a central scroll wheel (with the exception of the iPod shuffle). The standard iPod model stores media on a built-in hard drive, while the smaller iPod shuffle and iPod nano use flash memory. Like most digital audio players, an iPod can serve as an external data storage device when connected to a computer.i pod is a kind of play station where you can play music, video etc. its very handy. for details search google by this keyword.
you should have Preouts on the back of you Rec. . . it should say "PRE-out"Just about ever receiver should have at least a stereo output.  Most of the time, it is located near all the other outputs, like the video for the TV.. . If you have a wireless speaker package that is more than just two speakers, you have to hope that your receivers has 5.1 (6.1 or 7.1) pre outputs.  Normally these are used for external amps, but should work in the care of wireless speakers.

The basic idea of solar lanterns is this:  Sunlight shines on photoelectric cells which generate a voltage in sinlight.  This voltage charges rechargeable batteries (Nicad, Lithium) during the day when the sun is out.  When night comes, another type of photoelectric cell senses that there is no more light and switches the solar light on which then runs off the charged batteries.try this you will be amazed. http://computer.howstuffworks.com/

With traditional mechanical watches, the mechansm that provided "power" was a spring as opposed to a battery with modern watches. So, a watch had to be "wound" in order to compress the coil spring inside. As the spring slowly uncoiled, it provided the steady force that moved the gears inside that in-turn moved the hands that told the time.it cleans your floors.... . WHAT DO YOU THINK, it's kinda self explanatory, don't ya think?With traditional mechanical watches, the mechanism that provided "power" was a spring as opposed to a battery with modern watches. So, a watch had to be "wound" in order to compress the coil spring inside. As the spring slowly uncoiled, it provided the steady force that moved the gears inside that in-turn moved the hands that told the time.

to listen you call 123 from your mobile. then to delete the message press 3 anytime during listening to it.you cant sweetheart, just turn it off.....You will need to call your voicemail services and one by one access to your voice messages deleting one by one, in all cases pressing the number 6 will delete the recorded message.If you want to delete a voicemail somebody has left you, follow these instructions..... press 1 and call (this will ring your 3 mail). Then to listen to your messages press 1. Then if thats the one you want to delete press 3 (this will delete it). Or wait til the one comes up, then press 3.. . If you want to manage your greeting message...... Press one and call (this will ring your 3 mail). Then choose option 3. Then follow instructions with regards to removing it. . If you want to change settings of your voicemail. Press one and call (this will ring your 3 mail). Then choose option 4. Then follow instructions with regards to removing it. . Hope this helps xx
A fan doesn't cool anything down.  It actually adds heat to the air.   You'd be far better off just going to someplace more civilized.8 cells is 12Volts. Perfect. Get a 12V trickle charger panel from Maplin for £9.99. Also get a plug and socket pair of connections - the type that mains adaptors have. Fit the socket onto the Fan base and wire it to where the + and - wires connect to inside the fan. If you are clever you do not need to even solder in the fan. During the day the batteries will be recharged by the very sunny weather and you get free air at night!

make sure the cables are on the right connectors cable in to cable in exact and i know it seems obvious but all to often over looked they can be backwards and still get TV till the box tries to update..next try unplugging it for a count of 20 seconds or so make sure to wait.then plug in and do nothing let it cycle thru..if still Nothing take in and plug where the dvr box is see if the other cable or connectors are bad this way.if box still doesn't work the hard drive in box may be bad or it has just been dumped too long if box does work of course then you need to trace cable wires.as well as splitter can be bad or degrade signal to one of the boxes making it also not workthe splitter itself is causing the problem. more than likely you have the splitter connected  at the cable coming from your wall plate, it should be connected from the out to tv port to then each of the tvs. you should have one coaxial cable connected to the out to tv then the splitter and another coaxial cable to each of you tvs.Your connecting cable might not be tight enough. Try to redo and lay the cable out straighter. Might just need to tweek it a bit.if tighting the cable doesn't work- try calling and having your box reset they can do it from the company - it should work. just call and have them reset from thier endwho ran the split ? comcast or yourself . If it was you that could be the problem. basically store bought splitters and cables may not support the Comcast signals . . If it was comcast call them and get a tech out. Call and tell them you want to sit up a trouble call

Whether you are calling from a cell phone or a land line, it's the same thing:  011-52-000-000-0000.  The number "52" is the country code for Mexico, and the rest is the area code and phone number of the place you are calling.  Note - if you are calling a cell phone is Mexico, you have to add a "1" after "52": 011-52-1-000-000-0000.You have to call your Cellphone Carrier and have international calling activated on your phone.  Once that is done just dial the number as it is 0000 0000 0000.  Zeros were used as an example

DON'T RUB IT OFF! when all the toothpaste is gone, some of the scratches will be gone, if you want to remove more, repeat

Diagonally from say, the top right corner to the bottom left or from the top left to the bottom right.... Depending on if you are speaking of an older tv or one of the newer flat screen, high def, plasma or lcd screens, the measurement can be a little off - but you can get an idea of the screen size by the measurment from diagonal corners.... the outside of the tv is a different story.From one corner to the opposing corner.  Since different companies have different cabnet sizes, only the screen is measured to determine its size.In a word:  diagonally.. . When it comes to CRT screens (the "tubes" on old-fashioned TV sets and monitors), there's going to be a discrepancy between the actual size of the screen and the size of the viewable image (which can be as much as about an inch smaller), and some manufacturers will give you one measurement or the other; the good ones will indicate both.
The best way to check is to put a bunch of monochromatic 480x272 px. images on your PSP. I would suggest at least: black, gray, white, red, green, and blue. Check in both the light and a fully dark room.Are you talking about buying a new PSP or a used PSP. If your buying usually their is a return policy that you can return it in a certain amount of days for a new one if something is wrong with it. I would ask the store what their is a return policy is. You can also buy a replacement plan for the PSP. They usually have 1 and 2 year replacement plans. If anything happens to it within the amount of time of your replacement plan, they will replace it for free. It only cost $15-$25 extra, so I would buy it if I were you. If your buying a used one at gamestop or some other video game store that sells used video games and systems, ask to try it before you buy it. Usually you can see like a red dot or something like that on the screen. My friend had a flat monitor and it showed a tiny red dot on his screen, so I would assume it looks similer to that. Many stores that sell used games and system offer a return policy of 7 days. I would ask what theirs is. Hope this helped you.
30x is pretty good for a camcorder, with digital zoom, the closer you zoom the more blurry it will become. It will focus using the optical zoom.An optical zoom uses the camera lenses to zoom in (like a telescope), preserving the quality of the image.  The digital zoom takes part of the picture and stretches it to fit the camera view, losing quality the more you zoom.  Generally, the digital zoom is useless as the image gets too blurry to benefit from the increased range.. . 30x simply means the zoom is thirty times farther than an unaided view.

Dish antenna are used to send and receive signals from communication satellites (i.e. artificial satellite stationed in space for the purposes of telecommunications), it is essential that you place your dish antenna, at such a place that it can view that satellite without any obstruction to which it is supposed to communicate or receive signals. Any obstruction produces degradation in signal strength and so in the quality.. So, in most cases you need to place the antenna in open space, like open fields, rooftops of the buildings, Balconies or windows of the houses if it can see the required satellite from there directly without any obstruction.A dish antennae can be fixed anywhere where it will an un obstructed view of the sky like in roof, balcony, etc. If fixed in closed places like rooms then there can be disturbances in signal.

Dot Matirx was the robot in SpaceballsDot matrix usually pertains to computer printers.. . A dot matrix printer or impact matrix printer refers to a type of computer printer with a print head that runs back and forth on the page and prints by impact, striking an ink-soaked cloth ribbon against the paper, much like a typewriter. Unlike a typewriter or daisy wheel printer, letters are drawn out of a dot matrix, and thus, varied fonts and arbitrary graphics can be produced. Because the printing involves mechanical pressure, these printers can create carbon copies and carbonless copies.. . Typical output from a dot matrix printer operating in non-NLQ mode. The non-enlarged area is approximately 4.5 mm wide in real life.Each dot is produced by a tiny metal rod, also called a "wire" or "pin", which is driven forward by the power of a tiny electromagnet or solenoid, either directly or through small levers (pawls). Facing the ribbon and the paper is a small guide plate (often made of an artificial jewel such as sapphire or garnet) pierced with holes to serve as guides for the pins. The moving portion of the printer is called the print head, and when running the printer as a generic text device generally prints one line of text at a time. Most dot matrix printers have a single vertical line of dot-making equipment on their print heads; others have a few interleaved rows in order to improve dot density.. . These machines can be highly durable, but eventually wear out. Ink invades the guide plate of the print head, causing grit to adhere to it; this grit slowly causes the channels in the guide plate to wear from circles into ovals or slots, providing less and less accurate guidance to the printing wires. Eventually, even with tungsten blocks and titanium pawls, the printing becomes too unclear to read.. . Strictly speaking, "dot matrix" in this context is a misnomer, as nearly all inkjet, thermal, and laser printers produce dot matrices. However, in common parlance these are seldom called "dot matrix" printers, to avoid confusion with dot matrix impact printers.

It's another name for stand-by.. . Instead of completely switching the unit off, the sleep, or standby, mode switches off only some parts of the system leaving others working in the background.. . This saves energy consumption from the battery and speeds up the apparent switch-on.Whenever you power down an iPod, it really doesn't turn off. That's why it comes back on just about instantly. It goes into sleep, which uses little battery. Pushing the sleep button is the same as powering down your iPod by the Play/Pause buttion.go on the apple website

If you want make larger prints or crop your prints you'll need more megapixels.

Digital TV has 2 things that make it better.....More information and NOISE FREE..... . The old signal was ANALOG and only 480 lines of detail for the entire picture....Analog is not On/Off like Digital, it varies it's voltage between 0 Volts and 1.5 Vmax....before it's sent to the transmitter....that is the NTSC standard...The NOISE CREATOR is the Sun mostly....Background radiation of the Universe too... . When your TV signal is STRONGER than that Sun/Universe noise you don't see the NOISE....Now guess what....that tuner INSIDE YOUR TV HAS A MIXER CIRCUIT...That little bugger is NOISY!!! So your SIGNAL has to be STRONGER THAN THE MIXER NOISE or you see speckles...... . With Digital, it doesn't matter....YES there is a MIXER...IT does create NOISE....but the ON /OFF of DIGITAL  makes it TOTALLY OBLIVIOUS OF THE MIXER NOISE....the picture circuit is only looking for ON and OFF....nothing in between....That's what make it NOISE PROOF.....Woo Hoo!!. . Now that you know Digital is NOISE PROOF....let's deal with why your Digital picture looks like CRAP!!!. . Simple....You're looking at 50 years of OLD CRAP LOW DEF-- FILM, VCR TAPE, more Film and more VCR TAPE....IN LOW DEF 480 lines of information...... . You'll never get that converted over to Hi Def 1080 lines of information....you can't take 480 lines and somehow magically get enough information out of it to fill another 600 lines that never existed.....so you look at 480 lines and say to yourself...."God what a crappy picture"..... . Take a look at the old crappy 1920 movies compared to 1945 movies, compared to 1990  movies...Digital TV is not necessarily HD.. . There are several stations that broadcast the NTSC (plain old analog) signal and simulcast an ATSC (digital) signal.  With ATSC there are 18 different formats specified in the standard.  Only program streams with at least 540 lines of resolution are considered "HD".. . In addition to being "digital", the signal can (and normally does) have compression applied to it.  If the TV does a bad job of de-compressing it (or the broadcaster compressed it too much) then it can look blocky or soft.  I've seen a lot of shows being broadcast digitally that look worse than the simulcast NTSC signal.  BUT those shows were not HD...they were "Standard Definition" or SD.Digital TV has to be HD and has to be receiving an HD signal.. . If you have two sets, sitting side by side, with a regular TV and analog signal compared to HD digital TV with HD signal, (and with both TVs showing the same program) you will see a difference.. . I personally do not think it is worth thousands to watch HD when my 19" Panasonic has had an excellent picture for ten years.

OR.  you can grab a Bluetooth HUB that attaches to your computer via USB
When you're listening to a CD, the player must physically spin a disc in order to obtain the required data to produce music.  When listening to radio, the player simply intercepts and decodes specific frequencies of the radio waves in the air all around you.  Since there is no physical movement associated with radio, there will be less battery power consumed.To play the CD takes extra power because a motor is needed to spin the CD around at high speed while playing.  Also, the CD player needs to run a low power laser to illuminate the CD pits while it spins.  Neither the motor nor the laser need to be on for radio use.The cd requires battery for its movements in addition to the other function which r virutally same as while using the fm radio.I don't know...It seems like it should be the other way around :/

well you can have digtal stereo stereo means 2 speakers your digtail receivers can decode 5.1 6.1 7.1 thx dts dolby pro dolby pro 2 they are formats that send audio to differnt speakers depending on how they depended on how they sound, george lucas hated how theaters sounded like in the seventies he had specs that he like to reproduce the sound his way and now we have thx  and star wars would never be the same in stereo onlyDigital is the breaking down of sound into binary information (0s and 1s). This is opposed to analog, which is a physical imprint of sound, like a record groove.. . Stereo is a type of sound-reproduction that produces two sound channels (usually left and right). Stereo is short for stereophonic. There is also monophonic, which is one sound channel, and quadrophonic, which is four sound channels.Mono means one channel (or one speaker). Stereo means two channels (or two speakers with different sound coming from each). . Digital has nothing to do with stereo... Digital means that the information is stored in digital form, as opposed to analogue... An old black LP record is analogue, a CD is digital... Digital sound can be Mono (one channel), Stereo (two channels) or multichannel (2.1=3 channels, 5.1=6 channels, 6.1=7 channels, 7.1=8 channels or more)no difference between the two. stereo sound is made from two or more speakers and digital data is data in electronic form for example a cd is in digital form.Digital is the type of format -i.e. by using 1's and 0's.. . Stereo is the discreet channel seperation of the right and the left.(Dolby, Optical, etc) Digital vs. Analog (Stereo). . Biggest difference is the price... however, I don't think that's what you intended... storage medium for digital has already been picked apart.. . Stereo is as optimal a soundstage as you'll be able to reproduce when listening to music.  Face it music was mixed by a technition in a studio, with a mixing console, and panning fader deciding which side the bass guitar should be on, placement of vocals to the center of the stage, and the location of all the instruments within that stereo stage.. . With the left and right channel played through a turn table, coupled to a preamp, through the EQ, fired to the amplifier, and out to the staged speakers is going give most audiophiles a good run for their money.  Taking into consideration, they likely just dished out $20k + for their gear.  Not to mention the phase aligning power cleaners, balanced cables, and cost to replace tubes... and the days upon days spent reorganizing their space for acoustic perfection.. . Digitial on the flip side, is somewhat of a loaded word.  This has been established above, and can be applied to just about anything to do with electronics.  However, it could be stated that the staging effects of digital in comparison to a good 2 channel stage, directly opposed to using rear fill satellites with a full left, right, center, and the mono sub channel, just creates a mess when you're applying room acoustics to the ambient demands of music reproduction.  Digital in this display gets the crap kicked out of it over stereo for ambient staging reproduction simplicity for an average system. However, for home theatre full room ambience, a good staged multi-channel arrangment runs circles around stereo.. . Stereo in this respect can reproduce music wonderfully and accurately, while still producing a modest mind blowing theatre experience with a powerful enough system.  Whereas, Digital systems tend to rely on the fill effects in relation to their small size to create the same ambience produced by the Stereo speakers.  The problem with this, rear fill just doesn't work well hwen playing music.  Nobody stands backwards at a rock concert, this is also a common problem with car audio, when people overdrive the rear fills, it dissrupts the front channels ability to create a proper stage.  The result is something that sounds unnatural. . . With that said, digital on it's own can't survive with analog, but analog can survive without digital.  Besides, there is no such thing as a true digital amplifier, as even the Class D (commonly mislabelled) is still using a majority of it's circuitry based on analog designs.  Though, Digital Effects Processors are capable of splitting, resampling, and converting an analog source to digital, it still has to pass through a DAC (Digital to Analog Converter) so it can be sent to the analog speakers.. . Mixing the two... Digital reproduction is considered even by hardened audiophiles over analog, as a source, to be capable of cleanly reproducing music in ways analog could only dream of.  Mainly, you don't have the elevated tape hiss, the pops and scratches of vinyl, and the annoyance of 8-track splitting the mix half-way through your favourite song.  But!!! The analog recordings are as true tonally to the original as any medium can get, and unfortunately digital recordings fail in comparison.  They are also considered tonally harsher because the sound signal has to be converted from a square and reinterpolated back to an analog wave.  During this conversion, information is either lost, or open to interpretation.  Hence the problems with bitrates, the heated arguments over OGG, MP4, WMA, etc... . . There's still problems with this, as the benefits that analog sources provide over digital are truthfully wasted on the average person.  Most speaker systems, amplifiers, and crap we call stereo systems today in our make it smaller, make it cheaper society,  ju

If you just hold down the zoom button, it will probably pause for a second at the end of the optical zoom range and then proceed silently into digital zoom.  DON'T USE DIGITAL ZOOM THOUGH, because it really degrades the image quality.  You can do a much better job of "zooming" in by cropping the image on your computer or at the photo kiosk.Most cameras have both, and you probably have an option for using digital zoom or not - I would suggest not using digital zoom since it only makes the pixels bigger without actually magnifying the picture itself (which you can actually do with software anyway) - optical zooms, on the other hand, actually magnify the image without changing pixels...There's a button for zooming either way.  Push it towards plus and it zooms in.  The other way to zoom back out.  It eats up a lot of battery power, though, so use it only when you need to, and don't bother with digital zoom, as it's just in-camera cropping anyway.

The predecessor to the touch tone (DTMF) dial was the rotary dial. The rotary dial is a wheel with holes next to each number and operates on electrical pulses to signal the central office instead of tones like the DTMF dial does. The digit 1 is one pulse and the digit 9 is nine pulses. The digit 0 is ten pulses. Since the rotary dial uses a spring to recoil the dial, the digits had to be sequential and the digit 1 had to be first with the digit 0 being last (least number of pulses to most number of pulses). When the DTMF or touch tone dial was introduced in the 1960's, they maintained the same sequence so as to not confuse people and have numerous wrong numbers dialled. . . The Touch Tone system also introduced a standardized keypad layout. After testing 18 different layouts, they eventually chose the one familiar to us today, with 1 in the upper-left and 0 at the bottom. The adding-machine layout, with 1 in the lower-left was also tried, but at that time few people used adding machines, and having the 1 at the "start" (in European language reading order) led to fewer typing errors. In retrospect, many people consider that this was a mistake. With the widespread introduction of computers and bank machines, the phone keyboard has become "oddball", causing mistakes.. . http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/dtmf...Phones were set up the way they are, because on the old rotaries, the numbers started at the left top.  They tried to stay with that system.. With calculators, which were set up before the phones, the idea was to have to have the farthest reach for the high numbers.  That way if you mistouched something at the starting point, you were in the smallest numbers
You have to get an RF Modulator. I had to do that same thing. I bought one at Radio Shack.do you have those old t.v.'s? well i had the same problem. at radioshack or whatever its called now, you need to get an adapter. i don't remember what the item is called but the staff should know. it is simple to plug in and use, just turn the dial to 3 or whatever your auxillary channel is. hope you find it.get a anolog imput or converter at a store like best buy.You have to go to the store and get an adapter to hook them together, just ask the electronics dept.You need an RF modulator from a store like Radioshack.The easiest way to do it is to utilize an RF Modulator.  They are available from $10 - $30 depending on how many items you think you may need it for.  The purpose of the device is to convert Audio/Video outputs (yellow, white, and red cables) to a coaxial connection on older televisions.  Basically all you do is connect the cables from your DVD player into this device and then run a coax cable from it into your television, then put your TV on CH 3 to watch a DVD movie.  . . Some people get confused by these because they already have a cable going to the coaxial jack on the back of the TV.  Not to worry.  The RF modulator will have an input for that connection as well.  So you will connect your DVD player with the Audio/Video Cables, then connect your Cable Box (or VCR or Satellite or whatever else was connected to that jack originally) to the coaxial input on the RF modulator.  Then you will have one cable going from the RF modulator to the TV.  When you want to watch a DVD turn the TV on to channel 3, and hit play.  When not watching a movie you just turn off the DVD player.. . I hope this helped.

Optical zoom is "real" zoom and digital zoom sucks.  Just totally ignore digital zoom and choose based on optical zoom.Digital zoom is done artificially by the CPU - it is interpolated data from the existing picture (in most cases you are better off not using any digital zoom at all and doing the "digital zooming" on the computer - it will often be of a higher quality that what s small digi-cam can do.. . optical zoom is done by optics and it is the real thing.. . enjoyoptical zoom is the true zoom from the lens. More that 3x you will need a image stabilizer system (like 12x) in order to avoid the blurr.. . Digital zoom is  ... a scam.Digital zoom is done artificially by the CPU - it is  data from the existing picture (in most cases you are better off not using any digital zoom at all and doing the "digital zooming" on the computer - it will often be of a higher quality that what s small digi-cam can do. Optical Zoom is done with the lens. Very high quality doing it with the lens. Four to eight times is about normal with the lens. ( 35 to 200 MM )The way optical and digital zooms work are quite different from each other.. . An optical zoom works by using the physical legs to magnify the image coming into the camera. This is how film cameras, telescopes and microscopes work.. . A digital zoom works by taking the center of the image (cropping) and enlarging it to look as if you have actually zoomed in. Digital zoom does not provide any more detail as only a fraction of the CCD inside the camera is now been used to record the photo, the rest of the image is been thrown away thanks to the digital zoom.. . In reality digital zoom is of no use at all. If you want to 'zoom in'  a little more you are better off taking the photo without any digital zoom and then editing the larger photo using your computer.. . I recommend a three times optical zoom and don't worry what digital zoom a camera has as you should never use it.. . I recommend reading the information on this site, it is a great guild to the facts on digital cameras:. http://www.steves-digicams.com/best_cameras.htmlOptical is the actual "Zooming" of the lens it moves the lens in and out, which the bigger that number the better digital is just just the sensor in the camera "Zooming." You should have about 4x Optical and about 8x Digital.OPTICAL zoom works using LIGHT.. All lenses, in both FILM and DIGITAL, mark out the boundaries of the subject area and hence the area from where light will be received. (50 mm is generally taken as "what the eye sees"; zoom lenses reduces the subject area that is "visible" but as it fills the same size of "screen", the subject looks BIGGER).. >>>> After the light is "inside" the digital camera then it gets pixellated on the digital light sensor.  At this point, the light sensor technology is 100% representative of the light that has been received.. >>>> DIGITAL ZOOM is the feature that "tries" to make a part of the captured image bigger.  It can only do this by making the pixells bigger.  The bigger the pixells, the fuzzier the image becomes.  Mind you, there are some clever algorithms that try and "fill in" new pixells, but these new pixells are not "original" pixells and are generated based on the "neighboring pixells".  So short answer, digital zooming is not really beneficial with the prosumer cameras and software, but maybe works for satellite technology (best to confirm that with NASA!).  . >>>> OPTICAL ZOOM preferred size?  As big as you can afford and pick the good lens companies like Canon, Tamron, Sigma, Nikon etc.. >>>> DIGITAL ZOOM preferred number? Maybe in PHOTOSHOP (or similar digital image processing software) you might get away with a factor of 2 or 3, again though it depends on the pixell density of your original image and the output medium.. John Mc

A real Rolex will have hands that roll, while a fake one will have hands that tick.Genuine Rolex,s come with certificates and leather boxes .Also check that the serial numbers match ,you will find them on back of the watch and on the bracelet ,you can also check if they have been stolen .Rolex dealers will  do this for you..the real ones are very heavy, about 200 grams, you can just feeel the differenceGenuine Rolex watches have very smooth movements of the seconds hand. If you observe closely on the ticking of the seconds hand, it should be very smooth, almost like analog watches.. . Whereas for fake Rolex watches  or any fake watches, the ticking of the second hand is not that smooth, its almost like its taking steps. Do note that nowadays, fake watches have improved to the point that this observation is no longer valid (the wonders of piracy).. . You have to put both genuine and fake side by side to really see the difference, just remembre to tagged the geniune watch first!..

Yeah what the first guy said. Cellphone I guess is the original name, and mobile means convenient, as in carry with you like mobile homes, mobile scooter, etc...I think "cell phone" is a regional term, used in the USA.  "Mobile phone" is what people use in Europe.  They are the same thing.  There are lots of fun region-specific terms.  Like, all soft drinks in and around Atlanta, GA are known as "coke", and I have heard people order "orange coke" in restaurants.  Why?  Because Coke headquarters is located in Atlanta, GA.Mobile phone are connect to a cellular network of base stations (cell sites) so its called Cell phone.. . Wireless telephone that permits telecommunication within a defined area that may include hundreds of square miles, using radio waves in the 800–900 megahertz (MHz) band.. . "To implement a cell-phone system, a geographic area is broken into smaller areas, or cells(thats why cellular/cell phone), usually mapped as uniform hexagrams but in fact overlapping and irregularly shaped. ". . Each cell is equipped with a low-powered radio transmitter and receiver that permit propagation of signals among cell-phone users.Mobile phones are using antenna's which covering area are called cells. Move from cell to cell to pick up signal.Area where network service to be provide is divided into small areas which is called as a cell. Each cell contain one tower which provides signals. When user move from one cell to another he automatically shifted to his nearest tower and his mobile remain active continuously until cell exist.Mobile communication works between the handset and the BTS (Base transreceiver station) which you commonly called tower. Now the towers a re-arranged in such a way that the communication range of a tower intersects with another leaving no space in between and the fields take the structure of a honey bee "cells". and a tower stands at the center of each cell. Try searching for cellular network and get your diagrams from google image search. :-)The cell phone has derived its name from "Cellular Telephone.". . More information can be accessed from wikipedia:. . A mobile or cellular telephone is a long-range, portable electronic device for personal telecommunications over long distances.. . Most current mobile phones connect to a cellular network of base stations (cell sites), which is in turn interconnected to the public switched telephone network (PSTN) (the exception are satellite phones).

bluetooth is the technique to transfer the data to one device to another. this technique is popularly used in mobile phones. in this technique u dont require any type of connector. it is done with the rays.Bluetooth is a connection technology that allows small devices to communicate with each other without use of cables, wirelessly. Such as from your cell phone to your headset. It can also be used to link your phone to your PC (if your PC has bluetooth built in or you have a bluetooth dongle) or your headset to your PC.... or between two bluetooth devices.... two phones, PDAs or phone and PDA when you need to transfer files and other information such as SMS or eCards. There is no limit to its use.... if you have a need for it's service. You can even transfer music from one phone to another.It's either something that happens from not brushing often enough or a device that has something to do with a cell phone that makes people look absolutey ridiculous.. . OK, so it's what those guys down there said. Go figure.Bluetooth is an industrial specification for wireless personal area networks (PANs). Bluetooth provides a way to connect and exchange information between devices such as mobile phones, laptops, PCs, printers, digital cameras and video game consoles via a secure, globally unlicensed short-range radio frequency.

plug in the cord that comes with it and it transfers music onto the psp. just look in the manual.First you need to purchase and install a program that can convert the files properly so that they can be played on the PSP. If you don't convert them they won't work. The program I use is called Max Media Manager and you can buy that in any game/electronic store. Or you can also download a program off the internet called PSP Video 9, that also converts files to be played on your PSP. Once you have one of these programs use your USB cable to connect the PSP to the computer and then open the program and add the files and songs from Windows Media Player. They will automatically load into your PSP already converted and ready to play.First plug in your PSP with a USB cable. Then turn on your PSP, go to settings, and there it should say "USB CONNECTION". Click on that and your PSP should connect to your computer. Then, on your computer, go to Windows Explorer. Go to all the drives (C - Local Disk, D - CD Drive, etc.), and it should say "PSP" on one of the drives. Open up that drive, then there should be a folder called "PSP". Open up that folder and there should be a folder called "MUSIC". Put all of your music into that folder (drag and drop). Make sure all of your music files are either MP3, WMA, or WAV.. . Good Luck!

Ask a merchant of projector screens.  . They will give you the best advice.. . H a p p y. H o m e. T h e a t e r i n g !In general the conventional guidance is to use a white screen for a high contrast projector and a grey "high contrast" screen for "contrast challenged" projectors.. . But let's look at the situation a little closer. The NEC HT410 is an inexpensive projector with OK, but not earthshaking specs (See link).  The key one is contrast ratio (1200:1). This is marginal for good picture quality (2000:1 or better is considered adequate and 5000:1 or better is preferable) and therefore anything that a screen can do to help would be desirable. The logical screen choice is therefore a light grey screen rather than white.. . However, you might consider that a reasonable quality screen will cost at least $3-400, so given the inexpensive projector unless you require portability it might be preferable to consider a DIY screen.. . The AVS Forum on DIY screens (see link) provides all sorts of advice, but in brief I did a screen on a blank wall in my home theatre using 3 coats of a light grey paint mix (based on Behr paint from Home Depot) for a total cost of about $40. And when I compared it to commercial screen material for $1000 screens I basically couldn't tell the difference .... and I have a $5000 projector. . . If you really want a screen the article at the third link may provide information to help you decide.. . Hope that helps.I would recommend one of these, they will give you a great crisp bright picture and are a very good price.. . http://www.mogiz.com/Pages/Browse.aspx?CategoryID=65To tell you the truth, I would not worry about the screen you buy.  Just get one that is as large as you want your picture to be.  The bulk of picture quality will be determined by the resolution of the DVD and projector.  As a matter of fact, if you have a blank white wall in your home you can project on to that.  . . If your are really concerned about your projecting surface, a smoother surface will generally look better than a textured one.  i.e. a bed sheet vs a white screen.. . Hope this helps- have fun!

The only reason I can think of is that you have an older pc with no dvd drive. Why not buy a new pc or laptop (new ones with cd/dvd rewriters can be bought for £300).The best way i can see of doing it is by using a piece of software called magic dvd ripper (its free to download just google it).  This ripps information from dvd, converts it into a different format such as mpeg4 so it can be viewed on a psp or ipod video, or avi so it can be viewed by windows media player, and saves it onto your computers hard drive.  You can then burn it onto a cd using something like sonic cd record now!.  If you do this, it can only be viewed on another PC (or psp/video ipod) NOT on a dvd player.  Just make sure that the files you burn onto cd are no larger than 700mb.if you have a cd burner, then just connect the left and right audio out from the dvd player to the left and right audio in on the cd burner, and press record. Bluetooth is a ear piece that is used with a  cellular phone It is like a hands free device to talk on your cell phone. It is wireless.  You ever seen someone with a weird looking device on their ear and has no connection to it? you wear it kinda like a hearing aid.It's a 2-way wireless communication protocol, that allows different gadgets to talk to each other - over a short distance.. . It was developed in Sweden, and named after a Scandinavian king who unifiied previously warring Scandinavian tribes.A bluetooth is a gaget that u put on ur ear like an ear peice but its cordless and u use it on ur cell phone. but it doesnt work on all cell phones. u must check to see if urs can use it. its great when ur drivin and it starts ringing u push a button to answer and when ur done u push the same button. also it comes with voice command so like when u want to call someone u dont have to look through ur phone u just say who u want to call.. hope i help u answe ur question.i *think* it is for like. a wireless earphone thing for like cell phones and such. im not positive though. you could always try googling Bluetooth and see what comes up :) Good luck!a blue tooth is a device you put in your ear so when your cell phone rings and your driving you don't have to pick it up. the blue tooth automatically answer es it for you. but if they like to talk alot on their cell  phones i suggest you don't get them oneBlue Tooth is a wireless interface system that. connects a cell phone with your vehicle radio . speakers.. When electricity is passed through a coil of wire some energy is converted to magnetism.. . in a speaker this is used along side a fixed magnet to make the vibrations that cause sound waves.. . A microphone does the same in reverse (basically)Speakers (including those in your earphones) are controlled by magnets.  The magnet pulls and releases the speaker cone, generating the sound that you hear.Because the electric signal passes through a coil of wire which is in the magenetic field, this causes it to oscillate back and forth driving a diapraghm which produces sound waves. No magnet, no sound.Speakers use electro magnets to drive the cones to cause the required vibration for sound.Are they? I'm goona try that when i get home! I do know that if you stick them in your mic socket you can sing into them like a microphone!B/c a speaker works with a magnet. The magnet pulls on the electric current and the speaker cone, thus producing the sound you hear.

nee-kon in asia. nye-kon in english speaking countriesIn the 60's, "we" used to call it "NEE-kon" the same way a select few pronouce the car name "POR-shuh."  Before too long, everyone who knew just gave up, so we say it "Nye-kon" now so people will know what the heck we are talking about.The name Nikon, which dates from 1946, is a merging of Nippon K?gaku (????: "Japan Optical") and an imitation of Zeiss Ikon. Nikon is pronounced in two syllables like the English words “knee cone”.correct is nee-kon

try wikipedia, google or ask.comVery basically, an antenna in the unit picks up the magnetic waves and filters the signals then displays the strength.The RD4000 has 3 different modes it operates in, Power - looks for the 50/60hz range emitted from mains wires. Generator - is adjustable to look for the frequency of the generator connected to the wires being located. Radio - looks for higher frequencies that may be emitted by wires or pipes.. . The RD4000 is available in different models that have more functions depending on how much you want to pay for it

Bluetooth  is a technology providing wireless personal area networks (WPANs) for small devices as cellphones or PDAs. It operates on the unlicensed 2.4-GHz industrial-scientific-medical (ISM) band, and has essentially been established by Ericsson. The Bluetooth Special Interest Group (SIG) was then founded with its original promoters being Nokia, IBM, Intel, and Toshiba. Today, approximately 2000 members are counted, amongst them Agere, 3Com, Lucent, and Microsoft.. . The complementary of Bluetooth is the Infrared device of the Infrared Data Association (IrDA). During the last few months, it has been argued that Bluetooth has been created as a substitute for Infrared. Though, this is not quite true: Bluetooth has been invented as an enhancement of Infrared, especially in terms of low cost, small volume, low power, and the accomplishment of Infrared's limitations, such as the its unidirectional connections, the connectivity range of only meter or its limitation to point-to-point connections. Although Bluetooth has actually coped with these constraints, e.g. by omnidirectional connections, the connectivity range of up to 10 meters, or its capability for point-to-multipoint connections, the two technologies are quite complementary. While Bluetooth is very applicative for networking, Infrared is more appropriate for the direct connections, e.g. for exchanging business cards.Bluetooth is a radio signal, and non-directional. Infrared is a light-wave communication and is limited to line of sight. Even a piece of paper between the transmitter and receiver will disrupt communications. . Bluetooth also has a few different specs which allow for range from a few feet to a few tens of feet. Bluetooth is also quite a bit faster than infrared.. Bluetooth is definitely more versatile.bluetooth is powerful and infrared is less powerful. well the thing that seprates BLUETOOTH and INFRARED is the speed and connectivityi believe infrared needs to be aligned, but bluetooth just needs to be in proximity of source. if  that makes any sence at all.
Your iPod will not show up a "Removable Disc" but instead as whatever your iPod is called. Make sure that in iTunes, edit>preferences>iPod>Music "enable disk-use" is checked.when you hook up your ipod into your computer, in itunes it allows you to change ipod settings in the edit > ipod settings part of the toolbar. on the settings screen you have to look for a little box that you can check off that is labeled "enable disk use", meaning that you are allowing your computer to view your ipod as pretty much a portable external hard drive (aka a portable memory place to store stuff like files from your computer).. . after that is enabled, you should be able to access it in your "My Computer" and save your word files that way. it should work just liek a removable hard drive.
the nano is under 10gb in size? then all you do,is format nano,  move all your pc music to a file, then in itunes select: ''add file to library'' add the music,. then itunes will say: '' not enough space in library, do you want itunes to select a random music selection to add'' . then it will put a totally random selection on to iPod nano!You could create a Smart Playlist, do this in iTunes by going to File/New Smart Playlist.. . Leave Match the following rule ticked. . In the first drop down pick "Last Played", then "is not in the last", then "14", then "days". That will pick any tracks you haven't listened to in iTunes or your Nano in the last two weeks.. . Now, Limit then the size of your Nano, either 1,2,4,8 then "GB", and finally, selected by "random". This will restrict the playlist to the exact size of your Nano (make it smaller if you use it as a drive to store documents on). . I always tick Match only checked items because I untick tracks like Christmas songs because they aren't appropriate.. . Then tick Live updating, this should make sure it picks any new music straight away and that definitely will not have been played in the last two weeks.. . Now click OK and give it a decent name like Nano Bites.. . Next time you connect your Nano, click on the Nano and pick synchronise selected playlists only, then pick Nano Bites.. . NO you need some solder you can buy it at any home fix it center . 1. put wire in place. 2.get soldering tool hot . 3. when hot, touch solder to wire and apply heat. 4 when hard solder meets heat it becomes a liquid so be careful and use only a littleThere should be a positive and negitive wire that need to be seperate.  Place solder gun on the wire , let it heat up and than place a small amount of solder on the hot wire , remove heat and let harden, repeat on other wire , making sure not to reheat first wire. Tape the solder joints after the are cooled to prevent them from grounding out.you need to use solder and sometimes flux is required to make the solder stick.You have to have solder from the hardware store to perform this

I ringtone is something that YOU can hear when somebody calls you. A ringback is when somebody calls you, and they can hear music while they wait for you to answer!a ringback is something other people hear when they call you, a ringtone is something you hear when someone calls you.Ring tone Is The Tone Which You Hear When Someone Calls You,. Ring back or Greet Tune is a tone which you can set in place of a boring dial tone, when someone call your cell number, this can be in the form of a specially recorded message by you or a one of your favorite songs.Ringtone- the tune you hear on your phone when someone is calling you. . Ringback- The tune the person on the other line is hearing while they are waiting for you to pick up the phone.

They call the FM radio controll agency and they tell them wich ones are available and then the radio station just chooses between one of those but if its one radiostation going to buy out another they will probaly just keep the same frequencyThey are assigned by the FCC.In the U.S. they are assigned by the FCC after a radio engineer performs a radio frequency site survey to determine what other transmitters are operating in the area. This is done to minimize the possibility of interference between the new transmitter and existing ones.. . WK

L     E          Dlight emitting diodes...they are little lights that can be brighter than normal lights...Light Emitting Diodes. Just like common diodes,they are polarity sensitive.LED stands for Light Emmiting Diode. An LED is different from a regular light bulb due to how it produces light. In an atom, there are orbitals, which are where particles of the atom reside. Sometimes they jump, and then photons are released. An LED lights by forcing the particles to jump.Light Emitting Diode.. . They're the small lights that are used in things like scoreboards and Christmas lights.light emitting diode.  i think.Light emitting diodes.......................................

Bluetooth technology allows phones to connect wirelessly with other electronics. . . The most practical use for bluetooth  would be a headset that hooks up to your ear while your phone remains in your pocket.bluetooth in "mobiles" is a wireless technology that allows interaction between two (or more) mobile phones with an existing bluetooth device.. . by interaction, i mean bluetooth allows one to transfer files like pictures, music, documents, contacts e.t.c from a mobile to another. however, some people have the habit of leaving their (phone's) bluetooth on. this kills the battery of the phone faster than usual. it also puts the phone in danger of getting a virus (speaking of virus, the 3230 of my brother's girlfriend got corrupted as well as the memory card). now why i'm saying this is because once ur phone gets corrupt, u're likely to lose everything on ur phone (and memory card).. . all in all though, the bluetooth is a good thing, cheers.

because air contains water and generally warm air contains more water so as the air is cooled by the refrigeation unit inside the airconditioner a bit of water/condensation develops in the box and it drains away onto the floor.. The principle is similar when you put cold coke in a glass and let it sit on the bench some condensation comes on the outside of the glass on its own.When an air conditioner cools air, the air's capacity for holding moisture is diminished.  This excess water has to go somewhere, so it drips out of the unit.  This is similar to what happens when a cold glass forms condensation on the outside, and water runs down the side.That is the moister that is in the air that is in your home, . . PeaceThe condensate.It called condensation.  When the warm air (or at least warmer than you like) passes of the evaporator coil of the air conditioner it condensates.. . This is much like a cold glass of soda or tea sweating on warm day.  . . The circulated air dehumidifies and condensates as it passes thought the unit.  The cool, dry air is passed into the room and the condensation (water) is disposed of via drain line or the back of your a/c unit.because its cold and the machine sweats and the cold air freeze but avopperate in the warm air around the tube thus the waterIts all like dew in the air accumaliting and forming over it and then flowing as watersimple. just like fridge, it produces water. but it doesn't actually freezes it, instead it comes out.i dont know and thx for the 2 points

The quality of the output of digital camara is determined by its megapixels(it should be notified on your camara). The higher the pixels better the quality, at the same time lens also play the vital part in it's output, for developing at photo-lab or printer  try adjusting your resulation upto the highest. If you just want for email or website - adjust lower resulation.. . Alternatively, photos you took on high resulation can be cut, trim and manipulate to your need by the photo software that came with your camera. But photos taken on low resulation(email and website) aren't good enough for printing. That's why it's always good idea to take photos to camara's full resulation and manipulate to your need later on.. . Digital camaras use memory cards instead of films, so whatever you take are stored on memory cards. You simply take that card to photolab to print. The number of photos and videos(didital camaras are also equipped with video capturing function) can store is determine by the capacity of memory card. The common ones now a days are 512mb, 1gb and 2gb.. . Digital camaras come with LCD pannel where you can see your photos before and after you take. If you aren't happy with your photo simply delete it and re-take until you are satisfied. . . Turning off LCD and taking photo through view finder saves battery. . . I hope this is enough to play around with your new digital camara for the moment. sometimes the TV has to be set on channel 3 or 4 and the VCR set to the correct channel. If only the TV is on the right channel, the VCR will not pick it up. . . Don't jump into buying a new VCR. It sounds like you're just missing one of the steps.. . oh, and make sure the cable hook-up is tight on the "in" port on the VCRMake sure the record setting was on, and if that doesn't work, try another video. If neither of those work, either contact the manufacturer or buy a new vcr, although if you want the new thing, try getting one of those dvd things that will also record. They'll last longer because they're newer.Check owners manual and follow direction written in the manual.  For timer recording, VCR must be turned off.Televisions made in the past few years have been removing their Video Out.  My suggestion, find a VCR that allows you plug your cable into it, and then connect the VCR (video out) to the TV (video in) using an RCA cable.  If you have an HDTV, the setup is different.. . Most likely, the close caption feature is not built into your TV, since the law went into effect in 1998 that required all TVs to support close captions.  However, you can still view close captions on your TV by adding an external decoder.you should have a CC button on your remote. Most TVs closed captions only accessable with the remote. Bluetooth is an industrial specification for wireless personal area networks (PANs), also known as IEEE 802.15.1. Bluetooth provides a way to connect and exchange information between devices such as personal digital assistants (PDAs), mobile phones, laptops, PCs, printers, digital cameras and video game consoles via a secure, globally unlicensed short-range radio frequency.it is a wireless handset for your phone. you use it so youi dont have to hold anything while your talking on the phone. it is mostly used to driving and other things. it clips to your earBluetooth is a program that you can use to transfer files. For example if you want a ringtone from your friends cell phone and you both have bluetooth you can use that to get a copy of your friends ringtone. Or if there is a photo on your cell phone you want to use for something like your myspace you can use bluetooth to transfer the photo from your cell phone to your computer.It is wireless communication secured by a handshake signal from the receiver and transmitter.   Bluetooth is used in wireless headsets for cellphones.     . . It is used in other wireless devices as well.  It won't be long until some of the game systems are using it for their controllers instead of radio or other signals.a wireless hand set that look like you are talking to your selfIt's an expensive wireless headsets for cell phones.

RFID stands for Radio Frequency IDentification. A powered RFID has its own power or is powered by whatever its in (something like a car remote). a non-powered RFID gets its power from an outside RF, usually the device thats scanning the RFID (that microchip between your dogs shoulders that gives the vet a number to look up in the master data base for dog catchers so they can contact the original owners).Active tags have a battery on the tag. The battery may be used to boost read/write range, allow for larger memories, or add sensory and data logging capabilities, such as temperature sensing. Passive tags receive all of their energy from the read/write device that "powers" the tag to allow it to transmit data.

Professional pest control is the best answer, inspection is the key to elimination. i would not like to suggest a chemical to kill them because you might have a bad reaction to it..... Wait 3 days to see if it will dry.  If it still doesnt work, bring it to a repair shop and see if they can do anything. If not, then use your warranty and get a new one.By replacing it with a new one.. . Of course if that isn't an option, I hope that you did not turn it on immediately. If you did turn it on right after pulling it from the water, more than likely you have shorted out most of the circuitry and it is toast.  Time for a new one.
It means that there . is an amplifier on-board.  . Or, that it has it's own amplifier.Amplification is simply the reproduction and strengthening an electronic signal.  In a sound system, for example, a signal is introduced through an input "transducer" (a transducer is anything that changes one form of energy into another) such as a microphone, that turns sound waves into electronic equivalent.. . That signal is then processed and fed to the amplifier.  Here the amplifier significantly increases the signal strength before reaching the loudspeakers, which are the output transducers.. . Short answer?  Amplified means made stronger.

Ni-Cad batteries have a memory, so recharging them when they are not fully discharged will shorten their life.. . Lithium-ion batteries are just fine to plug in no matter what the charge is.. . No matter what, all batteries will lose their ability to keep a charge over time.Not if it uses a lithium battery.  (Supposedly)Charging your battery when not needed will shorten its overall lifespan.  Regardless of it being lithium, Ni-cad or ceramic.  The effect is less on Lithium and ceramic, however overall it will reduce the life.. . Suggestion, recharge only when less than 1/3 indicated life is displayed and you will maximize the life of your battery.

If you have a Double-Layer (DL) capable DVD-writer you can burn up to 8GB per DVD. You will need DL DVDs as well, and they cost MUCH more money than the "standard" DVD+/-Rs. The recording speed is lower than the normal.. . Other way to do it is to try the "overburning" option found in some burning software (e.g. nero, etc.) but it is not recommended.. . If you're trying to record some video file(s), try reducing the quality a bit to "shrink" the file to 4.5 GB that will fit on 1 DVD.. If you're writing data files, try to "compress" them with some archiver program (rar, zip, 7zip, even windows built-in zipping).. . Awesome Question!  The resistor (heat-maker) is actually imbedded in a ceramic insulator.  Which is why, when you turn the stove burner on, it doesn't get hot immediately.  In conclusion, the ceramic does not allow the electricity to reach your pan.. only the heat.There is a ceramic insulator covering the electric heating element

no they don't have battery memory.  you can charge them even if they are only half drained.Different battery chemistries each have their own 'quirks'.  The memory effect is a quirk of Ni-Cd batteries only. . . Li-Ion batteries don't have this quirk. When not in use for extended periods, however, Li-Ion, like Ni-Cd, lies to be stored discharged. Lead-Acid batteries are the reverse of this, and like to be stored charged all the time.

the pros are:Plasma’s greatest strength is flexibility of use. You can put them almost anywhere as proven by the now-famous Philips ad where a young couple installs a plasma on the ceiling above their bed after a long battle to figure out which wall was best for their slick new TV. . . the cons are:Plasma is not a perfect technology, and its weaknesses should be taken into account when deciding on a display. Plasma screens are fragile. They must be shipped standing up, and as they are mostly glass, they must be handled with extreme care. They are heavy, and the wall mounts must be properly set. They should never be installed where they could be knocked over or bumped into.Plasma sets are power hungry because of the high voltages necessary to activate the actual plasma elements. The picture quality degrades with time due to phosphor wear, much as a traditional CRT TV set does. Also, the glass face reflects light in the room, somewhat degrading the image, as compared to the other flat panel technology, LCDIve heard LCD TVs are better compared to the Plasma, but then ive been told at a john lewis store in london that the plasma is better? however saying that, he did say the plasma tvs have a life expectancy.. im thinking of buying a HDTV but it'll probably be an LCD one!PROS- 1. Larger screen size availability. .               2. Better contrast ratio and ability to render deeper blacks. .               3. Better color accuracy and saturation. .               4. Better motion tracking (little or no motion lag in fast  .                    moving images). .                . CONS- 1. Plasma TVs are more susceptible to burn-in of static .                   images. .               2. Plasma TVs generate more heat than LCDs, due to .                   the need to light of phosphors to create the images. .               3. Does not perform as well at higher altitudes. .               4. Shorter display life span (about 30,000 hours or 8 hrs.                   of viewing a day for 9 years) than LCD. This can vary  .                   according to other environmental and use factors.
it's the mirrors.. . . http://www.dlp.com/includes/demo_flash.aspDigital Light Processing. It's a gimick often found in rear projection tv's. LCD is liquid crystal display and is probably the best type of screenDIGITAL LIGHT PROJECTOR It has a little motor and a spinning colored wheel inside with a bright light behind it and that's how it projects the picture. Looks like something Thomas Edison built, but they work good and look great.

You could get a small transformer to step down the voltage first and then use a small resitor with a reasonable power disipation say 0.1 W, just make sure you current is less than 30 mA for normal LED's. If you only want to check the voltage then you could use a neon lamp which operates at about 70-90 V and use a smaller resistor, or lastly you could a zener diode (specifiy about 90 or 100 V) with an led and then use a moderate resistor (about 1,2k ohm 1 W) to limit the currentLED's operate on MUCH lower voltage than 110v! You could do it, but if you just want to test for voltage, buy a cheap voltmeter. If you are testing outlets, get a small lamp or shop light.yo bro u should hav voltage resisdent in ur circuit board. Use resister for ur circuit and use pot for controling the current. May b u dun noe abt that. use the transformer and low the current voltage. Or link all the LED via through that transformer and u will c it is work. Good luck buddy.

mp3 is basically an industry standard, and many computer programs recognize it. iPods, an Apple invention, uses iTunes, which uses a format called AAC to compress the music files. There is a difference, and the two are not compatible. You can set your iTunes to use mp3, though.The only difference is the manufacturer. Wikipedia has a good explanation of the two.... . H a p p y. V i e w i n g !The terms "Digital Television" (DTV) and "High Definition Television" (HDTV) are often used interchangeably, but they are NOT the same thing. . . Digital Television refers to a TV signal that is transmitted digitally as opposed to an analog signal. Digital Television can be broadcast in several different formats. Of these formats, two are considered to be "high definition". The term high definition implies that the resolution of the digital television signal is very high. For example, the 1080i standard is considered high definition and has a resolution approximately twice that of analog NTSC television. . . All HDTV is digital, but not all Digital TV is HDTV. . . The same bandwidth for digital TV broadcasting can either used to supply a video signal (or several) and other services, or can be used to transmit a single HDTV signal. . Although there are technically 18 different standards for digital TV broadcasting (all Digital TV tuners are required to decode all 18 standards), the practical application of DTV has come down to 3 standards. These standards are: 480p, 720p, and 1080i.HDTV is high definition television. It has more resolution (lines per inch) than standard television so it is able to render far more detail.. . I subscribe to digital cable television, but I can't get HDTV because I don't have an HD capable television to receive it on.. . So, no, HDTV and digital are NOT just two different names for the same thing.

If your TV has R (red ) & L (white) and video (yellow) connections, you can use RCA cables to make the connection to your surround sound system.. . If your TV doesn't have audio/video connections, and you have a VCR, use the VCR's audio/video RCA connections.. . You will need an A/V receiver to make the connections as well, so if your surround sound system is just speakers, you will need a receiver or surround amplifier to complete the system.. . H a p p y. H o m e. T h e a t e r i n g !Hopefully this isn't as complicated as you feared.  This depends on your TV and what else you will be connecting to the system.  Here's a few options for what you are trying to do.. 1) Direct TV Connection Option: If your television offers an audio output this will be the easiest of the connections, all you do is connect an audio cable from the TV's audio output (white and red jacks), to the input of your choice on your receiver (TV/SAT, Video 1, AUX, etc).  When you want to watch your TV through surround, you turn on your receiver to the correct input and trun on your TV, and you're good to go.  There may be an option in your TV menu as well to leave the audio output as fixed - choose this option if available, this means that as you adjust the volume on your TV, it won't mess with the sound through the receiver.. 2) Using a Cable or Satellite Box:  If you have a cable or satellite box connected to the TV, the sound quality will be better than coming directly from the TV.  For this you will utilize the audio outputs on the back of the boxes, either Analog Audio (red and white), or a digital output (optical or digital coax).  From the back of the box, connect one of the cables from the audio out (analog or digital) to your receiver to whichever input you choose, and now when you watch your cable or satellite, you will have sound from your receiver and/or your TV.  (This is my preferred choice).. 3) Using a VCR:  If your TV doesn't have an audio output, and you're not using a cable or satellite box this is pretty much the only other option (if you have a VCR that is).  If you have a stereo VCR and your TV signal (basic cable/antenna) is running through the VCR, you will connect an Audio cable from the Audio output on the back of the VCR to whatever jack you prefer on your receiver.  All you do is leave your VCR on when you want to listen to the stereo, and whatever channel the VCR is on, that sound will come through the Stereo as well.  . . I hope this helps in your quest, I know its a lot of information, but I like being thorough.It depends on what outputs are available on the back of the TV.. . Most have stereo output jacks (red and white rca) which can feed an amplifier/receiver input of the same type (or can connect to powered speakers directly and be controlled by the TV volume control if the menu is set for external speakers to be "variable"). Sound will be stereo, not surround, unless processed through a surround matrix decoder in the receiver/amp (e.g. Dolby ProLogic).. . If you have a coaxial or optical audio output from the TV (See second link for photos of different connection types) you can connect to the same type of connector on the amp/receiver and get digital surround from programs that include it (usually indicated on the screen at the beginning of the program).. . Hope this helps.

T-Mobile WILL give you the code IF you are a current T-mobile customer in good standing and you tell them you will be traveling out of the country and want to use that country’s sim card.. You cannot alter or improve the pixel rate of camera's on phones. On some models you can adjust the picture quality to better then the standard setting, this normally just uses  further image processing to make it look better, but the actual resolution is unchanged.. . Professional image editing software like Adobe Photoshop claims to be able to resize a picture to almost any size with no loss of quality. This software is expensive and takes time to work out how to use it.. . Best piece of advice. Take your phone to a photographers and see if they can resize the image. Failing that get a phoen with a better camera, or buy a cheap digital camera with a better resolution.. . Incidentally I have a 2.0Mpixel camera on my phone, and the images that come off that are more then reasonable and are detailed enough to go full screen.You can upgrade your cellphone. The card goes into the camera. Any pictures taken will be stored on that card. Formatting isn't usually necessary, but the camera will tell you if it needs to format. Once you've taken a few pics, just insert the card into your SD slot on your computer and it will look like another drive to your computer with pictures on it. It would be pointless to buy a supercomputer because in a few months it would be worthlessa computer that performs at or near the current highest operational rate for computers. Such a computer is typically used for scientific and engineering applications that must handle very large databases or do a great amount of computation. The most significant difference between a supercomputer and a mainframe is that a supercomputer channels all its power into executing a few programs as fast as possible, whereas a mainframe uses its power to execute many programs simultaneously. . Refers to those computing systems (hardware, systems software, and applications software) that provide close to the best currently achievable sustained performance on demanding computational problema computer that is super

A kicked up version of an MP3. I assume it holds more videos, songs, etcMPEG-4 Part 14, formally, ISO/IEC 14496-14:2003, is a multimedia container format standard specified as a part of MPEG-4. It is most-commonly used to store digital audio and digital video streams, especially those defined by MPEG, but also can be used to store other data such as subtitles and still images. Like most modern container formats, MPEG-4 Part 14 allows streaming over the Internet. The official filename extension for MPEG-4 Part 14 files is .mp4, thus the container format is often referred to simply as MP4. Devices that play .mp4 files are referred to as MP4 players.

Night vision glasses are used at night time. You look through the lenses. You would see movement of one person or two people or more by body heat. They are usually in red, yellow or green. They're used in spying and for private eyes. How is this a music and music player question?They amplify the little light that always exists even during the darkest night.. . Night vision goggles should be sealed off around the eyes as any light intruding from the sides could ruin the effect.. . Also, if you look at a bright light with night vision devices you could hurt your eyes because the light will be so strong.. . Fun fact: With most night vision goggles you can't see what's really close to yourself (or it becomes very distorted), so walking while looking down at the ground can be quite a strange experience.. . ----------. Edit: The poster above describes a thermal vision device.

Simple... see your love one when you want to...3G (or 3-G) is short for third-generation technology. It is used in the context of mobile phone standards. The services associated with 3G provide the ability to transfer simultaneously both voice data (a telephone call) and non-voice data (such as downloading information, exchanging email, and instant messaging.Basically a 3G mobile phone has to do with the ability of the phone and the network to transport much more data than is capable on 2G networks. This opens up a host of applications like watching TV on the mobile phone handset, playing games with other users on the internet, being able to browse etc. Think of it as the mobile version of broadband internet, when compared to dial-up.

Conditioning is allowing the battery to *completely* run down before charging again.  This is also called "training" the battery.  Typically this only has to be done once with modern cell phone batteries.drain life till its dead then recharge drain again then rechargeIts something that you may need to do for older phone batteries (Non Lithium).. . It's a time consuming process, but it is worth doing. You will notice a difference:. Drain your battery completely (until the phone powers itself off). Charge the battery for a long time (12hours). Repeat this process 3 times. . You can get battery conditioners that will drain the power from the battery and recharge both quickly and automaticely, but that is up to you.  Check Radio Shack or eBay if you wanna pay for one
