Yes there is a "super HD" system under development, but no-one expects it to replace consumer HD for some time, if ever.  (It is being developed for medical and scientific uses.)  As with all improvements like this, there is a law of diminishing returns.  The better a system is, the harder it is to make significant improvements, and the cost of those improvements keeps increasing.  Many people feel that the improvement from ordinary TV to HDTV is only incremental and some don't even appreciate the difference.  It will be even harder to see the difference in "super HD" and it will cost a whole lot more.  We are more likely to see technology improvements within the current HD standards: better displays, lower cost displays, etc.I think the next generation of tv that would be way cool is interactive 3d tv where it immerses you in the film that you watch. Example: imagine been a side kick in ur favorite martial arts film ohhh man the future would be so sweeeeet.I had been watching a program called Daily Planet and according to them there is a super HD that is coming out. If You Are Completely Convinced That Your PSP Analog Nub Is Broken, Best You Contact Sony For Assistance (1)... . If Your PSP Is Still Under Warranty, You Just Might Have It Fixed/Replaced For Free, Otherwise, You'll Might Have To Pay A Fee For It... . Remember: If You Try To Mess With The PSP Yourself And Fix It, Trying To Open It And Modify It Will Void Your Warranty... . For Any Other Help, Don't Hesitate To Contact Me!If the analog stick feels 'crunchy' the internals are broken and you'll have to have a new one installed. If it still feels smooth you can try SLIGHTLY adjusting some of the case screws which won't void your warranty. If the faceplate isn't sitting exactly right it will mess with your analog contacts. There are two screws in the deep holes on the back of the PSP, one black screw in the battery compartment, and the outside silver screw along the edge, all of which you can remove or adjust without voiding the warranty. If it's still under warranty send it to sony, if not PSP Repair Service will fix it for $59 rather than Sony's $89 refurb exchange. Also good if you don't want your firmware updated :-)

DVD-R and DVD+R are similar but different standards. They're the result of manufactures couldn't agree to produce the same kind of discs. Generally speaking, DVD+R appear to be a little better produced. I would use DVD+R to backup my data over DVD-R any day. Whether if your DVD burner can take a +R disk is really dependent on the DVD burner. If it says + and - R, then it can do both. If it only says +R or -R, it's probably only meant for that one kind. Hope this helpone is a + and one is a -. no you cantone is a recorder only and the other is a recorder + moreI've asked many a storeperson about this question.  They've all told me they're the same, but one is older.  It doesn't matter which one you use, you can use either, one's not better than the other.DVD-R (pronounced as DVDR or DVD "Dash" R) is a DVD recordable format. A DVD-R has a larger storage capacity than a CD-R, typically 4.7 GB (or 4.38 GiB) instead of 700 MB, although the capacity of the original standard developed by Pioneer was 3.95 GB (3.68 GiB). Pioneer has also developed an 8.54 GB dual layer version, which appeared on the market in 2005. A DVD-R can be written to only once, whereas a DVD-RW (DVD-rewritable) can be rewritten multiple times.. . --> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DVD-R. . DVD "dash" (-)  . First DVD recordable format released in the market. Developed by Pioneer and backed by the DVD Forum. Has broader playback compatibility than the "+" especially with much older players. The dash format is based on an older CD-R/RW format for easy upgrade or migration for disc manufacturers. . DVD "plus" (+)  . Developed by Philips and Sony with their DVD+RW Alliance. Came out after the "-" format.Well, doll, it's a different format of recording, you must check you DVD recording states on this and if it's able to burn DVD -/+ R (this means it can record both formats) you better rec on DVD-R because most DVD players don't support the + format and such will be only playable on the recording player.Aw. That is so cute :). . There is no difference.It depends on your burner. Check the box that it came in and see if it lists both formats. Most new burners will support all formats if it's a good one. The only difference is, the +R will usually have faster burn speeds than the -R. At least that was true in the early going. They may be the same now.

Not sure what you are . looking for, but you can look . up much about HDTV on Wikipedia...There is no HDTV timetable.  There is a deadline for TV stations to stop broadcasting analog TV.  Those who want to continue in operation will broadcast digital TV.  Many stations are now broadcasting both on a digital channel and an analog channel; they will shut down the analog channel at the changeover date (early 2009).  Digital TV does NOT mean HDTV, and much television broadcast digitally is not HDTV. . . When the changeover occurs, analog TVs now in use will not be able to receive off-the-air broadcasts.   Adapter boxes (digital tuners) are supposed to be available for these sets at a low price.  This changeover will have no effect on people receiving their TV signals from cable or satellite.. . While digital television does not mean HDTV. in fact most of the digital broadcast will conform the HDTV standards.  Even now, almost all prime-time programs on the major networks and many on the smaller networks are in HDTV, and that is sure to increase.  It is up to the local station whether to transmit these in HDTV format, but certainly almost all of them will.The original time table was Feb, 2006.  This was the point in which broadcast companies were supposed to have HDTV channels up and running.  The problem was that not enough HDTV's were sold, so the broadcast companies didn't want to waste their money on upgrading.  Currently, all of the core channels like ABC, CBS, NBC, PBS, Fox and Warner Bros all broadcast in HDTV.  Through cable/sattelite, about 25 channels are currently being broadcast in HD.  Chances are these are all the channels you regularly watch.  December of 2007, nearly every channel will be broadcast in both HD and SD (standard definition).

This is one of those "its just is" questions.. . I guess the person who came up with bra sizes isnt the same person who came up with the battery sizes.Those batteries were used for vacuum tube radios back about 80 years ago. Once they figured out how to use the tubes and other electronic devices to create the voltages they needed (in the 1930's), the batteries disappeared from retail stores. The B batteries were used for the tube output, or plate, and sometimes you'll see switches for the B+ on old radios (in old movies, too) that would let you put it in a standby mode to keep from running down the battery.. . The amateur radio folks used to have some good books on the ancient (but still useful) technologies...There is an A battery it's made by panasonic, part code hhr210A, 1.2v, 2100mAh. As for the B cell, I haven't been able to find anything about it.I would surmise it's historical. Since Size A and B were already taken, they were not reused, although it doesn't quite explain why Size C is reused. But it's a start...

digital is prone to interference from the same electric (spikes) that cause computers to crash,running through electricity mains,causing a click and volume loss or picture (freeze)u could try buying a surge protected plug adapter that may help,also central heating thermostats when faulty can have a effect on (receiver) equipment.IE:TV or radio.intercom any thing that uses a frequency.also try not using the Ariel signal booster and see if the problem subsides.boosters are mainly for analogue reception to enhance UHF or vhf signals, digital is transmitted in blocks of information and decoded by your set top box ,in my experience boosters make the situation worse. if the Ariel is misaligned or weather beat the booster enhances the bad reception  to a louder brighter bad reception in analogue,and a complete overload on your set top box circuitry.if you are using freeview you might be gettign interference from some other device in your house.I developed this problem when I switched over to Freeview. Why are you sitting so close to the TV?  I have an HD TV (Not quite that big), but the further away I sit, the better the picture is.. Put some distance between you and the screen and see what happens.  If still not satisfied, take it back like someone else suggested.You probably got a tv with DLP.  DLP technology uses mirrors to create a clear picture.  One of the downsides of DLP is that the mirrors can pick up reflections from the other pixels and create a shimmer [or screen door] effect.  It's part of the technology.Hi there. Your television should not be doing that, take it back to the retailer and demand an exchange, dont be fobed off with a repair....Why would you want to sit that close? You need to be at least 1.8m away to view that TV and closer and you wont get the best out of it.Im not too sure but you should be sitting further away than that for the sake of your eyesBecause you should have got a 42" Panasonic

The speed at which anything downloads is a function of many things - the speed at which the server is connected to the internet, how many other people are connected to it, also downloading, the traffic on the internet, and the speed of your connection.  You might try downloading at a different time to get better speed.  To register another ipod (shuffle or whatever) just plug it in to your computer and give it a different name.d
Oh, well, I'd just create new On-The-Go playlist matching the songs not in their right order. There's smthg like 'shuffle songs' in your iPod, but it's shuffeling all the song you got on it. :)In itunes view the songs by album, go to the songs in the album you want to change the order of.  Right click the first song.  Click on get info, then go to the info tab.  Then change the track number to the whatever number you want the song to play.  For example if you are looking at the first song on the album, but you want it to be the fourth song you hear, change the track number to 4, then go to the second song and change the track number again.  Do this for all of the songs in the album, then the songs should play in that order.   Keep in mind changing that order in itunes will not change it on your ipod, so change the track numbers on the songs in your ipod.  hope this helps.

I would say the ipod is great i think they are neat.. but for convenience I like having my phone and music all in one less junk to carry around..An iPod IS an MP3 player.  The only difference between iPods and other MP3 players is the brand name. The same mistake is often made with TiVos and DVR's. A TiVo IS a DVR, just as an iPod IS an MP3 player, but the two brand names have become so popular now that people often believe they are another technology altogether. Don't be fooled. The only difference is that iPods are called iPods, and other assorted MP3 players are called by whichever brand makes them. Simple as that.. . (HOWEVER - obviously the user interfaces and some of the features are going to vary from system to system, but the main point I wanted to make was that the iPod IS an MP3 player. It just happens to be the most popular. And therefore, I would recommend it.)
Sony does NOT make any PDAs anymore. The ones they used to make were all Palm OS machines.No, Sony's PDAs ( Sony clie's) all come with Palm OS .
HD ready concerns the ability of television receivers to display high-definition pictures. In the USA, "HD Ready" refers to any display that is capable of accepting and displaying a high definition signal at either 720p, 1080i or 1080p using a component video or digital input, and does not have a built-in HD-capable tuner.. . The fact that a product bears the label "HD ready" does not necessarily mean that it can display the full picture resolution possible from a HD source. Most HD-ready sets do not have enough pixels (1920x1080 or 1280x720) to give true pixel-for-pixel representation without interpolation of higher HD resolutions.hd ready you need to buy the box to get hd hdtv has the box built in the tv

Optical zoom is the lens actually working to move towards the object.  It would be like you walking up to the object, you can still see fine detail. Digital zoom is 'Cropping', like you taking a picture, cutting out the area you want to bring closer, and stretch it back to the right size, witch will make it pixelated, and you won't be able to see fine detail.  My suggestion, turn your digital zoom off...you can always 'crop' later, on your computer or photo kiosk.optical zoom uses lenses.  Digital zoom uses microprocessors to enlarge a picture.  If you enlarge a picture using digital zoom, you'll start to see pixels.  Definitely get a handycam with good optical zoom capability.I would say no because zoom is zoom you know?Optical refers to physically changing the focal length of the lens where as digital zoom crops the image.  The more you zoom in with digital, the less the quality will be.  There is no drop in quality with optical zoom.optical zoom will not cause blurriness but digital zoom willBasically, optical zoom sees what you see, digital zoom uses a "magnifying glass" (for lack of a better word). When you use the digital zoom, you lose quality in your photo, because it makes up pixels. It's much better to use optical zoom - I never use the digital zoom on my camera.Optical zoom uses moving lenses to enlarge the image on the CCD sensor. Digital zoom uses software in the camera to enlarge the image already on the CCD. This is like zooming in on a Mapquest picture, or using the + magnifying glass on most computer picture viewers.. . Optical zoom and digital zoom can be used together to get substantial zooming (enlarging) capacity.It is the optical zoom that matters in a cmera lens. The more the better. Digital zoom is obtained by interpolation. This reduces quality of image. The normal advice is to keep the digital zoom off if you want good photos.OPTICAL ZOOM:. Optical zoom magnifies the size of an image by adjusting the lens. Unlike digital zoom, optical zoom enlarges the subject without sacrificing resolution.. . DIGITAL ZOOM:. Unlike optical zoom, which uses the optics of the lens to magnify the size of an image, digital zoom discards pixels around the edge of an image, fitting the remaining pixels into the same space to give the appearance of zoom. Since digital zoom comes at the expense of resolution, you should always choose a camera based on its optical zoom, not the digital or combined figure.

xbox is gheyPoints are purchased through the Marketplace on your 360 dashboard.. . Yes, you can play NFS Carbon on Live.Real points are not earned, they are purchased. You can buy them from the XBL marketplace menu, 1600 are about $20 US. Or you can go to a store like Best Buy or Target and buy a card with a serial number. Enter the serial number into XBL marketplace and it will add the points to your account.. . Microsoft has hinted that in the future they will allow things that earn you points, but as of now there are none. One example they gave is allowing people to make skins for car games, etc. and sell them for a few points. The points are transferred to your account, which you can then spend in whatever is it that you want. They will probably use the points too as currency for the new video distribution service that will launch this week.. . The reason why you have to buy points instead of paying directly with a credit card? Because credit card transactions under $5 don't add up for Microsoft. By letting you buy the points you can spend them in things that would add up to less than $5 in real money. For example, gamer picture packs are 150 points, which is $1.87 in real money. Registering XBL Arcade games costs 800 on average, which is about $10, competitive against shareware flash games.

If they are in another format, such as wma or aac, you will need to find mp3 transcoding software. Usually there will be a few choices from economy, regular, and fine (or even super fine). Fine or super will result in the best photos for resizing later, but will also require more space. Go into the cameras menu to check or change your settings. ANALOG WILL HAVE OLD TYPES OF VOLUME CONTROL AND OTHER FEATURES ..................... whereas digital will have chip movement and will have LCD display ................ and size may be smallerIt depends on the manufacturer and how they define the word digital in respect to their product.. It could just mean in the control circuitry alone, or it could be that the audio that comes in is processed with an A/D converter and then back through an D/A before amplification.. The manufacturer specs should detail this information.

Interlaced versus progressive scanning. Basically, the way the television refreshes its picture. Some people, usually tv salesmen or "audiophiles" that think $1,000.00 interconnects are worth the price, will swear that progressive(usually more expensive) is better, but there are advantages and drawbacks to each system. If your tv lets you choose, try switching back and forth to see the difference. I personally would not buy a television based on interlaced vs progressive scanning. Too many other factors contribute to picture quality.i stand for interlaced and p for progressive. To produce an image in screen TV usually do that by scanning from top to bottom left to right.. For interlaced to produces one picture, the scanning process takes two times first it scan the odd lines and than the even lines.. For progressive only need one scanning process.

Make your own ringtones. . 11/11/2006. . . Custom ringtones are the preferred way for many people to express themselves. Cellular providers love this trend. Ringtones sell for up to $3. And some kids and adults change their tunes every week.. . If you have an MP3-capable phone, you don't have to spend on ringtones. With a few steps and the right tools, you can make your own.. . First, you'll need software to cut ringtone clips from your digital collection. Most phones only play ringtones for about 20 seconds. Whole songs are wasteful. I'll detail instructions for Audacity, which is both capable and free.. . Set up Audacity. . You can get Audacity through my Web site (click here). Audacity requires a separate LAME encoder file to work with MP3s. You can download the file through a number of sites. Click here for the file recommended by Audacity's developers.. . Save the LAME encoder file in Audacity's folder, typically C:&#92;Program Files&#92;Audacity. If you downloaded a compressed (.zip) file, decompress it. In Windows XP, right-click the file and select Extract All.. . Older versions of Windows can use programs such as 7-Zip (click here), BiGZiP (click here) and 100Zipper (click here).. . Open Audacity. Click Edit>>Preferences. Select the File Formats tab. Under "MP3 Export Setup," click the Find Library button.. . Audacity will prompt you to locate the LAME encoder file. Click Yes, then locate the file in Audacity's folder. Select the file and click Open. Now Audacity is ready for MP3s.. . Cut your ringtone. . Load your favorite MP3 into Audacity by clicking File>>Open. You'll be prompted to locate the song on your hard drive. You'll see a timeline paired with what looks like the screen of an oscilloscope.. . By default, Audacity fits the song's entire playtime into the window. For precision editing, click View>>Zoom In. Each time you zoom in, the timeline will become more precise. A timeline marking every second or every five seconds will do.. . Finally, it's time to cut your ringtone. Press the Play button in Audacity to listen to the MP3. Note which 20-second section of the song stands best as a ringtone. Pay attention to that section's place in the timeline.. . Highlight the section you want in the timeline. The process is similar to selecting text in Windows. Press Play and Audacity will play only that section. You can adjust the start and end points of the selection.. . Once you've got the sound clip you want, click File>>Export Selection As MP3. You'll be prompted for a location to save the selection. It's also a good idea to change the file name. The name should distinguish the sound clip from the complete song.. . That's all there is to preparing the ringtone.. . Getting the tone to your phone. . An easy way to get the ringtone onto your phone is via e-mail. Check with your service provider for your phone's e-mail address. Simply e-mail the ringtone from your PC to your phone. Many phones also accept Bluetooth wireless connections. However, the same cannot be said of most PCs.. . You can also transfer the tone by connecting your phone to your PC. Some phones connect using a USB cable. The cable is usually included as part of mobile toolkit software.. . Web sites also let you upload ringtones from your PC. Then, use your phone's Web browser to download the ringtone to your phone. Be careful using these sites. Most require an e-mail address to register and use it to send you spam from the site.. . Finally, check your phone's data plan. Sending and receiving ringtones can push you over your limit. Extra charges may apply.go to nextel.com and download them or cut your ownLook for a program called labjal or webjal they are both free and even Motorola offers some free programs that will save your contact list or upgrade your phone software. After you do that look for the drivers for the phone because you will need them to connect your phone to the computer if not it will not recognize it.. If you cant find the programs let me know i will get them for you and rings and games so you can hook up your phone.. Go to the websites below and you will find the programs i have mention here or at least most of them.

A podcast is a multimedia file distributed over the Internet using syndication feeds, for playback on mobile devices and personal computers. The term, as originally coined by Ben Hammersley in an article in The Guardian February 12, 2004 [1], was meant as a portmanteau of "broadcasting" and "iPod".[2] Like 'radio', it can mean both the content and the method of delivery; the latter may also be termed podcasting. The host or author of a podcast is often called a podcaster.. . By the way, why didn't you just Google that?a crisp way to describe the technology used to push audio content from websites down to consumers of that content, who typically listen to it on their iPod. It's usually a talk show or radiio show you can listen to on your ipodA free radio program that is recorded with no commercials can be found on itunes you can hear a samples.It's for your iPod (you can listen to them on iTunes too. It's kind of like the radio, but they're more like lectures and informative articles (spoken of course). Some examples of Podcasts are National Geographic (types of animals generally), there's 1 for SAT/ACT/GRE prep to improve your vocabulary, NPR: All songs considered, and Wall Street Journal.It what you do to your iPod when the battery dies (just after the end of the warranty).. . Best results achieved from rooftops.

LCD or DLP? "The answer: It actually depends on the application(s) for which you intend to use your new DLP TV or LCD TV. Part of the reason has to do with basic mechanics: LCD and DLP technologies differ greatly in how the image is generated." Check out the following link which discusses the benefits of both.who told you LCD is better.. Actually each has their own advantages and disadvantages.. DLP picture is better (smoother) but the color is worse since it uses color wheel. LCD color is better since it usually uses three LCD for each basic color.Actually, DLP technology is better than LCD...The DLP will offer better "black levels" (this means that shadows and the bars at the top and bottom of your "cinema scope" movies will appear black and NOT gray)...Some LCD projectors are trying to correct this problem with an IRIS over the light bulb to reduce the amount of brightness from scene to scene...Also the newer DLPs with the FASTER spinning color wheels deliver SLIGHTLY better color...But as for SHARPNESS and DETAIL both projectors are evenly matched.

To erase and reburn you need to use a RW disc. a DVD-RW for movies and CD-RW for audio. RW stands for RE-WRITABLE.. On a standard disc (CD-R, DVD-R) the R stands for RECORDABLE.no you cannot dvd -r and dvd+r are record once only discs .. . _dvd-rw and dvd +rw can be recorded on and then erased.. . dvd ram discs can be recorded and erased also they can be edited meaning if you record something say of tv you can remove adverts etc but not all recorders and burners are compatable with dvd ram.. . hope this helps bob the blade
Yes, they Infrared LED's can pick up heat/motion and trigger the camera to turn itself on.  This works the same as a alarm system in your home.I believe that they are used for motion activation. Meaning, the camera isn't recording until something comes within range of the motion sensor. I could be wrong, but I think that's what you're looking for.

sometimes if the set is on standby a small power blip can turn on a tv and because you did not use the remote control a station wasn't selected. with most modern televisions if no signal is received for a set period (usually 5 minutes) the tv will turn off automatically. the time this has been happening would support the "power blip" theory because power stations usually change generators in the early hours and this creates a minor blip.Some TVs have a "timer mode" that turns on the TV at a certain time, just like an alarm clock rings at a preset time.. . Go into your menu....look for the clock page, you will find a Time On with 3:00 on it....there should be an ON /OFF command on the same page...... If not, then advancining the time should eventually show a 0;00 or "none" in the list....just depends what the brand name is..... . I'll bet your TV is an RCA.....This happened to me before and it spooked me too.  I have heard that remote signals can be universal like garage door openers if they are not programmed right can open someone elses garage door.  It may be that your TV caught a signal from someone else's remote?  How close are your neighbors?Try to switch the TV off from power button (not stand by mode), If necessary unplugged the Power/AC cord. If it still switch on after you unplugged the power cord than you can start to freak out maybe call ghostbuster or something.NO thats my late grandmother who told the space alien to say HI to you so then you can ask that question and i now know she said hi.

you have to be in the "build wall" tool, and then press ctrl while holding down your mouse as if you were building another wall. same goes for pools, i think...In build mode, hold the Crtl button and left click at the start of where you want to delete and drag to where you want to stop.  Be sure to release the left click before the control button.When using the wall tool; press down the "Ctrl" key and click down on the wall portions you want to remove; then while holding down the right mouse button, go over the walls you want removed (note you still need to hold down the "Ctrl" key) and then release on the mouse key; then the "Ctrl" key and it should remove the walls you want removed. Hope this information helps.
The Nintendo DS Lite has the following advantages over the original DS:. . - It's smaller and lighter.. - Brighter screen, with 4 brightness settings. (Original has 2, on/off).. - The power button has been moved to prevent accidental shutoff during play.. - Start and select buttons have been moved to reflect the layout of more popular console controlers, making for easier play.. - Microphone has been centered.. - Stylus holder has been relocated to make it a little more discreet.. - Larger stylus for better grip.. - Smaller directional pad.. - Triggers on back even with case, as opposed to slightly extended on the original, to prevent accidental triggering during game play.. - All buttons are more pronounced for easier play.. - Longer battery life, although dependant on brightness settings and is decreased with Wi-Fi usage.. - "Weather stripping" over the game port to prevent dust damage, also allows game cartriges to fit more snuggly.. - Available in 3 colors (white, black and pink), as opposed to only one (blue) for the orginal.It is a slimmer, brighter, sleeker and more lightweight redesign of the earlier Nintendo DS model.The difference is this:. . Nintendo DS was created first, it's also quite heavy for people to hold for long periods of time.  The company figured this out a little too late, so it thought it'd correct the mistake.  Instead of taking away the DS it marketed out the DS lite version.  The DS lite is the same thing except it supposedly has better lights for the background and also is lighter than the DS version.The lite is lighter in weight and brighter in picture, plus a way to play GBA games on it as wellThe DS lite is smaller than the DS but is more expensive since it's newer.. . Performance-wise there's no difference between the two.NDS Lite is more comfortable to hold. It's more comfortable than the previous version. NDS Lite's light is also brighter and it has 4 choices of brightness, so you don't have to squint. The first NDS has only 2 choices. The stylus in NDS Lite is much comfortable to hold too. It's slightly bigger and longer than the first NDS which is smaller and shorter. In other words, get the newer version because the newer and improved ones are always much better than the older. Hope this helps.

It's a wireless way to to use a mobile, I think.  It's the reason why people walk around with those ridiculous Star Treck earpieces in.Bluetooth is the name for a wireless protocol that goes only short distances.  . . It is primarily used for connecting wirelessly to a mobile phone, with a headset or a computer for data transfer, but is now being used to connect computers with other local devicesIt's just another way to say wireless.  For example, an earpeice that interacts with your cell phone but has no wires.  It is automatically detected.It's wireless technology basically...Bluetooth is a global initiative by Ericsson, IBM, Intel, Nokia and Toshiba to set a standard for cable-free connectivity between mobile phones, mobile PCs, handheld computers and other peripherals. . . This allows you to send data or connect your phone for example to a headset, without wires.. . Thanksits is wireless technology that enables to to transfer data (1) handset to handset or (2) handset to PC or vice versa. they are also helpful in pairing with handsfree devices . in addition u can also print pictures clicked with ur handset and get that printed out from machines as a hard copy. also soon they are goin to install the same technology in Digitals camerasIt's a way of turning your teeth blue.  It's great if your teeth are green.. . Seriously, it's a way that electronic devices (phones, PDA's, computers, etc.) can communication with each other wirelessly over short (10 meters or less) distances.There is a part in the phone known as tooth, which is blue in color.That is why is called bluetooth and if that same features is avalible in different phones then you can transfer data, ringtones or pics. "mov", "av" or "mpg" ?. If are NOT mpg you will need some sort of software to convert your movie files into "mpg" format in order to be able to see it on TV using regular standalone DVD player. There are shops you can take it to,to get it unlocked,not sure if you're supposed to but you can. I know a place in my town centre called "Phone Doctor" who does that sort of thing for £10. Any phone shop that isn't a big brand will probably be able to offer the same service.To have your T-Mobile Samsung T629 unlocked you will need to call customer service and they will submit a request on your behalf with the manufacturer. . . Before you call them, you need to get the following information ready and make sure you write it down. You will need to get the IMEI number of your phone. To obtain the IMEI number you need to enter the following code in your phone *#06# and press the green button on your phone or the button to make a phone call. You will see a long 15 digit number -- note this number down. . . Call T-Mobile and ask them to file a subsidy unlock request for you they will require the IMEI give it to them and they will submit it for you. Also make sure you give them a working email address as the manufacturer will email you the instructions on how to unlock your phone. The usual time line for this request is 72 hours, and you will receive it via email. . . Let me know if you have any further questions.. . go to your local hardware store, they sell all sorts of things to hide cables, pipes etcSince your wall is plasterboard (studded). I would suggest making a hole behind the TV and another one above or below in an inconspicuous place then "fishing" the wires between the two holes. Hopefully there are no cross studs between.you chase(chisle)them into the wall leaving the ends poking out behind where the tv will sit.bingo!!!You could dig a channel out of your wall,sink the cables into it then fill in then paper over or do what l did and put a really nice panel of wood going from the floor all the way up and fixed the tv to it,gives the tv a nice surround and if you need into the cables at a later date you don't have to wreck your wall!a messy idea is to dig a groove on the wall and sink it with papier mache or plaster. a neat idea is to buy a wall wire sticker that has the same colour as the wall and hide the wire with it.you can buy a coiled cable with a split down the side just put wires in there it tidys the wires up.

MP3 is a format in which music is compressed i.e. its file size is reduced so that more songs can b stored on a storege media & iPod is a music player from Apple.It can play these compressed MP3 files.So the former is a software whereas the latter is hardware.Got it?mp3 is a kind of file format.. iPod is so called pocketPC...A MP3 file is a kind of music format that can be played using the iPod. An iPod is a portable device used to play MP3 files, also known more generally as an MP3 player.. . Sort of the difference between a piece of toast and the toaster.i believe MP3 is a kind of file like jpeg, bmp, gif and so on.. Mp3 is for audio materials or such.. while iPod is a portable device other than pc which reads Mp3 files...A pretty big one - for one thing, an MP3 is a song and an iPod is what  can play songs. MP3 is just a data format that an audio file has been converted or compressed to (the purest format from CDs are AIFF files, which are huge; MP3s by comparison take up less space). iPods are a type of portable device made by Apple that can contain anywhere from 1 GB of material to, I think, 80 GBs. Also, iPods aren't simply just for music storage; people put photos, movies, podcasts, and music videos on them.. Go to http://www.apple.com/ipod/ipod.html to look at some iPods... although, they aren't the only type of MP3 playback device, just the most popular.
If you look close their is probably a symbol writ next to the power receptacle that looks like( neg _---Co---+pos ) , But if not  <----Their is the answer. You are also going to want to make sure your charger has enough mA to charge your player. Most times you will need a minimum of 500 mA It's not possible to have to many mA'sRemove the batteries from your player.  Using an ohm meter, check the resistance between the negative battery terminal and then either the inside pin or outside of the AC adapter input connector.  Look for a resistance very close to 0.  That should identify the negative side.

AudioStation plays audio CDs, digital music files stored on your PC hard drive. and streaming audio from the Internet (also referred to as "Internet Radio" or. "Internet Broadcasts"). These three types of music are accessed by choosing. from three main modes of operation, which are activated by the tabs on the. left of the main screen view.  . .   . Features: . *  Plays CD audio, MP3, WMA, video and MIDI file formats. . *  Plays digital audio stored on networked PCs. . *  Burn custom CDs of your favorite tracks that are in MP3, Windows Media .    or WAV formats. . *  Autogain(TM) Level Control corrects changes in song volume levels when .    burning CDs. . *  Gapless Playback eliminates pauses between tracks when burning CDs. . *  Automatically import album and title information from the Internet. . *  Optional RF remote control lets you control functions from other rooms .    in your home. . *  Print CD labels with song titles and jewel case covers with custom artwork..    . . Benefits: . *  Convert your CD library to digital format by storing thousands of songs .    on your PC's hard drive-so you can enjoy your favorite songs without .    the frustration of searching through a pile of CD's to find them. . *  Tailor your music collection to suit your mood by playing songs by your.    favorite artist, in a particular genre, or your own custom compilations. . *  Create a PC digital music collection by converting CDs into Windows Media.    or WAV formats. . *  Easily find songs by title, artist, genre, etc. and create custom.    playlists. . *  Create a personalized selection of your favorite Internet Radio stations. . *  Diagnose audio and MIDI problemsA audio station is an audio (sound) broadcasting service, traditionally broadcast through the air as radio waves (a form of electromagnetic radiation) from a transmitter to an antenna and a thus to a receiving device. Stations can be linked in audio networks to broadcast common programming, either in syndication or simulcast or both. Today, stations also broadcast via cable FM, local wire networks, satellite and the Internet.

Blackberry is like a cell phone/pda hybrid. Bluetooth is a wireless technology.blackberry is like a gadget for e-mail. Bluetooth is a device that u can send or receive files.they dont MEAN anything, they're just names for the devices sometimes based on the color.  The names just draw people in like the chocolate cell phone.  just sounds coolThe BlackBerry is a wireless handheld device introduced in 1999 which supports push e-mail, mobile telephone, text messaging, internet faxing, web browsing and other wireless information services. It was developed by the Canadian company, Research In Motion (RIM) and delivers information over the wireless data networks of mobile phone service companies. BlackBerry made headway in the marketplace by first concentrating on e-mail. RIM currently offers BlackBerry e-mail service to non-BlackBerry devices, such as the Palm Treo, through the BlackBerry Connect software. The original BlackBerry device had a monochrome display, but all current models have color displays.. . While including the usual PDA applications (address book, calendar, to-do lists, etc.) as well as telephone capabilities on newer models, the BlackBerry is primarily known for its ability to send and receive e-mail wherever it can access an appropriate wireless network of certain cellular phone carriers. It has a built-in keyboard, optimized for "thumbing", the use of only the thumbs to type. System navigation is primarily accomplished by the trackwheel (or "thumbwheel"), a scrolling wheel with a "click" function, located on the right side of the device. Some models (currently, those manufactured for use with Nextel, TELUS, and other iDEN networks) also incorporate a two-way radio. BlackBerry devices still depend on mobile phone service coverage and are not Wi-Fi compatible unlike similar handheld devices that are on the marketplace.. . Modern BlackBerry handhelds incorporate an ARM 7 or 9 processor, while older BlackBerry 950 and 957 handhelds used Intel 80386 processors. The latest GSM BlackBerry models (8100 and 8700 series) have an Intel PXA901 312 MHz processor, 64 MB flash memory and 16 MB SDRAM.[2]. . The devices are very popular with some businesses, where they are primarily used to provide e-mail access to roaming employees. To fully integrate the BlackBerry into a company's systems, the installation of BlackBerry Enterprise Server (BES) is required.. . In November 2004, RIM announced that the number of subscribers to the BlackBerry service had reached two million, having doubled within ten months.[1] Continuing their growth, RIM announced an additional one million subscribers in May, 2005, only six months after reaching two million.[2] On December 21, 2005, RIM announced that their subscriber base reached 4.3 million subscribers [3] and has surpassed 5 million by March 2006, despite slowing sales [4]. In October 2006, RIM announced that the number of subscribers had reached 6.2 million.. . Bluetooth is an industrial specification for wireless personal area networks (PANs). Bluetooth provides a way to connect and exchange information between devices such as mobile phones, laptops, PCs, printers, digital cameras and video game consoles via a secure, globally unlicensed short-range radio frequency.. . Bluetooth is a radio standard and communications protocol primarily designed for low power consumption, with a short range (power class dependent: 1 metre, 10 metres, 100 metres) based around low-cost transceiver microchips in each device.. . Bluetooth lets these devices communicate with each other when they are in range. The devices use a radio communications system, so they do not have to be in line of sight of each other, and can even be in other rooms, so long as the received transmission is powerful enough.

Slide it upwards:. . Anyway, flip that switch up and the little orange light just above it should sporadically pop on for a second or so, and if you scan for a local network connection, it light up quite a bit!

The LG VX8300 cell phone is a CDMA phone (offered through Verizon).  CDMA phones do not use SIM cards.  Only GSM phones uses SIM cards.u just go ur LG mobile,s homepage site ...where u found all above information to ur phone ..n also how remove the simmI can't answer the question until you answer one for me.  Do you have insurance on your phone?slide the back plastic part off where your battery goes and take the battery out and that's where your card is.no no no....like others said, cdma service doesnt have sim cards, ie sprint and verizone while gsm carriers do, ie cingular and tmobile.  Sim card is where you "activation" and numbers are stored.  With gsm you just take the sim card out, put in another gsm phone and you are off and running.  The drawback with cdma is you have to call your carrier to transfer service from phone to phone.LG VX8300's don't have sim cards. VZW only has Sim cards in their global phones.

As long as you just install itunes on to your computer, all the songs that you have stored on your hard drive will automatically be uploaded in to itunes (as long as you have the folder selected under itunes or individually add the songs from where ever they are on your computer). After itunes is on your computer and all the songs are uploaded, it's a simple drag and drop on to your ipod nano and all the songs, videos, or photos you need/want will be there waiting for you. Then it tells them to hang up, hit *82 and then call again. . . Another option theyhave is to say your name. Then you hear their name, and decide if you want to answer.you will probably have to call your phone company and ask them to put it in for you and they will charge you a little somthing for it.IF YOU GO TO TEEN FREEWAY.COM AND CLICK ON PHONES. Go to your telephone book  in the front if your in Canada,and probably in the back for the U.S.A. .  There will be a section in the beginning pages about tracking the last caller and blocking and downloading numbers into your phonebook ect.ect....  well just in case you don't find it, it is .  It is called (call screen) . Dial *60 .                                                   Follow the voice prompts.  You will have the option to:  Add or remove phone numbers from your call blocking list..                                                  If you want to make a list that your choice..                                                  Once you have established your list, you will have the choice of turning it back on or keeping it off..                                                   To turn it on or off Dial *60, Press 3 then listen to the voice prompt.. . If you have a window such as the Vista 350 you can also do call privacy which is (*11)(*60).  I hope I was helpfull.

download a cd on to itunes and then plug your ipod into the computer and drag the songsHave you ever been able to get music onto this ipod using this computer before? When in itunes your ipod should appear in the source list on the left hand side and your ipod screen should be flashing "do not disconnect". If you don't see that, your computer is not reconizing the ipod. Your computer's operating system may need to be upgarded or your ipod may be broken. Once you find the ipod in the itunes program drag the songs from your library to the ipod in the source list if it is set to manually update. Other wise once you connect the ipod the ipod will automatically update to whatever is in your itunes library at the time.

Install the software/driver using the CD that came with the camera.  Then you can connect your camera to the computer with a USB cable to download the photos.  Or you can also use a USB card reader.with ur eyes and fingersIf you don't have (or can't find) USB cable, consider buying a card reader instead.  This will work with any camera you buy in the future, as well.. . If you get a card reader, no additional software is necessary.  This is not only faster, but it saves your camera batteries.  Your computer or printer may even have a card reader built into it.  I have enough USB ports that I just leave it plugged in all the time.. . First of all, be sure there are some pictures on the card.  Plug the card reader into an open USB port.  Plug the card into the appropriate slot on your card reader.  I use Photoshop Elements and as soon as I plug my card into the reader, it starts its own card reader and displays a thumbnail of every picture on the card.. . If this does not happen automatically, open your photo editing software. Do whatever you usually do to open a file, but click on the selector where you can change drives. Your card reader will be assigned a new drive name that will be one letter higher than you ever saw before, such as "Drive G:" or such. Then, just double click on the name of the file you want to open and it will appear in your photo editor.read the instructionsif you have a memory card then put the memory card into the computer if not then use the usb cable that came with your camera and hook it up to your computer and camera. . . your manual should tell yuo more info.When you bought your camera, it should have came with a cable and a software disk. If you don't have it, you might have to get both the software and cable.
An i-pod is an MP3 player. I-pod is a brand name for the MP3 player made by apple... they are exactly the same thing!the price!An iPod is an mp3 player. iPods will play music, but depending on the make, they will also play videos and podcasts. Mp3 players vary by brand, but you can buy ones with just as much, if not more, memory than an iPod. It's a matter of personal preference.It's all just about the name...an ipod is an MP3 player. its just the most known one thats all.. i personally have a sony MP3 which i think is better than the ipod and so does my mate who has an ipod. mine can hold alot more tunes than hers and the sound is better when put on speakers.. depending on which MP3 you have bought her she will be up there with the ipod.An iPod is like youtube and myspace. It's for pretencious* young people. If you look at the specs, they're not that great.An iPod is a refined mp3 player and works with iTunes (a music subscription service).  It is also much smaller, thinner, and sexier looking than anything else on the market.  Some versions have a very nice screen for playing videos. Apple has basically dominated the legal mp3 game.  Itunes make for like 80 or 90% of all legal downloaded music.  Plus they have games, tv shows, news movies.   I think the advantage is that you'll have more purchasing options with an ipod, and if you decide to sell it will be a piece of cake on ebay.Three primary things:. . 1 - Downloading 99-cent songs from iTunes.  Those downloads won't work on an MP3 player, as they're in an iPod-only format.  (However, you CAN play standard MP3-format audio on an iPod.). . 2 - User interface.  Tap, slide, scroll, all from a single faceplate, with a good GUI above it.. . 3 - Aftermarket support.  The REAL win if you want to interface your player to your car, a home system, etc.  . . And one other thing, more difficult to define:. . 4 - It's cooooooler.... . Now, that being said... I have an older Creative Labs Zen which has performed very well for almost three years.  I bought it instead of an iPod because, when I was shopping, the iPod's battery life was not sufficient (I needed 10+ hours for regular long car trips), but that has changed and the newer iPods have longer battery life.  (Also the overall effective life of the built-in batteries in iPods was problematic, but I believe that has changed as well.). . I play my Creative Zen in the car and at home; it's not rocket science, you just plug a mini-jack cable into the headphone outlet and connect the other end to powered speakers of some kind and you've got great sound.  At home, I have a cable with a mini-jack at one end and RCA jacks at the other and I play through my receiver; in the car I have one of those adapters that goes into the tape player.  The sound is adequate, MARGINALLY less clear than a CD, but you can buy iPod-compatible stereos that take the DIGITAL output from the iPod and convert it internally, so you don't lose any quality through the connectors if that keeps you awake at night.. . All in all... we got my younger daughter an iPod for Christmas last year, and it's cooler than my Zen.  And the 30Gb video iPods are now $249 at the Apple Store, which is about what I paid for my Zen two and a half years ago.  The upshot is that we're planning to get my oldest daughter an iPod for her birthday (early next month), because the cost differential isn't great enough for the features to make it worth getting something else.I know a disadvantage. ITunes wants to keep everything in it's proprietary format, so it is not that easy to port the songs to standard MP3. You can change the default to MP3, but last time I bought from ITunes I didn't get that choice. Therefore to get these as MP3 I had to burn a CD with the songs, then re-rip them with Windows Media Player to get the MP3 version

Unless you have hd equipment and the program you are watching on tv is mastered for surround sound than that is all you will get.  With your dvd player upgrade to a coaxial audio cable (orange) or optical if you haven't already for far superior sound. (If your system supports this.)your tv output may be variable-this is to say you can alter the information being outputted by using the volume control on your remote so next time try turning up the remote volume-either this or select the appropriate input on your receiver for stereo tv input.-it is also worth noting that if your tv does have variable output ensure the volume is set to mute-this feature should be in the tv's menu. also ensure that the speaker parameters are set for the input supporting your tv (the speaker set-up may not be the same as your DVD players input).

PS2 memory cards are designed to hold game saves only.. while the PSP memory card are designed to hold game saves and music, movies, pictures and such..1000 MB = 1 GB.  The answer is that the technology for the PS2 memory cards is almost 7 years old.  The flash memory technology at today's level was not available back in 2000 with the PS2 launched.No, a gigabyte (GB) is bigger than a megabyte (MB).  I would imagine the reason for the amount of space on the PSP cards is because they're designed to hold music and movies, which take up a lot more space than save game files--which is all the PS2 memory cards are designed to hold.. . ~Scottie
http://en.Wikipedia.org will have the answers for you.Whew... that would be one long answer.  See the article below for a basic understanding.  I just read an article yesterday that said LCDs are going to take the market in about 3- 5 years and that Plasma won't be able to keep up.  It also said that the price of LCD will drop in about 12 months, so if you can hold out, you may want to do so.. . Good luck with your choice!PLASMA uses gas in plasma form for display, LCD uses liquid crystal display and a light source for display DLP Digital Light Processing uses a color wheel and moving mirrors. . Plasma TV is still the biggest, but LCD TV is now also available in a size similiar to a medium Plasma TV and a good one also offer better contrast. A good LCD TV tend to be higher in price than a Plasma TV in the same size.  DLP a little less than plasma and has a smaller market share.   A DLP has a bulb that has to be replaced on a regular basis.  It can be fairly expensive but can be done by the consumer. . . Both LCD and Plasma are thin enough to mount on the wall while a DLP is much lighter but looks like a traditional TV. As for different kinds TVs.. . You may also want to look at getting a projector and mount it to the ceiling.plasma is bad....the screen burns in to fast only lasts 3 to 4 years......... LCD is the best it last 12 to 15 years....... and DLP is digital liquid display but i dont know anything about those...Plasma and LCD are close to the same just LCD cost more are lighter and better picture.DLP are more wide and cheaper but rear projection as in the one sony has are better the DLP but cost a little more. they are worth the money. so get and LCD or LCD projection.To begin with HDTV means high def TV all that you mention can display this signal, Plasma is a gas charged HDTV,  LCD is liquid crystal display that comes in 2 formats flat panel like a plasma or projection that is similar to DLP  the difference is the way the image gets to the screen both LCD and DLP projection have a light source that shines the image to the screen LCD uses small lcd panels 1 or 3 depends on the brand you choose and DLP uses a color wheel combined with the Texas Instruments mirror chip. To make it simple when shopping for a TV go for what fits your room, and wallet (don't waste money getting a flat panel unless you are space deprived or you are really going to hang it on the wall) All these styles of TVs can produce a good HD image  just pick the one that gives the best picture to you. Also don't get caught up on brands either even the cheap brands get their parts from the big brands

Government.the reason is proberly because some of the stores the owners are cheep selfish bastereds!!!!!!!!!!!!!!There are lots of factors. The main ones are import and sales taxes (this is the amount the EU and UK governments add to the cost of the item) and exchange rates (the pound is stronger than many other currencies including the US dollar and the Yen).. . Companies also tend to set their prices based on how much they think customers are prepared to pay for the items they sell, and not necessarily how much the items are worth. Perhaps Sony thinks British consumers are prepared to pay more for the PS3 than American and Japanese consumers?two reasons.. 1) The UK import these items making them more expesive. 2) 17.5% VAT is also payable.welcome to rip-off Britainif people didnt rush out & buy this stuff, the manufacturers would have to drop prices!!. . dont think the british government help either, the more these things sell for, the more vat they getThe government is a little greedy here! You should never use chemicals on it.It is called CRT for Cathode Ray Tube which yes is a TV screen use a soft towel and a little windex applied to the towel wipe gently.Your crt is made of none coated glass on the outside, so it is safe to use windex or other glass cleaners on it.  LCD screens should NEVER have cleaners used on them as they ARE a coated screen.  Use only a damp clean cloth on them.

It's a music player, like a walkman only no need for tapes or CD's, it's all saved on a computer, and in the memory of the playerand MP3 player is a digital music player.  the most common of course is the iPod.  You put music on your computer from CD's you own or Song you pay money to download off of iTunes, and you hook your MP3 player to your computer via a USB cable and put the music on the MP3 player from your computer.  You can then walk around with your MP3 player and a pair of headphones and listen to your music wherever you go, and with the right adapter you can listen in the car.  MP3 players are not made for games at all, but the newly released iPod actually comes with some games such as Tetris and Solitaire.  iPod's range from about 100 bucks to 400 bucks, depending on the hard drive size you buy.  The bigger the hard drive, the more music you can have with you at all times.  That's an MP3 player.  Hope this helps.an MP3 Player just holds songs and music, and allows the owner to listen to these tracks on the go. They start from about £12, but the more you pay, the more songs they store. Hi, Rather than have your earphone plugs hanging down, place them in your ears in the upward position & loop the leads behind your ears this will lessen the drag on the earplugs. Then you can either run the leads down the front of your top or down the back of your neck. Of course a lot will depend on the amount of physical body movement you are engaged in while using your equipment.You have got issues.get your ears loweredTry leaving some slack cable inside your top, then when they snag on your top and pull, theres more cable for it to tug at before they come out of your ears.Try not to make the headphone's strings too tight down your top. Try to let some slack loose. Not much is needed, just don't make it so tight that any slight movement will yank them out of your ears.. . A lot of jackets have internal pockets, so if you're wearing one you could always put the MP3 Player in those. It won't be visible and there will be a lot of loose cord.. . I think you are talking about the Blurps you "hear" in your speakers.  The problem is speakers are not shielded so they pick up energy from outside sources.  In this case GSM is at a frequency that speakers pick up and transmit as audible sound.. . You might notice that it is not always when making a call, it is also when you cell phone sends messages to local towers, you will here a BLURP or two.Well, the phone is a transmitter. The radio signals induce currents in the phone/TV.

The manufacturer.... . Only Apple makes iPodsThey are compatible with different formats of music file.. . mp3 players can play mp3 files, and perhaps other formats such as ogg, depending on the player. Most mp3 players cannot play apple's own proprietary format (the itunes format).. . ipods can play apple's own format as well as mp3, but they can't play ogg.i'm not much of a gizmo freak but as far as i know there are two differences:. 1. ipods are of better quality. . 2. their storage capacity is more.. well, ipods cost much more than an mp3 so i bet its better (stupid....?, but might be! )
If you have HDMI connections, this is the most convenient . way.  See or contact Crutchfield for specific help...Put the white wire where the white wire goes.  Put the red wire where the red wire goes.  Put the thingamabob in the thingsbabob, and BINGO !  There you go.  Maybe someone should've made sure their TV came with instructions mmmm?First, you need to determine what type and how many of a each cable type your TV supports.  The typical inputs are HDMI (flat looking connector, single cable), component (three colored cables that look like the cables to connect your stereo), S-video (one multi-pin cable) and composite ( one cable that looks like the cables to connect your stereo).  This should all be in your TV manual.  Then you need to determine the same thing about your cable box and DVD.  Then, hook a compatible cable between the cable box or DVD to the TV.  The list of cables is in the order of quality...so, HDMI is better than component, etc.  If you are using your receiver for sound, then you will also need to run audio cable from the DVD and cable box to the receiver.

Sorry. It's not possible. You have to have iTunes to sync your music to your iPod...... you realize that they're both Apple products, right? iPods don't work without iTunes. You NEED to use iTunes to put your songs on. That's why a disc came with your iPod that told you to install iTunes... duh. And hopefully you're smart enough to realize to use a P2P network to download songs. *cough*Limewire*cough*...If you bend your iPod in half and buy a real mp3 player, like one from Creative Labs, Samsung or Sandisk, you'll be able to move your music back and forth without restrictive Digital Rights Management (DRM - also known as the Recording Industry's ability to limit your enjoyment).  With almost any of the above players, you can also store your word documents, powerpoint presentations, or whatever computer files with you.  . . And you can share your music with your friends at school with a non-ipod using a simple USB cable.  You just can't do that with an iPod because Apple wanted to corner the .99 cents per song market, and the only way they could do that was to let the Record Companies bend them over for royalties.  As a result, NO SHARING/COPYING/BACKUPS  ALLOWED.. . Joey K, thanks for assuming the poster was illegally downloading music.  For all you know, he ripped all of his CDs on his hard-drive and wanted to transfer mp3 files to his player without loading garbage i-tunes software all over his computer. I'm not sure why you'd want to do this but here goes... The easiest way is to get a sound card for your computer with an S/PDIF digital input that is compatible with the digital output on your minidisc player.  The software that comes with your sound card can record this input digitally which makes a perfect copy to the CD.  . . Please note that since MiniDisc is already a compressed format, going to CD won't lose any quality, but if you convert that CD back to a format like MP3, then you may hear some 'fuzziness' in the recording.. . I've attached a link below to an attachment to popular Sound Blaster cards that will let you do this.  You need this attachment in addition to one of the supported cards listed in the link.well it depends why you are doing it, if you are trying to copy it to cd's to burn on an mp3 like an ipod then dont move it to a cd just download the music you want online. A lot of companies will "lock" your phone, making it impossible to gets songs except straight from them.. . To get songs from your phone company, you have to log onto the internet browser and then go to where it says you can DL songs. Be aware that being on the internet costs money (it will usually warn you before logging in) and songs also cost money. Typically they are around $1-5.. . If your phone is not locked, you can get an adapter to hook your phone up to your computer and I believe it comes with software. I believe your phone supports Mp3s so that makes it easier. Unfortunately the cord adapter is usually kind of expensive and you can't tell if your phone is locked until you try (as far as I've seen).. . the shape. 1st gen the sides are flat. 2nd gen they are round.The number one difference is the case. The Gen 1 cases are plastic and have been prone to scratching. The Gen 2 cases are aluminum. All things being equal, I would get the Gen 2. Brighter screen, more storage, longer battery life, coolness factor.i think that they have different features and storage capacity1st gen has a plastic case (scratches easy) about half the battery life, and a darker screen.. . 2nd gen has an aluminum case (doesn't scratch so easy) 24 hour battery life (and yes I tested it, it is 24 hours) and a 40% brighter screen.

An LP is a vinyl album played on a record player.  A CD is a compact disc - digital media.LP also known as Long Play, is a black disc. it is played by a needle.. . CD known as Compact Disc, is read by date thru a lens.. . nope, you can not play LP on a CD player and you can not also play a CD on a turn tableAn LP is a vinyl disc that cannot be played on a CD player. It's an analog recording, and a CD contains digital recording.

when a digital camera captures a picture, the image is stored. the more pixels are stored for that picture the better quality it will be. one mega pixel is 1,000,000 pixels. that means there is one mega pixel's worth of data stored in your camera and your camera with use one mega pixel  to represent your picture once printed. a pixel is just a certain amount of space represented in a 2 dimensional area.Steve, I'll have some of what you're smoking.. * A pixel is a colored dot.. * Mega means one million.. A one megapixel picture, is a picture that is made up of one million colored dots. A 6 megapixel picture has 6 million dots, etc. . The bigger you print your picture, the bigger all of these dots become - and the more pixels you have, the bigger you can print before the individual dots become discernable.

you pretty much answered your own question.. . a cd/mp3 player, depending on the company, can either play regula CDs and CDs with mp3s or is a CD player that plays CDs AND store mp3s/I think only difference should be that u can play -MP3 cd's on the Mp3 cd player, n on the other only normal cds.The portable Cd player, will only play classic Cd's (like the ones you buy from disk stores). Those have a format of ".wma" A compact disk can average 20 tracks per disk.. . The cd/mp3 player will play the above but it will also play ".mp3" formats. mp3 format is most common in music downloading because it has a significantly lesser size per track. So you can put about 150 songs in the disk.The diff is that the CD/MP3 player can play CD's that have been burned using the mp3 player format.  The MP3 player CD's will not play in the regular one or in any regular cd player that does not have MP3 format.A CD player can only play audio CD's (about 70 minutes).  If it's also an MP3 player, you can put MP3 files on the CD.  They don't take up as much space and you can fit about 700mb.  That should play quite a few hours of music.Not to much really..  The CD/MP3 player just has the ability to decode the mp3 format.

They can check just by knowing your postal code.Hi, I work for a company that sells TV's etc. There are several possible reasons why you can't receive all channels. Firstly, there may not be a strong enough signal on those particular channels in your area. You can check this by going to freeview.co.uk Secondly, your tv aerial may need a booster. These are relatively inexpensive. May be an idea to contact a local aerial installer from the yellow pages to check this. Hope this helps. There are two main types of MP3 players.  These are flash players and hard-drive based players. . . 1) Flash Players.  These players have solid memory in them, which is just like the Ram in your computer.  There are no moving parts, which prevents skipping and increases battery life.  The downside is that flash memory is more expensive per gigabyte (GB) than hard-drive players.. . 2) Hard drive players are just like the hard drive in your computer that stores large volumes of info.  They are cheaper but usually only exist in MP3 players as large drives.  (You're unlikely to find a 4GB Hard Drive player)  They use more power since they have to spin a hard drive inside the device at speeds like 4500 or 5400RPM.  (It's pretty much like a big record spinning inside, but reading the music as digital data). . I'm pretty sure that the flash memory you refer to is built into the device and is not something you need to buy.  I'm not aware of any MP3 players where you buy the memory and add it yourself.  Most likely it is just referring to the type of device that it is.  Hard drive based players have a tiny amount of flash memory that they transfer data to before sending it the the headphones, so maybe this is where the confusion came from.u need flash media playeri suggest you buy an ipod nano with 4 gb that has a hard disk not a flash memory. A flash memory is a memory that if it's overwritten a couple of thousands of time it damages it's self and you can not use it anymore. If you buy an mp3 player with a hard disk you won't have this problem anymoreIf it has the flash memory installed, that's great and very similar to the iPod nano.  Specifically means there's no moving parts.  Some higher capacity mp3 players actually have a hard disk inside.  Flash memory players either have the memory permanently installed or you buy "cards".  In either situation, no moving parts, less to break down.flash only means the memory it already has built into the mp3/mp4 players. it doesn't require you to buy any thing else extra.It means the player has no hard disk. HD players can store up to 60 gigabytes. Normal size is 30 Gb. And no, you don't have to buy anything extra. 4 Gb is good for a flash player. That's its internal memory, It's like your RAM memory in your PC.

Do you mean Bank Switching?. . Bank switching (also known as "paging", but only loosely related to the ordinary meaning of "paging" in computing) was a technique common in 8-bit microcomputer systems, to increase the amount of addressable RAM and ROM without extending the address bus.. . Since 8-bit CPUs such as the Zilog Z80 and the MOS Technology 6502 series, with their 16-bit address registers, could only address a maximum of 64 KB of memory, 8-bit systems containing more than 64 KB of memory addressed the memory in 64 KB banks (or "pages") — in other words, although the system may have contained 128 KB or more, only 64 KB was ever addressed directly at one time. This scheme offered access to more memory at the cost of more complicated programming and somewhat poorer performance.. . While bank switching was less efficient than switching to a processor with a wider address bus would have been, it was an inexpensive way to increase the shelf life of several computer lines of the 1980s and it provided a high degree of backward compatibility with earlier systems: for example, the Apple //e, //c, and Apple /// could run software written for the Apple II+, and the Commodore 128 could run all the software of its much more prevalent predecessor, the C64 (which had already employed bank switching to allow for 64KB of RAM and still provide for ROM as well). Accessing the lower 64 KB part of memory was as simple as addressing the first (lowest) bank. The Atari 130XE used a similar technique, but added the ability for its two processors (the 6502 and the ANTIC) to access separate banks. This allowed programmers to make large playfields and other graphic objects without using up the memory visible to the CPU.. . In 1988 the companies Lotus, Intel and Microsoft agreed on a specification called Expanded Memory System (EMS, also stated as LIM-EMS) for use in IBM PC compatible computers running MS-DOS. It was a form of bank switching technique that allowed more than the 640 KB of RAM foreseen by the original IBM PC architecture, by letting it appear piecewise in a 64KB "window" located in the Upper Memory Area. Some computer games made use of this, and the feature is nowadays emulated by later Microsoft Windows operating systems to provide backwards compatibility with those programs.. . Bank switching was also utilized in some video game consoles. The Atari 2600, for instance, could only address 4 KB of ROM, so later 2600 game cartridges contained their own bank switching hardware in order to permit the use of more ROM and thus allow for more sophisticated games (via more program code and, equally important, larger amounts of gameworld data such as graphics and sound). The Nintendo NES contained a modified 6502 but its cartridges sometimes contained a megabit or more of ROM, addressed via bank switching called a Multi-Memory Controller. Game Boy cartridges used a chip called MBC (Memory Bank Controller), which not only offered ROM bank switching, but also cartridge SRAM bank switching, and even access to such features as infrared links or rumble motors.. . Bank switching was later replaced by segmentation in 16-bit systems, which in turn was replaced by paging memory management units."Switch bank" can mean several switches that work in conjunction with each other. The set of all the pushbutton switches on your cell phone could be considered a "switch bank" because they all provide human interface input for the same device.. . WK

MP3 is a music format.  MP3 players are basically portable music players that use the mp3 format of music.MP3 is a format of storing music electronically. MP3 players will only play this format only.. . You can think of MP3 being similar to how .jpg and .gif are both formats for electronically storing images, and .pdf is an Adobe Acrobat file. They are all storage "formats" and they are all 'file extensions', even .mp3.

yes indeed there are diferences...first thing uk system has pal i,and Australia pal b.. the diference is in sound carrier, 6 for pal i , 5,5 for pal b.But...99,9999% of tvs are multistandard, meaning they'll work on all pal sytems.if not...it can be adjusted with a quick visit to a tv repairsman , there are sound converters available for something like 2$.the chanell problem is even less significant, all the modern tvs have continous bands so it does not matter the tv norm.. Conclusion:there are 95% chances your tv will work in australia too.It should. PAL has one or two versions. But apart from NTSC (never twice same color) It is a std now adopted almost all over.The only problem you may encounter are different wattage and voltage limitations, which can be solved with a transformer.There are several variants of PAL.. . The U.K. uses PAL-I.. . Australia uses PAL-B and G.. . The main difference is the sound-carrier offset which is 6MHz in the I variant and 5.5 in the I.. . This means that a receiver built for one variant won't receive the sound of the other.

Why dont u use HDMI?The deal with component cables assuming you are talking about the Y, Pb, Pr is that they are designed for progressive scan signal. The letter i in 1080i stands for interlaced. The best resolution for use with the component cables is your 720p which is actually better then 1080i. You see the lines of resolution on a interlaced signal are refreshed at 1/60 of a second and alternate every other line so the entire screen does not refresh all at once but more like half and half. Of course this happens way fast. The progressive scan refreshes each line in sequence from first to last at a rate of every 1/30th of a second so use them components and set your DVDs output to its highest resolution ending in p such as 480p or 720p and you will be on the road to great movie experienceIs it a BluRay DVD player? otherwise a standard DVD has no higher resolution than 480p, no matter the cables.Your HD system is only as good as the weakest link.  If you want to run 1080i using the component video you can do that as long as everything else is also 1080i compatible.  That includes your television, DVD player, and even your DVD.  If they are all compatible, you will probably need to go into the settings on your television and DVD player and make sure they are set to play at 1080i.  That having been said, the picture quality on an HDMI connection at 1080i will be a better picture than component video connected at 1080i.   If you can upgrade to the digital signal you won't be disappointed.Be sure your DVD is upconvert capable for starters. Then Use the componet cables. You may also have to select 1080i on the DVD player.
CC1 is the standard Close Captioning format. Some stations/networks air their programs with a secondary Close Caption languages This is not SAP. The stations/networks will let the viewer know when a program is available in another language by displaying a notice and the proper CC mode at the begining of the program. CC2 is currently use by NBC for Spanish Close Captioning and CC3 by Telemundo for English captions.c1 and c2 are 2 agencies that create closed caption. some work better for different stations
The MP3 format was invented by a team of European engineers who worked in the framework of the EUREKA 147 DAB digital radio research programme and finally standardized by ISO/IEC in 1991.. . MP3 encode music is originated by the artist that create the music. Sometimes they encode the music themselves, other times it is done by fans (legally or illegally).MPEG-1 Audio Layer 3, more commonly referred to as MP3, is a popular digital audio encoding and lossy compression format, designed to greatly reduce the amount of data required to represent audio, yet still sound like a faithful reproduction of the original uncompressed audio to most listeners. It was invented by a team of European engineers who worked in the framework of the EUREKA 147 DAB digital radio research programme and finally standardized by ISO/IEC in 1991 .

Unit) standards which enables roaming service for cellular subscribers.Global System for Mobile Communications (cellular phone technology)In Europe the GSM standard (Global Sysytem for Mobile communications)  was introduced in the mid 1980s. There are numerous GSM standards: GSM 900, GSM 1800 and GSM 1900.. . GSM is used in over 135 countries and this standardisation allows for international roaming, data services, text messaging, essentially everything we take for granted on our mobile phones these days.Global System for Mobile communitcation. A European digital standard for mobile or cellular telephony.
