Tv stations make their money from selling ads. They want you to watch the ads for that reason.No offense to anyone, but there's quite a few wrong answers up there. . . The volume does not increase during commercials.  First off, all will agree that the audio in a commercial is generally very loud. 2ndly, when a show "fades to black" to go to commercial, both the video and the audio portion are faded down to zero.  So, when the commercial comes on, it sounds like it's much louder than the show you were watching. What you are hearing is the loudness difference between the quiet part of the show fading to black, and the commercial coming on "balls to the wall".  Additionally, when the show has a very loud scene going on, like a chase scene, it's no quieter than the commercials. The commercials just "seem" louder because of the way human ears work. This can easily be proven using test equipment to measure the peak audio signal during both events.companies know that a lot of people leave the room during commercials to go to the kitchen or whatever else they may want to do, and they want you to still hear their commercial. they want your attention so you will buy their products.They compress the sound.  It helps squeeze more speech into a time slot.  It also gives a stronger, richer sound.  When they record it, it is on normal settings, but when they compress it for broadcast that increases the intensity of the sound.  That makes it louder, even though the broadcasters lie and say it wasn't (they know it is, though "technically" it isn't).I read about this somewhere a few years ago.  TV manufacturers claim that because there's usually music and the voices are over it, it just sound louder.. . Others say for volume there is a range and that commercials transmit at the maximum range to get your attention.. . I guess it's good for when you leave the TV to go to the fridge, if it gets too quiet, it's time to go back, your show is on.the telewaves become differentThey're watching to see how fast you can hit your "mute" button!to get your attention!!!!!!!Actually the volume doesn't change but the compression does.

There is a big difference between digital and optical zooms.  Optical zooms move the lens to make the subject of your picture appear closer (like binoculars or a telescope).  Digital zooms are very different, they don't actually "zoom" at all; digital zoom simply uses the computer in the camera to enlarge the center of the image -- the more it is enlarged the more distorted the image becomes.  So, in researching a quality digital camera a higher optical zoom will provide the highest quality photo.Optical zoom focuses in on something far away, whereas digital zoom only explodes the picture (like when you enlarge a picture on paint); it makes the picture distorted.. . Optical zoom is better.Digital and optical zooms differ at a great extent. By optical zooming, we mean bringing a given object closer to or farther away from you using the movement of the opcital lense in the camera. Most middle-class digital cameras have an optical zoom of 3x, or 4x, however 6x are neither uncommon. The larger the number is being indicated, (3x, 4x, 6x, or 12x or even beyond it) the closer your camera is capable of bringing a given object to you with its lens. . . Digital zooming however is a different thing: Digital zoom, in contrast with optical zoom brings you an object closer to you not be lens movement, but by enlarging the pixels with the camera. In other words, it ENLARGES you the image instead of bringing it closer to you with a lens. This obviously comes with the loss of image quality (noise, sharpness) depending on the degree to which you wish to zoom with it. . . It you're planning on buying a digital camera, make sure it has an OPTICAL zoom as well, not just a digital zoom. Most beginner cameras are nowadays equipped with it, and the smaller zooming range usually starts from 3x or 4x of optical zooming. The digital zooming function is found in almost all of these cameras (you can use the digital zoom once you are no longer able to bring a given object closer to you with the lens, and the camera continues to do this by enlarging the image for you (digital zooming). . . If you're a beginner and plan on buying a camera, I advise you to buy one that is also equipped with an optical stabilizer (this smart option allows you to take sharp photos even if you photography a moving object, therefore they won't become blurred.) Almost all of the Panasonic digital cameras are equipped with an opticalstabilizer and their prices are affordable even for small bugdets. . . In case if optical stabilizer isn't that important for you, the other reliable leading brands are Canon, Nikon, Olympus, Panasonic, Leica, Pentax, Kodak, and Konica-Minolta (this brand does include optical stabilizers in its cameras)   and finally some say HP is also good, but I haven't this brand so far. Good luck with shopping!Digital zoom is like using the magnifier on a picture in Photoshop.. . Optical zoom is REAL, with lenses, etc.. . Simple. Optical is best, digital is just a bonus, 'so what' type of thing.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_zoom. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_zoom. . That was hard.Optical zoom is when the picture enlargement is done by optical means and that means high quality, whereas digital zoom is realized through software that runs in the camera chip, which means lower quality (it inserts pixels that weren't there in the first place).Optical zoom uses lens to actually zoom in and digital zoom is just enlargement of the image.Optical zooming is done using physical lenses and optics, expanding the image naturally.. . Digital zoom is just pixel trickery, the on-board chip in the camera interpolates what the missing parts of the image should be, by comparing adjacent colors. Not very useful.Optical zoom makes image got closer in stages

A "Monophonic" ringtone is a ringer with one variable tone, like the old Nokia ringers. (kinda like an 8-bit video game.). . A "Polyphonic" ringer is one with multiple tones that can produce near song quality music. (Like a 16- bit video game.). . . If you ever listened to Nintendo game music when it came on, it sounded "one sided", like someone was repeating the same thing at a different pitch. that's what Monophonic means: the same tone with different pitch variables.. . The Same is true with Polyphonic tones, but if you played Sega Genesis. The music for Sonic The Hedgehog sounded more like actual music.I think you mean monophonic and polyphonic.  If you are referring to ring tones phonic would be having to do with soung versus graphic having to do with visuals.  Monophonic means one sound and polyphonic means two or more.  Most phones have polyphonic and they may have 64 or more different "voices" that can be played simultaneously.
When you talk wattage there are a few terms that come into play.  Peak wattage which is the most the speakers can take, but are not designed to be operated at, and then continuous is where they perform best.  There are more and the manufacturer likes to put the big numbers up there to impress people who do not understand the terminology.400 watts Music mean or PMPO means it is the short term rating of the speaker.For example for one second.The measurements in themselves are kinda meaningless to be honest, there should be more data given to make it meaningful.. . RMS=Root Means Squared is the the most meaningful measurement to most users, it also gives the lowest number. . . However saying RMS is not enough. The spec should say something like 20Hz-20KHz RMS handling 100W.. . Then you can compare it to two other figures...something like.... 20 Hz 40 W RMS. . This tells you that even though the speaker will go as low as 20Hz, it isn't really very good at it.. . Ditto for higher treble frequencies.. . The result of having speakers with dramatically different RMS ratings for very low frequencies and very high frequencies is that the sound will come through unbalanced. It will be very toppy or very middy.. . Continuous is a version of the RMS measurement. . . Let's not get too technical, but let's say that speaker manufacturers who can't afford, or don't care about the proper RMS measurement quote "continuous" ratings.. . They are somewhat comparable to RMS but not quite as accurate.. . So what does Music mean?. . Music ratings and their first cousin "program" ratings depend on a fact that hifi buffs discovered long ago.. . It was, in the 1940s, better to overdrive your speakers. That is if they are rated at 60W, drive them with a 100W amp.. . This was very practicable in the 40s-60s because tube amplifier technology had a different charactertistic to the transistors used today.. . Also music back then tended to have peaks of volume and quiet bits. . . The quiet bits allowed the speakers to cool down and avoid meltdown.. . It is dubious to try this out on a modern amplifier and speakers with modern transistor technology.. . So a music rating is what the speakers will handle "long term" OVERDRIVEN with "typical" material.. . These days the only thing that fits that "typical" material is either classical music or vocal music.. . So taking the two specs together, what it means is that if you are listening to a choir singing, you can use a 400Watt amp to power them without blowing the speakers. This means that when the choir suddenly hit a loud bit, you get a very exciting rush of volume.. . PMPO is what the previous contributor got a bit mixed up about.. . A speaker doesn't sadly respond equally well to all parts of the sound spectrum. It can handle loud volume in one part really well, but blow to pieces with an equally loud volume at another part of the sound spectrum.. . PMPO plots help you avoid blowing speakers by telling you that a speaker will take a 1KHz tone at 800W for one second without blowing, whereas it will take an 500Hz signal for 9 seconds without blowing.. . Using this knowledge very selectively can help you not blow up your speakers.. . PMPO is a very useful measurement, but the previous contributor is right in saying that some manufacturers just give the loudest PMPO measurement in order to look good.. . If you want loud music, buy a pair of 100W RMS speakers with a flattish response curve. Ask the salesman to show you the curve and compare it to those of other speakers.. . If the response curve is stable, then 100W is really loud in the average living room. Plenty loud.

Best thing is this that Split AC is very quiet as compared to Window's a jet engine.. secondly you don't need a big hole just a little one that u can say connector between both indoor and outdoor unit. Difference is physical size. Both are 75ohms, which means if you measure the resistance between the center conductor and the shield in a 1000 foot long piece of cable, it will measure 75 ohms. Generally RG6 is superior.RG-6 is double or quad shield cable suitable for distribution of cable TV in home wiring, good up to 1 Ghz. frequency. It is low loss, so longer runs see little signal loss. Due to it's excellent shielding, it has very good rejection of outside interference. On the other hand, RG-59 is a cheaper, smaller TV cable, that has a higher loss, and poor shielding. It is not recommended for a good home TV distribution. It is widely used in black and white 'security cameras' due to it's small diameter. However for color, the cable is susceptable to interference, loss with length, and poor high frequency transmission.RG6 can carry a greater bandwidth, and therefore more information. RG6 is critical for cable runs between a satellite receiver and a satellite dish because while the satellite signal goes from the dish to the receiver, electricity to power the dish also runs from the satellite receiver to the satellite dish and RG59 is just not stable enough.

at RadioShack they have a little (but expensive) plug that will convert the Pal format to NTSC...that i am aware of you cant remove a dvds region code by riping it and reburning it.  its all in the frame rate the speed of playback and more.  its not that easy.yes you're doing it wrong.... you need more gear than you're using. You need a PAL playback device with component output; send that output into a multi system time base corrector with component video capability or equivalent, then output that into a DVD burner.. I'm not 100%, but I think it would be cheaper to buy the disc with region1 coding.
to prevent glaires1) To desguise the camera. Most people don't know it's a camera when they see a dome.. 2) To prevent you from knowing where the camera is pointing to. This will discourage someone trying to hide from the camera.Because cameras are very gaudy and look horribly unattractive, that's the aesthetic reason.  The functional reason is as stated above: so you can't tell whether you're being watched.  The dome could also hide the fact that there is no camera there at all--they just want you to think you're being watched so you behave accordingly.Some plastic domes are used to enable the camera to move to point to a target. I have seen some cameras that are used outdoors that have a wide range of movement. I don´t think is your case. Fixed cameras are mounted in big metal boxes. The small ones can be happily fitted in domes like the one you are talking about. In any case avoid eye contact for your own safety.

It does not come with even the standard 50mm lense/There is no camera lens"body only" means that you get only the camera basics without lens. This is of course only possible concerning (D)SLR.. . The advantage is that you can combine the camera body (main functions) and lens (wide angel, zoom, tele) you need.

Vent is available through copper pipe in split ACsplit ac is more effective, costly n beneficial than window ac bcoz it saves power, cools the area faster, has more facilities....split ac is more effective, costly n beneficial than window ac bcoz it saves power, cools the area faster, has more facilities eg THERMOSTAT etc.. split can also be installed simultaneously in 2 rooms but u may need an well qualified engineer for that.most important, there is no need to make a large hole in the wall.

It's just not practical to make them wide enough to avoid the lines completely. The scanning method would need to be changed, raising the price significantly.Your widescreen TV has a 16:9 ratio (1.78).  Most widescreen films have even wider ratios, as much as 2.35.  You get LESS of the black lines, but (unless you find a film that is presented at the 1.78 ratio), you'll always have some.. . Edit: The point to buying a 16:9 TV is that TELEVISION is (will be) broadcast at 16:9.  The bars will only be present (like I said above) if you're watching a MOVIE.  TV shows (hi def) are 16:9.  You will get the entire picture with no black bars.   THAT is the purpose of widescreen TV.  No TVs are being made that will match the width ratio of movie screens -- it's incorrect to assume that the reason for widescreen tvs is to watch movies without the bars.The resolution that ure source has isnt actually wide screen, but has been formatted to fit and work on wide screen by adding the black lines.. . if u have a dvd movie that is double sided and has widescreen on one side and regular on the other u wud notice the difference.. . the quality of the resolution has to be set to widescreen at the source and that is usually attained from original dvds.. . SAY NO TO PIRACY AND BUY ORIGINAL. . REPORT ALL FAKES TO 1-800-NOCOPYEven PC monitors have them. Black lines come from  wires which are used to keep the deflection panels in place. Those panels are used do control the flow of electrons from the emitter to the screen.This black line is Normal , If you didn't know Evey film that is shot today they use this type of Camera, So every time you see Movie with these Black lines is the best way to view the movie , as this is how the Director seen it :) ............There is abit more to it but I'm sure your see what i mean !That should only happen with films shot in panavision. It's call a proximity effect.  The exaggeration of low-frequency sounds in a directional microphone when it is very near the sound source. An increase in bass response occurs when the sound source is near the microphone, a loss in bass response is experienced as the microphone is moved away. The same occurs with headphones, speakers, etc.the ear buds are touching your head, and the bass gets transmitted directly into your skull bones.

a blue tooth and infrared connectivity is both wire less but in infrared you have to keep both the devices as close as possible where as in blue tooth you can take the device any where in a distase of 10 mtrs...I am not too clear abt wap(wireless application protocol)... but Bluetooth uses RF signals(same as radio signals, but having different frequency) to communicate with devices within abt 10 meters..   Infrared uses infrared signals(used most commonly in tv remotes) to communicate. they have shorter range and require devices to be kept in a line....not too popular after bluetooth appeared.i do nt know about wap but the difference between a blue tooth and infrared is just that a blue tooth can operate at a distance 10 mtrs and in infrared you have to keep both the devices sticking to each other....Go to bluetooth.com. They compare the different wireless technologies and the information varies from basic user information to in-depth specifications. The site below compares the different technologies.

CD-R: CD Recordable. you can only place information on them, you can't erase the info on them.. . CD-RW: CD ReWriteable. You can burn them and erase the information to reuse it again.. . Pretty simple huh?. . P.S. The more you erase a CD-RW, the integrity of the data becomes questionable, and sometimes you may not be able to access some of your stuff.Cdr is a writable disk . cannot be reused .  A cdrw is a writeable, erasable and reuseable.  you can continue to add and erase data( these are the best)yeah what everyone else said..... plus cdrw cost more than the cdrs. use cdrws for like skool thats what i do...cdrs are good for music..its a waste to not record over a cdrw again..than it will die in vain becasue it could not fufill their purpose....(tear) lolyou can record only once onto a cdr---multiple times on a cdrw----rw===re-writableCD-R = CD-Recorderable (can only be written to, not erasable). CD-RW = CD-Rewriterable (can be written over and over again & also erasable)On a CDRW you can re-write things on that disc. Once you write something to a CDR, it cannot be used again.cdr = 1 time recording. cdrw =recorded  many times earce it
make sure that there is plenty of heat, to cold of a solder iron will cause a bad fillet, you want enough heat for the type of solder your using and also make sure to use flux, this will help with the smoothness of the fillet and let it get to where you are trying to get it to (inside holes or to flow around a lead or bend) you don't want the heat to high though because you can burn the item you are trying to solder to as well. good luck.Put that robotic machine to work, i suppose that's what its for !!!. . Enjoy that fillet !!!!
Dish uses Satlite receiver while Cable uses an Antenna. . . Cable is a system of providing television, FM radio programming and other services to consumers via radio frequency signals transmitted directly to people’s televisions through fixed optical fibers or coaxial cables as opposed to the over-the-air method used in traditional television broadcasting (via radio waves) in which a television antenna is required.digital cable is the latest version of regular cable - hard wired to your house only in digital format which allows for digital TV and audio.. . Dish is similar only broadcast from satellites to a dish mounted on the side of your house.Essentially its the same thing from a user's standpoint. The dish is an actual satellite dish that is mounted outside of your house in order to recieve the television signal whille digital cable is facilitated through the underground cable line from your local cable company. . . What makes the dish programming so good is that it has interactive menus and program guides that you could not get on regular cable tv. Digital cable gives you the best of both worlds because your signal is not affected by snow, wind, or rain the same way that the dish is affected.You eat off a Dish while watching Digital Cable..."Dish uses Satlite receiver while Cable uses an Antenna". . Bollocks.. . A "dish" is an antenna, or more correctly it is the most recognisable and largest part of a microwave antenna.  . . A cabl system uses .... a cable, not a receiver and its consequent need for an antenna.Digital Cable is a cable through your house that comes from your local company. Dish is a satellite communication with the network that is transmitted trough space. digital cable cost more. $65. I just switched to them from Direct TV. direct TV was $43. I switched because they offered a special deal-$25 off each month for 16 months. now the Price is the same. The difference is the package came with all the Encore channels and a few learning channels. after 16 months I will look for a deal with Direct TV or Dish. Their is always a good deal. Just keep your eyes open and you will find one.. They all have features better than the other and the have features worse than the other.About $30 for the same number of channels.
